comments.author: martinald
comments.content: The problem is essentially memory bandiwdth afiak. Simplifying a lot in my reply, but most NPUs (all?) do not have faster memory bandwidth than the GPU. They were originally designed when ML models were megabytes not gigabytes. They have a small amount of very fast SRAM (4MB I want to say?). LLM models _do not_ fit into 4MB of SRAM :).And LLM inference is heavily memory bandwidth bound (reading input tokens isn't though - so it _could_ be useful for this in theory, but usually on device prompts are very short).So if you are memory bandwidth bound anyway and the NPU doesn't provide any speedup on that front, it's going to be no faster. But has loads of other gotchas so no real "SDK" format for them.Note the idea isn't bad per se, it has real efficiencies when you do start getting compute bound (eg doing multiple parallel batches of inference at once), this is basically what TPUs do (but with far higher memory bandwidth).
comments.content_cn: 问题的核心本质上是内存带宽限制。简单来说，大多数（甚至全部？）NPU的内存带宽并不比GPU快。它们最初是为兆字节而非千兆字节的机器学习模型设计的。NPU内置少量极快的SRAM（我记得大概是4MB？）。而LLM模型显然无法装入4MB的SRAM。并且LLM推理过程严重受限于内存带宽（不过读取输入标记不受此限——因此理论上NPU在这方面可能有用，但设备上的提示词通常很短）。所以，如果你已经受限于内存带宽，而NPU在这方面无法提供加速，那么它就不会更快。此外NPU还存在大量其他问题，因此没有真正的“SDK”格式支持。需要说明的是，这个想法本身并不差，当你确实开始遇到计算瓶颈时（例如同时进行多批次并行推理），NPU能带来实际效率提升——这基本上是TPU的工作方式（但TPU的内存带宽要高得多）。

posts.title: Microsoft May Have Created the Slowest Windows in 25 Years with Windows 11
posts.author: nabla9
posts.title_cn: 微软可能用Windows 11创造了25年来最慢的Windows系统
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕“Windows 11可能是微软25年来最慢的Windows系统”这一核心话题展开。用户普遍对Windows 11的性能表现和设计方向表示不满，认为系统存在明显的响应迟滞问题，例如右键菜单加载缓慢、开始菜单出现广告等。许多用户指出，即使在高端硬件上运行，系统仍感觉卡顿，且频繁的更新和强制重启影响使用体验。

讨论中提到，部分用户认为测试环境（如使用不兼容的旧硬件）可能影响了基准结果，但更多人强调问题在于系统本身过度集成AI功能、加入广告推送，导致资源占用增加。有用户对比了早期Windows版本（如Windows 2000）的高效，表达了对当前系统偏离“工具性”的失望。同时，也有用户指出他们正转向Linux系统（如KDE、CachyOS），因其在相同硬件上表现更流畅。

共识在于，社区普遍认为Windows 11在性能和用户体验上显著退步，尤其反感系统内置广告和强制更新。分歧主要体现在对问题根源的分析：有人认为微软过度追求AI集成牺牲了效率，也有用户强调硬件兼容性和测试方法的影响，但整体上对Windows 11的负面评价占主导。

comments.content: Running W11 on unsupported hardware aside.I was surprised the other day when I used a W11 machine that the new context menu took a perceptible second to appear and it still didn't have everything the old had so you still have to call the old one, very dismaying.
comments.content_cn: 抛开在不支持的硬件上运行W11不谈。前几天我使用一台W11电脑时很惊讶，新的右键菜单需要明显的一秒才能出现，而且它仍然没有包含旧菜单的所有功能，所以你仍然得调用旧菜单，这非常令人沮丧。

comments.author: WillAdams
comments.content: If I could still be running Windows 2000, I would --- it simply flew on a Fujitsu Stylistic ST2300, and I was able to hack the Compaq TC1000 Finepoint digitizer driver for Windows NT to run on it --- w/ a CF--IDE adapter, no spinning rust to worry about, and I even had room for a full install of Encarta, my only worry until it died was buying AAAA batteries for the stylus, and the only thing I missed was pressure sensitivity (but my work computer had a Wacom Intuos, so the delicate stuff was done on that).That said, my favourite Windows computer ever was the Fujitsu Stylistic ST4110 w/ transflective display and Wacom EMR digitizer --- put an SSD in it, carried a couple of spare batteries, added a USB GPS, and kept a pair of docking stations w/ power supplies at my desks at work and the office and a third power supply in my laptop bag and it just worked --- despair of really replacing it, the Samsung Galaxy Book 12 was close, but then Fall Creators Update came out and crippled styluses down to an 11th touch input so that they would scroll rather than select text... getting by w/ a Book 3 Pro 360, but Windows 11 has me looking at a Raspberry Pi paired w/ a Wacom One or Movink display....
comments.content_cn: 如果现在还能用Windows 2000系统，我绝对会继续使用——它在富士通Stylistic ST2300上运行如飞，我还成功将康柏TC1000的Finepoint数位屏Windows NT驱动移植到这台设备上。通过CF-IDE转接器，完全无需担心机械硬盘故障，甚至能完整安装Encarta百科全书。设备报废前我唯一的困扰就是得四处购买手写笔专用的AAAA电池，唯一缺失的功能是压感识别（不过工作电脑配备了Wacom Intuos数位板，精细操作都在那上面完成）。话说回来，我最钟爱的Windows设备始终是配备半透反射屏幕和Wacom EMR数位板的富士通Stylistic ST4110——加装固态硬盘、随身携带备用电池、外接USB全球定位系统，在办公室和工作室各配置一个带电源的扩展坞，笔记本电脑包里还常备第三个电源适配器，这套组合始终稳定可靠。真正令我感到遗憾的是难以找到替代品，三星Galaxy Book 12曾接近完美，但秋季创意者更新后触控笔被降级为第11点触控输入，导致滚动时误选文字……目前勉强用着Book 3 Pro 360，但Windows 11系统让我开始考虑搭配Wacom One或Movink显示屏的树莓派方案。

comments.author: doodlesdev
comments.content: Regarding the video benchmark on the page: what would be fair is testing against the hardware that was available when the operating system was released. Windows 11 is absolutely not meant to run against hard drives, and current notebook and desktop offerings for home and enterprise users reflect that: you can get a 256gb SSD for a pretty decent price nowadays, to the point there's absolutely no reason to put in an HDD. When Windows Vista was released, your computer would absolutely have an HDD, so that would be a fair comparison.That said, I was restoring a notebook owned by my aunt recently and I decided to run Ubuntu on it so I could mess with gparted a little bit. I'm already a full-time Linux user (have been for about five years now, I guess), but I was still surprised to see that one of the most bloated Linux distributions ran lightning fast on my aunt's Pentium Gold + 4gb RAM + HDD while Windows took over four minutes to boot.It's absolutely time to abandon Windows if you're still dependent on it. There are alternatives. Heck, I'm not a fan of Apple either but at this point I'd recommend a MacBook for anyone wanting to get away from Windows and not comfortable with Linux or a Chromebook.
comments.content_cn:
关于页面上的视频基准测试：公平的做法应该是用操作系统发布时市面上已有的硬件进行测试。Windows 11完全不是为机械硬盘设计的，当前面向家庭和企业用户的笔记本与台式机配置也印证了这一点——如今256GB固态硬盘的价格已经相当合理，完全没有理由再使用机械硬盘。而Windows Vista发布时，电脑普遍配备机械硬盘，那样的对比才具有公平性。

话说回来，最近我帮姑姑修复她的笔记本时，决定安装Ubuntu系统以便稍微折腾一下gparted分区工具。虽然我已是全职Linux用户（大概有五年了），但当我看到这个被称为最臃肿的Linux发行版，在姑姑那台奔腾金牌处理器+4GB内存+机械硬盘的电脑上运行如飞，而Windows启动耗时超过四分钟时，仍然感到震惊。

如果你仍依赖Windows系统，现在绝对是时候考虑转换了。市面上存在其他选择。说实话，我本身也不是苹果粉丝，但就目前而言，对于想摆脱Windows又不熟悉Linux或Chromebook的用户，我会推荐他们选择MacBook。

comments.author: hshdhdhj4444
comments.content: If you want an OS to simply do stuff Linux is now clearly superior.However, I found Omarchy to be whatever the opposite of a sweet spot is. It brings all the complications of a tiling WM, so you still have to learn a complicated new way of using your system, but at the same time it is extremely opinionated so instead of ending with a tailored custom tiling WM that suits your needs at the end of the learning curve, you end up with a tiling WM that is suited for someone else’s needs.On the flip side, the simplifications it does add, such as a supposedly easier way to add packages, does no such thing. comments.author: user2722
comments.content:
May not have been a fair test. Windows is running the kernel in a kinda VM which older computers have not been optimized for -- newer generations of CPU can smooth out the overhead.For a fair test against Windows 10 and below, you'll have at least to do this:
"Temporarily turn off your Memory Integrity and VMP" -- https://support.microsoft.com/en-USAlso, it's important to have all bits and pieces of Hyper-V/Windows Virtual Platform off (which the Menory Integrity relies on), thus cutting off WSL functionality.We don't need flawed tests to tell us Windows 11 sucks -- yesterday my explorer bar didn't respond to clicks nor Windows key. In the past killing explorer.exe and restarting it, or logging off and back on, worked. Yesterday I had to reboot the machine to fix it.
comments.content_cn:
这可能不是一个公平的测试。Windows 在某种虚拟机中运行内核，而旧款计算机并未对此进行优化——新一代 CPU 能够减轻这种开销。为了与 Windows 10 及更低版本进行公平比较，你至少需要这样做：
“暂时关闭内存完整性和 VMP”——详见微软官方支持页面。此外，必须完全关闭 Hyper-V/Windows 虚拟平台的所有相关功能（内存完整性依赖于此），从而切断 WSL 功能。
我们不需要有缺陷的测试来证明 Windows 11 糟糕——昨天我的任务栏对点击和 Windows 键毫无反应。过去通过结束 explorer.exe 进程并重启，或注销后重新登录就能解决。昨天我却不得不重启电脑才恢复正常。

comments.author: api
comments.content: The reason for this is that it's hard to hire native UI developers, but easy to hire web devs.Something like 90% of all new devs today learn only cloud-native backend dev or web frontend dev. The only exceptions tends to be mobile and game developers. Collectively cloud+web, mobile, and games account for like 98% of all new devs it seems. Nobody learns anything else.The web is going to become the desktop UI in the future for this reason alone. It's going to be slower and much more bloated than almost any other alternative, but it's got the critical mass of adoption behind it and that's what determines core technologies in the industry. Technical merit is a distant second or third.This is frustrating but it's not surprising to one who has studied biology and evolution. In evolution this is called "path dependence," and it's why we have weird things like a man's testicles hanging in a bag below his body. A previous evolutionary path optimized the sperm production process to run at a lower temperature than the rest of the body, so then evolution's hack for this is to put them in a bag outside the body. Ticket closed with "resolved." The pathways taken through a complex solution space determine the outcome and the outcome is often bizarre and "hacky" for this reason. The key is that it's very hard to back-track. Once a path has been taken, it's very hard to un-take it.Large industries and markets are essentially "biological," not rationally designed, so you get the same kinds of phenomena.It could be much worse. If Linux+HTML+JS had not taken over, we might have the Microsoft Enterprise Web(tm) where Visual Basic (not VB.NET, OG Visual Basic) is the main language and each service or site would require an NT license for every node and an IIS license for every web hostname. UIs might be written in ActiveX or desktop ones in Microsoft C/C++ with OLE and similar horrors. It might be just as slow and infinitely uglier and more expensive and less open. Apple would be dead and open source would much more marginalized than it is today. The net would basically be a total MS monopoly. If you didn't live through the 90s: this nearly happened.
comments.content_cn:
原因在于，原生UI开发人员难招聘，而网页开发者却容易招到。如今大约90%的新开发者只学习云原生后端开发或网页前端开发，唯一的例外通常是移动端和游戏开发者。总体来看，云+网页、移动端和游戏开发者似乎占了所有新开发者的98%左右，几乎没人学习其他方向。

正因如此，网页未来将成为桌面UI的主流。虽然它可能比几乎所有其他方案都更慢、更臃肿，但其背后有着庞大的用户基础，而这正是决定行业核心技术的关键因素。技术优势反而退居次要地位。

这种现象令人沮丧，但对研究过生物学和进化论的人来说并不意外。进化论中称之为“路径依赖”，这解释了为什么人类会出现诸如男性睾丸悬垂于体外的奇特结构——早期进化路径将精子生产过程优化为在低于体温的环境中进行，于是进化采取的方案就是把它们放在体外的囊袋中。问题就此“解决”。在复杂的解决方案空间中，所选择的路径决定了结果，而结果往往因此显得怪异且“凑合”。关键在于路径很难回溯，一旦走上某条路，就难以回头。

大型行业和市场本质上是“生物性”的，而非理性设计的产物，因此你会看到类似的现象……

posts.title: “Erdos problem #728 was solved more or less autonomously by AI”
posts.author: cod1r
posts.title_cn: “埃尔德什问题第728号已由AI基本自主解决”
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕AI在数学证明中的角色展开，核心话题是AI工具Aristotle是否“自主”解决了Erdős问题#728。多数用户认为AI并未完全独立解决问题，而是与人类形成了协作关系：有人指出人类研究者需要在不同AI工具间传递结果并填补逻辑缺口，因此更像是“50/50的合作”。讨论中多次提到对AI形式化验证的担忧，例如如何确保AI生成的Lean代码准确对应原始问题，避免生成“看似合理但实际错误”的内容。同时，社区关注AI对数学研究生态的长期影响，包括学术评价（如AI合著论文如何影响职称晋升）以及数学家职业前景的变化。尽管存在分歧，但普遍认同AI能显著加速研究进程，尤其肯定Aristotle这类专业工具超越通用大模型的潜力。也有用户强调，当前AI仍依赖人类引导，尚不能替代数学家的创造性思维。

comments.author: maxwells-daemon
comments.content: I work at Harmonic, the company behind Aristotle.To clear up a few misconceptions:- Aristotle uses modern AI techniques heavily, including language modeling.- Aristotle can be guided by an informal (English) proof. If the proof is correct, Aristotle has a good chance at translating it into Lean (which is a strong vote of confidence that your English proof is solid). I believe that's what happened here.- Once a proof is formalized into Lean (assuming you have formalized the statement correctly), there is no doubt that the proof is correct. This is the core of our approach: you can do a lot of (AI-driven) search, and once you find the answer you are certain it's correct no matter how complex the solution is.Happy to answer any questions!
comments.content_cn:
我在Harmonic工作，这是开发Aristotle的公司。澄清几个误解：
- Aristotle大量运用现代AI技术，包括语言建模。
- Aristotle可以通过非形式化（英文）证明来引导。如果证明正确，Aristotle有很大机会将其转化为Lean语言（这相当于对你的英文证明投下了强有力的信任票）。我认为这次的情况正是如此。
- 一旦证明被形式化到Lean中（假设你已正确形式化陈述），那么证明的正确性就毋庸置疑。这是我们方法的核心：你可以进行大量（AI驱动的）搜索，一旦找到答案，无论解决方案多么复杂，你都能确信它是正确的。
很乐意回答任何问题！

comments.content: I have kept track of a few instances where AI has been applied to real and genuine problems. ~Not trivial problems. Issues with possible solutions, errors, and unresolved history.AI did not \\"solve\\" any issues on its own, but what stood out to me was the speed at which concepts could be rewritten, restructured and tested for stress.A mental model that has been useful to me is that AI is not particularly good at providing the first answer, however, it is very good at providing the second, third, and tenth versions of the answer, especially when the first answer has already been identified as weak by a human.In these instances, the progress seemed to stem from the AI being able to: Quickly reword and restate a given argument. Convert implicit assumptions into explicit ones. Identify small gaps in logic before they became large.What I have been grappling with is how to differentiate when AI is just clarifying versus when it is silently hallucinating structure. Is the output of AI being treated as a draft, a reviewer, a rubber duck, or some combination? When is the output so fast that the rigor of thought is compromised? I am interested in how others are using AI for hard thinking and not just for writing cleanup.

我关注过一些人工智能应用于真实且重要问题的案例——绝非琐碎问题，而是那些存在潜在解决方案、存在错误且有未解决历史背景的难题。人工智能并未“独立解决”任何问题，但令我印象深刻的是它能够以极快的速度对概念进行重述、重构和压力测试。对我而言一个有用的思维模型是：人工智能并不擅长提供第一个答案，但它非常擅长提供答案的第二版、第三版乃至第十版，特别是在人类已识别出初版答案存在缺陷的情况下。

在这些案例中，进展似乎源于人工智能能够：快速重述和重构给定论点；将隐性假设转化为显性表述；在逻辑漏洞扩大前及时发现它们。

It may help to look at this example concretely:The natural-language statement of the problem is (from https://www.erdosproblems.com/728):> Let C>0 and ϵ>0 be sufficiently small. Are there infinitely many integers a,b,n with a≥ϵn and b≥ϵn such that a!b!∣n!(a+b−n)! and a+b>n+Clogn?The Lean-language statement of the problem (which can be done either by hand or by AI) is (from https://github.com/plby/lean-proofs/blob/f44d8c0e433ab285541...):    ∀ᶠ ε : ℝ in [>] 0, ∀ C > (0 : ℝ), ∀ C' > C,
      ∃ a b n : ℕ,
        0 < n ∧
        ε * n < a ∧
        ε * n < b ∧
        a ! * b ! ∣ n ! * (a + b - n)! ∧
        a + b > n + C * log n ∧
        a + b < n + C' * log n

Yes on the one hand, one needs to know enough about Lean to be sure that this formulation matches what we intend, and isn't stating something trivial. But on the other hand, this is not as hard as finding an error on some obscure line of a long proof.(There's also an older formulation at https://github.com/google-deepmind/formal-conjectures/blob/f... but the new one is more in the spirit of what was intended: see the discussion starting at https://www.erdosproblems.com/forum/thread/728#post-2196 which gives a clear picture, as of course does Tao's thread in the OP that summarizes this discussion.)

具体来看这个例子或许会有所帮助：该问题的自然语言表述如下（摘自https://www.erdosproblems.com/728）：
> 设C>0且ϵ>0足够小。是否存在无穷多组整数a,b,n满足a≥ϵn和b≥ϵn，使得a!b!整除n!(a+b−n)!且a+b>n+Clogn？
该问题的Lean语言表述（可通过人工或AI完成）如下（摘自https://github.com/plby/lean-proofs/blob/f44d8c0e433ab285541...）：
    ∀ᶠ ε : ℝ in [>] 0, ∀ C > (0 : ℝ), ∀ C' > C,
      ∃ a b n : ℕ,
        0 < n ∧
        ε * n < a ∧
        ε * n < b ∧
        a ! * b ! ∣ n ! * (a + b - n)! ∧
        a + b > n + C * log n ∧
        a + b < n + C' * log n

一方面，我们需要对Lean有足够了解，才能确信这个形式化表述符合我们的意图，而非陈述了某种平凡情况。但另一方面，这并不像在冗长证明的某条晦涩行文中寻找错误那样困难。
（另有一个较早的表述版本位于https://github.com/google-deepmind/formal-conjectures/blob/f...，但新版本更符合原意精神：可参阅https://www.erdosproblems.com/forum/thread/728#post-2196开始的讨论，其中给出了清晰说明，当然陶哲轩在原帖中总结该讨论的线索也提供了明确阐释。）

comments.author: teiferer
comments.content: An issue with this approach is that it may not be robust. That is, you could run into a casr where a minor modification of your program is suddenly not provable anymore, even though it is still correct. The heuristic (AI or otherwise) has necessarily limits, and if your are close to the "edge" of its capabilities then a minor change could push it across.If the proof is rooted in the programmer's understanding who can give proof hints to the prover then any modification of the program can then be accompanied with a modification of the hints, still allowing automatic proofs. But if the human has no clue then the automatic system can get stuck without the human having a chance to help it along.
comments.content_cn: 这种方法存在一个问题，即可能不够稳健。也就是说，你可能会遇到这样的情况：对程序进行微小修改后，尽管它仍然是正确的，却突然无法被证明。启发式方法（无论是人工智能还是其他方法）必然有其局限性，如果你的程序处于其能力“边缘”，那么微小的改动就可能使其超出范围。如果证明根植于程序员的理解，而程序员能够向证明器提供提示，那么对程序的任何修改都可以伴随着提示的修改，从而仍然允许自动证明。但如果人类对此一无所知，那么自动系统可能会陷入困境，而人类却无法提供帮助。

comments.author: sibrahim
comments.content: That's what's covered by the "assuming you have formalized the statement correctly" parenthetical.Given a formal statement of what you want, Lean can validate that the steps in a (tedious) machine-readable purported proof are valid and imply the result from accepted axioms. This is not AI, but a tiny, well reviewed kernel that only accepts correct formal logic arguments.So, if you have a formal statement that you've verified to represent what you are interested in by some other means, Lean can tell you whether the proof created by genAI is correct. Basically, there is a nigh infallible checker that won't accept incorrect hallucinations.
comments.content_cn: 括号中“假设你已正确形式化陈述”所涵盖的正是这一点。给定一个形式化的目标陈述，Lean能够验证（冗长的）机器可读的所谓证明步骤是否有效，并从公认公理中推导出结果。这并非人工智能，而是一个经过严格审查的微型内核，仅接受正确的形式逻辑论证。因此，如果你有一个形式化陈述，且已通过其他方式验证其表达了你的研究目标，那么Lean可以判断由生成式AI创建的证明是否正确。本质上，这是一个近乎无误的检查器，不会接受错误的幻觉式结论。

comments.author: maccam912
comments.content: To answer the question a different way, I think you are asking how we know the proof actually matches the description the human provided? And I'd say we can't know for sure, but the idea is that you can pretty concisely write and check yourself that the problem is accurate, i.e. "There are an infinite number of primes" or whatever, and then even if an LLM goes off and makes up a lean proof wildly different from your description, if lean says the proof is valid then you have proven the original statement. I guess in theory the actual proof could be way different than what you thought it would be, but ultimately all the logic will still check out.
comments.content_cn: 换种方式回答这个问题，我想您是在问我们如何确保证明与人类提供的描述相符？我认为我们无法完全确定，但关键在于您可以相当简洁地撰写并自行验证问题的准确性，例如“存在无限多个素数”之类的陈述。这样一来，即使大型语言模型自行发挥，构建出一个与您描述截然不同的Lean证明，只要Lean验证该证明有效，您就完成了对原始命题的证明。理论上，实际证明可能与您的预期大相径庭，但最终所有逻辑环节仍会通过验证。

comments.author: maxwells-daemon
comments.content: Thank you! It depends on the topic. Some fields (algebra, number theory) are covered well by Lean's math library, and so I think we are already there; I recommend trying Aristotle for yourself to see how reliably it can formalize these theorems!In other fields (topology, probability, linear algebra), many key definitions are not in Mathlib yet, so you will struggle to write down the theorem itself. (But in some cases, Aristotle can define the structure you are talking about on the fly!)This is not an intrinsic limitations of Lean, it's just that nobody has taken the time to formalize much of those fields yet. We hope to dramatically accelerate this process by making it trivial to prove lemmas, which make up much of the work. For now, I still think humans should write the key definitions and statements of "central theorems" in a field, to ensure they are compatible with the rest of the library.
comments.content_cn: 谢谢！这取决于具体领域。有些数学分支（代数、数论）在Lean数学库中已有较好覆盖，我认为这些领域已经具备条件；建议您亲自尝试亚里士多德系统，看看它形式化这些定理的可靠性如何！而在其他领域（拓扑学、概率论、线性代数），许多关键定义尚未纳入Mathlib，因此连定理本身的表述都会遇到困难。（不过在某些情况下，亚里士多德可以即时定义您所讨论的数学结构！）这并非Lean固有的局限性，只是目前还没有人投入足够时间对这些领域进行系统形式化。我们希望通过将引理证明过程简化（这构成了形式化工作的主要部分）来显著加速这一进程。目前我仍认为，应由人类来撰写各领域的核心定义与“关键定理”的陈述，以确保其与现有数学库的兼容性。

He has experimented with this via crowdsourcing problems in a given domain on GitHub before, and I think the implications of how to use AI here are obvious.

comments.author: jacquesm
comments.content: I don't have a degree in either physics or math, but what AI helps me to do is to stay focused on the job before me rather than to have to dig through a mountain of textbooks or many wikipedia pages or scientific papers trying to find an equation that I know I've seen somewhere but did not register the location of and did not copy down. This saves many days, every day. Even then I still check the references once I've found it because errors can and do slip into anything these pieces of software produce, and sometimes quite large ones (those are easy to spot though).So yes, there is value here, and quite a bit but it requires a lot of forethought in how you structure your prompts and you need to be super skeptical about the output as well as able to check that output minutely.If you would just plug in a bunch of data and formulate a query and would then use the answer in an uncritical way you're setting yourself up for a world of hurt and lost time by the time you realize you've been building your castle on quicksand.
comments.content_cn: 我既没有物理学位也没有数学学位，但人工智能帮助我专注于眼前的工作，而不必翻阅堆积如山的教科书、维基百科页面或科学论文，去寻找那个我明明在哪儿见过却记不清位置、也没有抄下来的公式。这每天都能节省大量时间。即便如此，在找到所需信息后我仍然会核对参考文献，因为这类软件生成的内容难免会出现错误，有时甚至是重大错误（不过这些通常很容易发现）。所以，是的，人工智能确实有价值，而且价值不小，但这需要你在构建提问时深思熟虑，同时必须对输出结果保持高度怀疑的态度，并能够细致地核查这些结果。如果你只是输入一堆数据、提出一个问题，然后不加批判地使用给出的答案，那么当你发现自己是在流沙上建造城堡时，早已陷入无尽的麻烦并浪费了大量时间。

comments.author: roadside_picnic
comments.content: >  It is still likely very tedious to confirm what the LLMs say,A large amount of Tao's work is around using AI to assist in creating Lean proofs.I'm generally on the more skeptical side of things regarding LLMs and grand visions, but assisting in the creation of Lean proofs is a huge area of opportunity for LLMs and really could change mathematics in fundamental ways.One naive belief many people have is that proofs should be "intelligible" but it's increasingly clear this is not the case. We have proofs that are gigabytes (I believe even terabytes in some cases) in size, but we know they are correct because they check in Lean.This particular pattern of using state of the art work in two different areas (LLMs and theorem proving) absolutely has the potentially to fundamentally change how mathematics is done. There's a great picture on pp 381 of Type Theory and Formal Proof where you can easily see how LLMs can be placed in two of the most tricky parts of that diagram to solve.Because the work is formally verified we can throw out entire classes of LLM problems (like hallucinations).Personally I think strongly typed language, with powerful type systems are also the long term ideal coding with LLMs (but I'm less optimistic about devs following this path).
comments.content_cn: 要确认大型语言模型所说的内容很可能仍然非常繁琐。陶的大量工作围绕利用人工智能辅助创建Lean证明展开。虽然我对大型语言模型及其宏大愿景持较为怀疑的态度，但辅助创建Lean证明确实是大型语言模型一个巨大的机遇领域，并可能从根本上改变数学研究方式。许多人有一种天真的观念，认为证明应该是"可理解的"，但越来越明显的是事实并非如此。我们已经有了体积达千兆字节（在某些情况下甚至达到太字节级别）的证明，但我们知道它们是正确的，因为它们通过了Lean验证。这种将两个不同领域（大型语言模型和定理证明）的前沿工作相结合的特定模式，绝对有潜力从根本上改变数学的研究方式。《类型理论与形式证明》第381页有一幅精彩的示意图，可以清晰地展示如何将大型语言模型应用于该图中最棘手的两个环节以解决问题。由于这项工作经过形式化验证，我们可以完全排除大型语言模型的一类问题（如幻觉问题）。个人认为，具有强大类型系统的强类型语言也是未来与大型语言模型协同编程的理想方向（但我对开发者是否会遵循这条路径持相对保守态度）。

comments.author: pfdietz
comments.content: Tao has a comment relevant to that question:"I doubt that anything resembling genuine "artificial general intelligence" is within reach of current #AI tools.  However, I think a weaker, but still quite valuable, type of "artificial general cleverness" is becoming a reality in various ways.By "general cleverness", I mean the ability to solve broad classes of complex problems via somewhat ad hoc means.  These means may be stochastic or the result of brute force computation; they may be ungrounded or fallible; and they may be either uninterpretable, or traceable back to similar tricks found in an AI's training data. posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕Oh My Zsh是否因功能臃肿而影响使用体验展开。核心争议在于其便利性与性能损耗的权衡。有人认为Oh My Zsh提供了开箱即用的高效体验，适合快速在不同环境中投入工作；也有用户指出其启动延迟明显，推荐更轻量的替代工具如Zim或Starship，后者在保持便捷的同时减少了性能开销。讨论中提到，部分用户认为此类配置工具本质上都会引入臃肿，若追求极致速度应手动精简配置；另一些用户则对启动时间敏感度表示质疑，认为日常使用中影响有限。共识在于，工具选择需结合个人工作流——重视即用性可选Oh My Zsh，若关注性能可探索更轻量方案。

posts.title: How Markdown took over the world
posts.author: zdw
posts.title_cn: "Markdown如何征服世界"
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕Markdown如何成为主流标记语言展开。核心话题是Markdown成功的原因及其在技术社区中的广泛影响。多数用户认同Markdown因其纯文本特性、无格式锁定、易于版本控制以及原始格式的可读性而受到青睐。有人认为其成功关键在于它标准化了人们已在文本文件中使用的约定，使得书写直观且自然。也有用户指出，Markdown的早期出现和简单性符合“更差即更好”的趋势，使其战胜了更复杂的替代品如Word、DocBook或ReStructured Text。讨论中提到，尽管存在对标准不统一或功能有限的批评（如缺乏颜色、文本对齐等高级格式支持），但社区普遍认为Markdown在笔记、文档和协作场景中提供了理想的平衡。分歧点包括是否应让浏览器原生支持Markdown渲染，以及是否有必要使用更结构化的格式。整体上，用户赞赏Markdown的简洁性和实用性，视其为日常写作的高效工具。

comments.content: Markdown got there first/early depending on your perspective. Things like AsciiDoc got popular much later when AsciiDoctor was released around 2009 (though it technically existed already when Markdown was created) and is aimed at people who care about structured documentation. It's not aimed at casual users.Likewise, things like org mode, which also emerged around the same time, catered to a niche of emacs using people. Which almost by definition is a subset of techies. It wasn't a logical choice for a mainstream blogging tool.Markdown was aimed at people that used blogging tools (initially), and later any other kind of tool that accepted text. It spreading to tools like Slack, Github, etc. is no accident. Github actually has supported plenty of alternatives for documents. But they picked markdown for issue tracking, pull requests, etc. Because they had to just pick something and Markdown was the most popular.By the time AsciiDoc became more popular (2009ish), Github was already being developed. With Markdown support. AsciiDoc was a niche thing, Markdown was already somewhat widely used then. It was an obvious choice. Them picking Markdown was important because the whole OSS community started using Github and got exposed to Markdown that way.The rest is history. Other formats existed (textile, and various other wiki formats). They have features that are important to some people. But getting people to switch who don't really care about those features is hard. It's a bit like VHS over Betamax. Was it better. Not really. But it was there and video rental shops had to pick a format. And that wasn't Betamax when the dust settled.

comments.author: anildash
comments.content: It took me a long time to see the variations as a plus and not a minus; as a veteran of the RSS-vs-Atom wars, I was long an advocate of Technical Correctness(tm) like any good coder. But the years since then have made me a lot more amenable to what I think of as a sort of Practical Postelism, which I guess is like applied worse-is-better, where we realize the reality is that we'll _always_ have forks and multiplicities, so we should see it as a feature instead of a bug. It's like accepting that hardware will fail, and building it into the system.I mean, HTML itself is well specified in the streets, and infinitely different flavors in the sheets. I don't _like_ that, the part of me that writes code _hates_ that. But the part of me that wants systems to succeed just had to sort of respect it.
comments.content_cn:
我花了很长时间才将多样性视为优势而非缺陷；作为RSS与Atom之争的老兵，我曾长期像任何优秀程序员那样倡导技术正确性。但这些年让我更倾向于接受一种"实用波斯特尔主义"，这大概像是应用版的"差中择优"理念——我们意识到现实中分叉与多元性将永远存在，因此应该将其视为特性而非缺陷。就像接受硬件总会故障，并将其纳入系统设计那样。

我的意思是，HTML规范在纸面上定义明确，实际应用中却衍生出无限变体。我并非喜欢这种状况，那个编写代码的自我对此深恶痛绝。但那个渴望系统成功的自我，却不得不对此保持某种程度的尊重。

For instance whatever variant Github or some other major, main stream tool uses.  And then just ignore the critics.It'll certainly make some people angry, but if we try to please everyone we can't get anything done.  And I suspect that it is the fear of not being able to please everyone that is the reason browsers do not have markdown support.  It takes a bit of courage to say "this is the variant we'll implement".HTML was originally said to be an application of SGML.  It wasn't.  It was vaguely inspired by its syntax and that is the only reason HTML saw wide adoption. Had they tried to actually implement anything close to ISO 8879:1986 we would NOT have adopted HTML for the web.  Mostly because it would have been too costly to implement. (Anyone doubting that: have a look at the ISO standard.  You can get it in what is essentially annotated form in Charles Goldfarb's "The HTML Handbook").Of course, Markdown is nowhere near as complex. So this is where perfect is the enemy of good and we end up getting nothing.

HTML最初被称为SGML的一种应用，实则不然。它只是粗略借鉴了SGML的语法，而这正是HTML得以广泛普及的唯一原因。倘若当初他们试图实现任何接近ISO 8879:1986标准的内容，我们根本不会在互联网上采用HTML——主要是因为实现成本过高（若有怀疑者，不妨查阅该ISO标准，查尔斯·戈德法布的《HTML手册》中提供了带注释的版本）。

posts.title: Kagi releases alpha version of Orion for Linux
posts.author: HelloUsername
posts.title_cn: Kagi发布Linux版Orion的alpha版本
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕Kagi公司发布Linux版Orion浏览器alpha版本展开。核心话题是Linux平台浏览器生态的多样性及Orion作为闭源软件在开源系统中的定位。多数用户对Linux出现新的原生浏览器表示欢迎，认为这有助于打破当前Firefox与众多Chromium变体主导的局面，填补了面向高级用户的Linux原生浏览器市场空白。同时，讨论中形成明显分歧：一方积极评价Orion在macOS/iOS上的体验，赞赏其性能、广告拦截及扩展支持；另一方则对其闭源性质提出质疑，认为在开源操作系统上使用闭源浏览器显得矛盾，且有用户报告其在macOS上引发系统不稳定问题。此外，有用户指出Linux版WebKit生态薄弱，主要局限于嵌入式设备或特定浏览器，并提及Orion alpha目前仅向Orion高级用户开放。普遍共识是，尽管Orion功能受期待，但其开源与否将成为影响Linux用户采纳的关键因素之一。

comments.author: Fiveplus
comments.content: This is a healthy thing to happen to the Linux browser ecosystem imho.We talk a lot about browser diversity, but on Linux and Windows, it is a lie. You have firefox (gecko) and fifty flavors of chromium. Webkit on Linux has essentially been relegated to embedded devices or the GNOME epiphany browser, which I'll admit while is a noble effort, lags a bit in the stability and power-user features department. Big reason for that is that it lacks the commercial backing to keep up with the modern web standards rat race.Kagi bringing orion to Linux changes the calculus. It introduces a third commercially incentivized, consumer-grade engine to the platform. Even if you never use orion, you want this to succeed because it forces WebKitGTK upstream to get better, which benefits the entire open source ecosystem.The sticking point like always will be media playback (read: DRM/widevine). That is the graveyard where Linux browsers go to die. If Kagi can legally and technically solve the widevine integration on a non-standard Linux webkit build, they win. If not, it will be a secondary browser.
comments.content_cn:
在我看来，这对Linux浏览器生态是件好事。我们常谈论浏览器多样性，但在Linux和Windows上，这其实是个伪命题。目前只有火狐（Gecko）和各类Chromium变体。Linux上的WebKit基本已被边缘化，仅用于嵌入式设备或GNOME的Epiphany浏览器——虽然这款浏览器的开发初衷值得尊敬，但在稳定性和高级用户功能方面确实有所欠缺，主要原因是缺乏商业支持来跟上现代网页标准的激烈竞争。

Kagi将Orion引入Linux改变了这一格局。它为这个平台带来了第三个具有商业驱动力的消费级浏览器引擎。即使你从不使用Orion，也应该希望它成功，因为这能促使WebKitGTK上游项目改进，从而惠及整个开源生态系统。

关键难点始终在于媒体播放（尤其是DRM/Widevine支持）。这是Linux浏览器的"坟场"。如果Kagi能在法律和技术层面解决非标准Linux WebKit构建中的Widevine集成问题，他们就能赢得市场。否则，这只能成为一款次要的备用浏览器。

comments.content: I think this is great. True native Linux-first power user browsers are nearly an entirely unserved niche. comments.author: WhyNotHugo
comments.content: Being closed-source isn't just an ideological issue, it bring about a lot of practical issues. E..g.: distributions aren't going to package it, so users need to download the tarball and install it manually. They'll also need to manually update it (unless they're including some dedicated service?).Then, integration with the OS will be weird. If you're distributing binaries, you can't dynamically link system dependencies (they are either bundled or statically linked). Any distribution-specific patches and fixes will be missing. AFAIK the default path for the CA bundle varies per distribution; I'm not even sure how you'd handle that kind of thing. I'm sure there's hundreds of subtle little details like that one.The audience ends up being Linux users, who are fine with proprietary software, have time and patience for manually configuring and maintaining a browser installation, and are also fine with an absence of proper OS integration.I think Steam is the only popular proprietary software on Linux, and they basically ship an entire userspace runtime, and almost don't integrate with the OS at all.
comments.content_cn:
闭源不仅是意识形态问题，更会引发诸多实际难题。例如：发行版不会将其打包收录，用户需自行下载压缩包并手动安装，同时还得手动更新（除非内置专属更新服务？）。此外，与操作系统的整合也会变得怪异——若分发二进制文件，则无法动态链接系统依赖项（只能捆绑或静态链接），且会缺失各发行版特有的补丁与修复。据我所知，CA证书包的默认路径因发行版而异，甚至不确定这类问题该如何处理。类似细微的技术细节恐怕数以百计。

最终面向的受众将是那些不排斥专有软件、愿意花时间耐心手动配置维护浏览器安装，且能接受与操作系统缺乏深度整合的Linux用户。目前Linux上流行的专有软件似乎只有Steam，而它实质上打包了整个用户空间运行时环境，几乎未与操作系统进行整合。

comments.author: bisby
comments.content: > Then release it under a copyleft license. Or if you absolutely must, release your proprietary bit under a non-open source licenseAn old mentor once said to me that a contract is just the start of a conversation. If you sign a contract, the other party violates it, and your business goes under... you may be able to get some compensation through courts, but also your business is gone. And getting that compensation and proving that the contract was violated and how much you are entitled to costs time and money.Releasing something at all, even under a restrictive license, means nothing if you have no intention (or capability) of enforcing that license. Look at how often companies take GPL code, modify it, and then never publish their modifications... and then people have to sue to get things resolved.So "We aren't ready to commit the legal resources to fighting and defending the licenses" makes a LOT of sense. IP protection is not just a matter of signing a piece of paper saying people can't do a thing, you have to actually prevent them from doing the thing.
comments.content_cn:
那就以著佐权许可证发布。如果实在有必要，可以将专有部分以非开源许可证发布。一位前辈曾告诉我，合同只是对话的开始。如果你签了合同，对方违约导致你生意垮掉……或许能通过诉讼获得赔偿，但生意已经没了。而争取赔偿、证明违约事实、确定应得金额都需要耗费时间和金钱。

如果根本没有意愿（或能力）去执行许可证条款，那么发布作品本身——即便是限制性许可证——也毫无意义。看看有多少公司使用GPL代码进行修改后却从不公开修改内容……最终只能靠诉讼解决问题。

所以“我们尚未准备好投入法律资源来维护和捍卫许可证”这句话非常合理。知识产权保护不仅仅是签一纸禁令，更需要实际阻止侵权行为的发生。

comments.author: Fiveplus
comments.content: Hmm good point. The issue is also the distinction between widevine L1, i.e hardware-backed DRM and L3 (the software backed one).Correct me if I'm wrong but to stream 4K, studios require a hardware root of trust and a verified media path. They need a guarantee that the video frames are decrypted inside a trusted execution environment  and sent directly to the display without the OS kernel or user space being able to read the raw buffer.AFAIK Windows and macOS provide this pipeline at the OS level. OTOH, ChromeOS gets 1080p/4K not because it has massive market share but cause the hardware and boot chain are locked down by the almighty Google.On desktop Linux, where you have root access and can modify the kernel or compositor to inspect memory, there is technically no way to guarantee that secure path to the studios' satisfaction. Am I right in this assumption?Unless the DRM providers change their threat model, which sounds unlikely to me. Or distros start shipping signed and locked-down kernel modules that prevent the user from being root, which is again unacceptable to most (me included), we will likely be capped at 720p for some time now.
comments.content_cn:
嗯，说得有道理。这里的关键区别在于Widevine L1（即硬件级DRM）和L3（软件级DRM）之间的差异。如果我说错了请指正：要播放4K流媒体，制片方要求硬件级可信根和经过验证的媒体传输路径。他们需要确保视频帧在可信执行环境中解密，并直接传输到显示设备，操作系统内核或用户空间都无法读取原始缓冲区。

据我所知，Windows和macOS在操作系统层面提供了这种传输管道。而ChromeOS能支持1080p/4K并非因为其市场份额巨大，而是因为其硬件和启动链被强大的谷歌严格锁定。在桌面Linux系统中，用户拥有root权限且可以修改内核或显示服务器来检查内存，从技术层面无法向制片方提供令人满意的安全路径保障。我的这个推测对吗？

除非DRM供应商改变其威胁模型（这在我看来可能性不大），或者发行版开始提供经过签名且锁定的内核模块来禁止用户获取root权限（这对大多数人包括我在内都是不可接受的），否则我们可能在未来一段时间内仍将受限于720p画质。

comments.author: freediver
comments.content: Kagi founder here. Orion isn't open source yet primarily because we're a 5-person team that spent 6+ years building this and created significant IP doing so, and we're not in a position to defend our work against a well-funded company using it as a base (we care very much about the business model of the browser surviving). Restrictive licenses help in theory but enforcing them against a company with a larger legal budget doesn't.We also see limited upside from community contributions - the number of people who can meaningfully work on a WebKit browser is small (from our experience hiring), and most of them already work at Apple or Kagi. Meanwhile, managing an open source codebase of this size would add real strain to our small team.The plan is however to open source when Orion is self-sufficient (business model of Orion is you are the customer and can pay for it - like we used to pay for browsers 20 years ago before advertisers started paying for our browsing), meaning it can sustain its own development independent of Kagi Search. I want to take the opportunity to thank all people who supported the Orion browser vision  [1]. We're not there yet but recent 1.0 launch and expanding to Linux are steps in that direction. And on Jan 1st this year we began development of Orion for Windows (HN exclusive yay!).I understand this is unsatisfying to people who want source access now. It's a tradeoff we've made deliberately, not something we're hiding behind.[1] https://kagi.com/stats?sub_stats=orion
comments.content_cn:
我是Kagi的创始人。Orion目前尚未开源，主要是因为我们是五人团队，花费六年多时间构建了这款浏览器并创造了重要的知识产权。我们无法抵御资金雄厚的公司将其作为基础来使用（我们非常重视浏览器商业模式的可持续性）。限制性许可证理论上有所帮助，但面对法律预算更充足的公司，执行起来并不现实。此外，我们认为社区贡献的积极影响有限——能够实质性参与WebKit浏览器开发的人员很少（从我们的招聘经验来看），其中大多数人已在苹果或Kagi工作。同时，管理如此规模的开源代码库将给我们的小团队带来实际压力。

然而，我们的计划是在Orion实现自给自足时将其开源（Orion的商业模式是用户即客户，可以为其付费——就像20年前广告商开始为我们的浏览付费之前，我们曾为浏览器付费那样），这意味着它可以独立于Kagi搜索维持自身发展。我想借此机会感谢所有支持Orion浏览器愿景的人们[1]。我们尚未达成目标，但最近的1.0版本发布和向Linux系统的扩展正是朝着这个方向迈出的步伐。今年1月1日，我们已启动Orion for Windows的开发工作（HN独家消息！）。

我理解这对希望立即获取源代码的人们来说可能不尽如人意。这是我们深思熟虑后做出的权衡，而非刻意回避。

[1] https://kagi.com/stats?su...

posts.title: How will the miracle happen today?
posts.author: zdw
posts.title_cn: 今天的奇迹将如何发生？
posts.abstract:
这篇讨论围绕一篇关于搭便车经历的文章展开，核心话题是现代社会中间接体验与善意互动的价值。文章作者描述了通过搭便车获得陌生人帮助的体验，并将分享冒险故事作为对司机的“回报”，这引发了社区对人际互助、感恩与回报的深入探讨。

有人认为这种以故事换乘车的模式在现代注意力经济中已逐渐消失，但体现了人性中超越功利的美好。也有用户指出作者未明确回报那些帮助他的人，这显得不够真诚；但其他用户反驳说，善意本身不应要求即时回报，而可能通过传递帮助来延续。讨论中提到，类似体验（如朝圣实验或有限预算旅行）能培养对他人的信任与感恩，但部分用户质疑，有能力自立却刻意依赖他人帮助可能不够道德。

普遍共识是，这种经历能重塑人们对陌生人的信任，让人更珍惜生活中的偶然善意。分歧主要在于对“回报”的理解：一方强调直接或间接回馈的必要性，另一方则认为接受善意并保持感恩本身就是一种价值。

comments.author: Fiveplus
comments.content: I couldn't help but focus on the vicarious adventure aspect Kelly mentions which was the "payment" he offered drivers in exchange for the ride. This is a mechanism that has largely been deprecated by the modern attention economy.In the era of hitchhiking, the bandwidth for novelty was low. A driver on a long commute had no podcasts, no Spotify or audiobooks. A stranger with a story was high value. The transaction was something like = I provide logistics and you provide content; like the story of your cross-country bike trip.Today, we have near infinite content in our pockets. The marginal utility of a stranger's story has plummeted because the competition is Joe Rogan or an endless algorithmic feed. We have largely replaced the P2P protocol of kindness with a sort of centralized platform of service. We stripped out the human latency and the requirement for social reciprocity and replaced it with currency and star ratings. It makes me surreal to think about this.
comments.content_cn: 我不禁注意到凯利提到的替代性冒险体验，这是他提供给司机作为搭车回报的"报酬"。这种机制在很大程度上已被现代注意力经济所淘汰。在搭便车的年代，人们接触新鲜事物的渠道有限。长途驾驶的司机没有播客、没有Spotify或有声书。一个带着故事的陌生人就是高价值资源。这种交易类似于：我提供交通工具，你提供内容；比如你横穿全国的自行车旅行故事。如今我们口袋里有近乎无限的内容。陌生人故事的边际效用急剧下降，因为竞争对手变成了乔·罗根的播客或是无穷无尽的算法推送。我们基本上用中心化的服务平台取代了人与人之间的善意连接。我们剥离了人际交往的延迟性和社会互惠的需求，代之以货币和星级评分。想到这些让我感到超现实。

comments.author: thunderbong
comments.content: That was wonderful writing. As we go through the daily grind of life, we forget how privileged we are to be alive.I found the following two paragraphs truly incredible.> All of us begin in the same place. Whether sinner or saint, we are not owed our life. Our existence is an unnecessary extravagance, a wild gesture, an unearned gift. Not just at birth. The eternal surprise is being funneled to us daily, hourly, minute by minute, every second. As you read these words, you are rinsed with the gift of time. Yet, we are terrible recipients. We are no good at being helpless, humble, or indebted. Being needy is not celebrated on day-time TV shows, or in self-help books. We make lousy kindees.> I’ve slowly changed my mind about spiritual faith. I once thought it was chiefly about believing in an unseen reality; that it had a lot in common with hope. But after many years of examining the lives of the people whose spiritual character I most respect, I’ve come to see that their faith rests on gratitude, rather than hope. The beings I admire exude a sense of knowing they are indebted, of resting upon a state thankfulness. They recognize they are at the receiving end of an ongoing lucky ticket called being alive. When the truly faithful worry, it’s not about doubt (which they have); it’s about how they might not maximize the tremendous gift given them. How they might be ungrateful by squandering their ride. The faithful I admire are not certain about much except this: that this state of being embodied, inflated with life, brimming with possibilities, is so over-the-top unlikely, so extravagant, so unconditional, so far out beyond physical entropy, that is it indistinguishable from love. And most amazing of all, like my hitchhiking rides, this love gift is an extravagant gesture you can count on. This is the meta-miracle: that the miracle of gifts is so dependable. No matter how bad the weather, soiled the past, broken the heart, hellish the war – all that is behind the universe is conspiring to help you – if you will let it.
comments.content_cn:
这段文字写得真好。在日复一日的庸常生活中，我们常常忘记活着本身已是莫大的恩赐。以下两段尤其令我震撼：

> 我们所有人始于同样的起点。无论罪人或圣徒，生命都不是我们应得的。存在本身即是非必要的奢侈，是狂放的姿态，是未经努力的馈赠。这馈赠不仅始于诞生——永恒的惊喜正每时每刻、每分每秒向我们涌来。当你阅读这些文字时，时间的赠礼正冲刷着你。然而我们却是糟糕的受赠者：我们不擅于展现脆弱、谦卑与亏欠。白天的电视节目不会歌颂匮乏，自助书籍也回避无助。我们总是不合格的受恩者。

> 关于精神信仰，我的观念已悄然转变。我曾以为它主要是相信不可见的实相，与希望颇有共通。但多年观察那些令我敬重之人的精神品格后，我逐渐明白他们的信仰根基在于感恩而非希望。我所钦佩之人周身散发着知恩的气息，始终安驻于感激的状态。他们清醒认识到自己正持续接收名为"活着"的幸运彩票。当真正有信仰者忧虑时，他们忧心的不是怀疑（他们也有怀疑），而是自己是否辜负了这份厚礼，是否因虚度光阴而成了忘恩者。我敬仰的信徒对大多事并不确定，唯坚信这一点：这种感恩的状态……

comments.author: NaOH
comments.content: It's a choice. I go to the supermarket twice a week, not shopping for much. I switched the store I use three, four months ago, but I can already talk about some of the employees at the store I visit. Louis is back where he grew up right now because his 97-year-old grandfather died. Among other things, he feels lucky grandpa's passing came after the new year because of his time-off allotment. Nikki had great holidays, mostly because her adult daughter was here for a week. Nadine ("Shh.") has decided she's going to retire at the end of the month but hasn't yet told anyone at the store.Raffy, the UPS delivery guy I see maybe five times a year? He's doing well, finally feeling things slowing down some after the holidays. His fiancé will finish her graduate degree this spring, then they're going to decide if they want to stay here or move back to the state where they were born. They like it here, but think job opportunities will be better back home.I'm sure many here are familiar with "This is Water," the commencement speech given by David Foster Wallace. Many often cite his line, "Everybody worships," his observation that we all hold aspects of life in reverence, whether religious things or otherwise. It's a valid, pithy point, but I always thought the key part to his speech comes later and has been widely overlooked:And the so-called real world will not discourage you from operating on your default settings, because the so-called real world of men and money and power hums merrily along in a pool of fear and anger and frustration and craving and worship of self. Our own present culture has harnessed these forces in ways that have yielded extraordinary wealth and comfort and personal freedom. The freedom all to be lords of our tiny skull-sized kingdoms, alone at the centre of all creation. This kind of freedom has much to recommend it. But of course there are all different kinds of freedom, and the kind that is most precious you will not hear much talk about much in the great outside world of wanting and achieving.... The really important kind of freedom involves attention and awareness and discipline, and being able truly to care about other people and to sacrifice for them over and over in myriad petty, unsexy ways every day.He delivered that speech in 2005. Before the modern smartphone. All those people I mentioned earlier were strangers. That's no longer the case because all of us chose to interrupt what we were doing and open up a little to someone unfamiliar. It's a choice. Or, as Bob Dylan once sang,Freedom, just around the corner from youBut with truth so far off, what good will it do

comments.author: gcanyon
comments.content: I see others expressing this point, but I'll add my two cents: this essay really bothered me.1. The writer describes hitchhiking to work every day, presumably for months or years. He doesn't describe in any way how he paid back that kindness, either to the people he rode with directly, or just by paying it forward.2. The writer describes traveling in Asia for 8 years, and many of the instances of kindness he describe imply very strongly that he intentionally put himself at risk, where others were faced with the choice to help him or let him suffer consequences. It's one thing to get caught in a rip current and need assistance; it's another entirely to swim out past where you are safe, and then wait for someone to rescue you -- and to do that repeatedly for eight years. Further, it is obvious from the language used that he was traveling rough by choice, with the privilege and economic security of his background, and yet repeatedly accepting -- I would argue demanding -- the help of people from a poorer background than himself. He was cosplaying poverty and repeatedly being assisted by people living it for real.3. The backyard idea seems similarly pushy. He says he was never turned away, not once. So he believes that no one, given an actual free choice, would rather not have a stranger camp in their backyard. He ignores the possibility that people would feel uncomfortable about rejecting someone presenting as having no place to stay, and rather believes that everyone he asked woke up that day thinking about how happy they'd be to do a favor for a stranger. And he couches the whole process as him doing them a favor.4. He lists multiple instances where people less well-off than him went to great lengths to help him, without ever thinking about why they might feel obligated, and through it all admitting that not only doesn't he engage in such kindness himself, he can't imagine that he would.5. And through it all he characterizes what he very nearly describes as him pushing himself on people as "willingness to be helped" -- as some sort of saintliness.And of course each of these people only saw him once, for a short while. Reading this essay we see how it is a pattern: how he is essentially a traveling con man, moving from mark to mark, letting each of them believe that he just happens to need help this one time, so they put good out into the universe. But in reality he is taking, taking, taking, abusing the world's willingness to help -- if everyone did what he did, the world would swiftly become a meaner, poorer place.
comments.content_cn: 看到其他人也表达了类似观点，但我想补充几句：这篇文章确实让我感到不适。1. 作者描述自己每天搭便车上班，这种情况可能持续了数月甚至数年。但他完全没有提及自己如何回报这份善意——无论是直接回报搭载他的人，还是通过传递善意的方式。2. 作者描述了在亚洲旅行八年的经历，其中许多关于善意的描述强烈暗示他是故意将自己置于危险境地，迫使他人面临"帮助他"或"任其承受后果"的两难选择。被离岸流卷走需要帮助是一回事，但故意游出安全区域等待救援——并且连续八年反复这样做——则完全是另一回事。此外，从文字表述明显可以看出，他是在拥有特权和家庭经济保障的前提下，主动选择艰苦的旅行方式，却反复接受（我认为甚至是索取）那些经济背景不如他的人的帮助。他是在扮演贫困者，却反复接受真正贫困者的援助。3. 关于后院借宿的想法同样显得强人所难。他说自己从未被拒绝过一次。这意味着他相信，如果人们真正拥有自由选择权，没有人会不愿意让陌生人在自家后院扎营。他忽略了人们可能因拒绝看似无处可住的人而感到不安，反而认为所有被询问的人都真心欢迎他的到来……

comments.author: hliyan
comments.content: I'm from Sri Lanka. One incident I always remember is how the front wheels of my car went into a ditch and got completely stuck while trying to pull out of a shopfront parking lot. I was fairly new to driving and was at a complete loss as to what to do next. Within seconds, a crowd of men gathered, some from the bus stop nearby, others from the restaurant in front of the parking spot. "Get back in and reverse when we tell you", said one person. Then a group of about 5 men literally lifted the front of my car and placed the wheels back on terra firma. I reversed out of the ditch, parked the car and got out to thank them, but they had dispersed as rapidly as they had assembled. I always thought my people a bit brusque in social interactions -- we don't greet shopkeepers or supermarket cashiers; we don't smile randomly at each other; we don't often say thank you. But I suppose when it matters, people are more willing to get involved and roll up their sleeves to help.
comments.content_cn: 我来自斯里兰卡。有一件事我始终记得：有一次我从一家商店门前的停车场倒车时，前轮陷进了沟里，完全卡住了。那时我开车还不太熟练，完全不知道接下来该怎么办。几秒钟内，一群人就围了过来，有些来自附近的公交车站，有些来自停车场前面的餐馆。"回到车里，听我们指挥倒车，"一个人说道。然后大约有五个男人直接抬起了我的车前部，把车轮放回了坚实的地面。我倒车驶出沟渠，停好车，下车想感谢他们，但他们已经像聚集时一样迅速地散去了。我总以为我们国家的人在社交上有点生硬——我们不跟店主或超市收银员打招呼；我们不随便对彼此微笑；我们不常说谢谢。但我想，在关键时刻，人们更愿意伸出援手，卷起袖子帮忙。

comments.author: ericmcer
comments.content: Really nice article, but it sort of flies in the face of all our biological imperatives.Being a good "kindee" means forgoing security, control and some safety.Constant Gratitude for just the miracle of life means forgoing the driving dissatisfaction that will push you ahead.This is the classic battle between our ancient biological impulses and the reality of modern society. Many religions try to square these: Buddhisms central focus is to "stop grasping" your desires, Christianity wants you to "surrender" and put your faith in god. And then you also have articles like this that have a vague spiritual bent but mostly preach mindfulness and gratitude as a balm to our general dissatisfaction. Do we still need constant anxiety around our safety, do we still need to feel dissatisfied with each achievement and constantly want more? Or were those just useful imperatives for an animal 50,000 years ago but useless to us today?In my personal life I have momentary success being mindful/grateful, but the bare reality is we are the product of millions of years of life being a short cruel struggle, fraught with danger. Does modern society give us the right to throw all that away and pretend we get to float around observing the beauty of the world? Or is our life supposed to be a battle?
comments.content_cn: 这篇文章确实不错，但它似乎与我们所有的生物本能背道而驰。做一个“善良的人”意味着放弃安全感、控制欲和某些保障。对生命奇迹的持续感恩，意味着放弃那种推动你前行的不满足感。这是我们古老的生物冲动与现代社会现实之间的经典冲突。许多宗教试图调和这一点：佛教的核心是“停止执着”于欲望，基督教则希望你“臣服”并将信仰寄托于上帝。此外，还有像这样带有模糊灵性倾向的文章，主要宣扬正念和感恩，作为对我们普遍不满的慰藉。我们是否仍需要时刻为安全感到焦虑？是否仍需对每个成就感到不满足并不断渴望更多？抑或这些只是五万年前动物有用的本能，对今天的我们已毫无用处？在我的个人生活中，我曾短暂成功地保持正念和感恩，但赤裸的现实是，我们是数百万年来生命短暂残酷、充满危险挣扎的产物。现代社会是否赋予我们权利抛弃这一切，假装我们可以漂浮着观察世界之美？抑或我们的生活本应是一场战斗？

comments.author: dannyobrien
comments.content: For those in the thread worrying that KK may have been mooching off people, and would not reciprocate: many years ago, I opened up our back yard for people who wanted to come to O'Reilly's Emerging Tech conference, but could not afford the sky-high hotel prices in Silicon Valley (this was before AirBnB or couchsurfing).I was surprised when Kevin Kelly appeared. He'd been my (very distant) boss at Wired, was a published author of one of my favorite books, a very well-known figure and a smiling but disarmingly calm manner. He sat and amicably talked for hours with a yard full of people, many of whom have become some of my closet friends. Then, as the evening closed, he asked if he could sleep in my yard too. Others had brought tents, and burning men structures, and it had begun to rain. Kevin pulled out a camping sleeping bag from nowhere, struck out, and I saw him later, in the soaking, muddy garden, quietly curled up under someone's geodesic dome structure.Decades later, after Covid, I mailed him out of the blue, and asked him for advice. He immediately remembered me, invited me to his home, and talked to me, again, for an hour or so, about AI, optimism, and how to change the world.To be frank, I never emailed him thank you, and I still feel guilty about that, but now I feel like it was never needed or asked for. comments.content_cn:

comments.author: roughly
comments.content: What's interesting about this post is that it would be completely unsurprising to most people in most parts of the world, as well as most people here 100 years ago. The discomfort so many people in this thread feel with receiving kindness and the devaluing of the gift of companionship, gratitude, and a good story is a testament to how far off human norms our society is these days.I struggle with this a lot myself - I've had to overcome deep feelings of inadequacy and insecurity because I never valued what I offered people just by being present and because I always felt like I had to "square the books" - that every interaction or relationship was an exchange that needed to square its ledgers. The best thing for my mental health has been to become comfortable just being with people and accepting their continued presence and return to my company as something that doesn't require an exchange - that human companionship and kindness are things we enjoy as people, not services to be itemized and accounted for.One interesting note on this is that it's not just an "old world" phenomenon - if you look at many old farmhouses across the midwest, they've got a separate covered section that's accessible from outside the house - the assumption was that travelers passing by could and would spend the night there, and often the owners would have supplies of oatcakes or other durable foodstuffs for travelers, because everyone who traveled needed somewhere to stay or something to eat at some point, and reciprocity could be assumed when the homeowner traveled themselves in the future.
comments.content_cn:
这篇帖子有趣之处在于，它对世界上大多数地区的人们以及一百年前的本地居民而言都完全不足为奇。当前讨论中许多人面对善意时表现出的不适感，以及对陪伴、感恩与好故事这些礼物的轻视，恰恰印证了我们社会已偏离人类常态多远。我自己也常为此挣扎——我曾不得不克服根深蒂固的自我否定与不安，因为我从未珍视过"在场"本身带给他人的价值，总觉得自己必须"结清账目"，认为每次互动或关系都是需要平衡收支的交易。对我心理健康最有益的改变，是学会坦然与人相处，接受他们持续出现在我生命中并愿意回到我身边这件事本身——人类的陪伴与善意是我们作为人自然享受的美好，而非需要逐条列计的服务项目。

值得玩味的是，这种现象并非仅存于"旧时代"。如果你观察中西部许多老农舍，会发现它们都设有从房屋外部独立出入的带顶空间——当时人们默认路过的旅人可以在此过夜，屋主也常会储备燕麦饼等耐储存食物供旅人取用，因为每个行者都可能在某个时刻需要歇脚处或充饥物……

comments.content: My aunt lived to 94 and was in a retiremement community outside Boston. She never married (had some long term relationships) but was always interested in people. She would invariably give me a potted life history of these people, who she might only have known a few months.No need for crosswords or other activities to keep her brain active - talking to people and remembering their stories is what kept her going!Before moving to the community, she had a house in Cambridge (Boston) and let out the upper floor to students, post grads etc - and kept up with many of them long after they had left. Connection was definitly a skill of hers.
comments.content_cn: 我的姨妈活到了94岁，住在波士顿郊外的一个退休社区。她从未结婚（有过几段长期恋情），但始终对他人充满兴趣。过去我常从英国定期探望她，她总会把我介绍给社区里的各种人——护士、护工、园丁等等。她总会向我讲述这些人的生平故事，哪怕她可能只认识他们几个月。她根本不需要填字游戏或其他活动来保持大脑活跃——与人交谈并记住他们的故事就是她保持活力的秘诀！在搬进退休社区前，她在剑桥（波士顿）有栋房子，把上层租给本科生、研究生等，并在他们离开后仍与许多人保持联系。维系人际关系无疑是她的特殊才能。

comments.author: rconti
comments.content: I used to ride as well, and I had the same reaction. The sheer number of people who moved over for me (in California) blew me away every time I rode. They'd never hear me coming; they SAW me and made the choice to move over. I constantly felt that I was underestimating how many people were truly paying attention while they were driving, despite how much "we" like to complain that everyone's in their own world and nobody pays attention anymore.I try very hard to do the same. I did before I rode, and I still do now. I'm a skilled and trained and attentive driver who is rarely distracted. And yet, I am ashamed at how often I am surprised when a motorcycle splits past me. Maybe I shouldn't think so highly of my attentiveness compared to the "average" person.It's also a lesson on law and culture. Here in CA where it's legal by statute (if not always practiced in a legal manner), and where drivers are aware it happens, and MOSTLY aware that it's legal, the drivers are very kind. In places where it is ILLEGAL, drivers can be a lot more antagonistic and unsafe about the practice. But at the end of the day, the laws are arbitrary; on the asphalt, it's just another human trying to get from one place to another, doing nothing to inhibit the journey of the other.
comments.content_cn:
我也曾骑摩托车，有过同样的感受。每次骑行时，加州那么多人为我让路都让我惊叹不已。他们并非听到我驶近，而是看到我后主动选择让行。尽管我们总抱怨现在开车的人都沉浸在自己的世界里、不再关注路况，但我不断意识到自己低估了真正专心驾驶的人数。我努力效仿这种行为——骑车前如此，现在依然如此。我是个技术娴熟、训练有素、专注力强的司机，很少分心。但每当摩托车从我旁边穿行而过时，我仍会因频繁感到惊讶而惭愧。或许我不该把自己的专注力想得比“普通”人高出太多。

这也关乎法律与文化的启示。在加州，车道分割有法可依（即便实际操作未必完全合法），司机们普遍知晓这种现象，也大多明白其合法性，因此驾驶者往往非常友善。而在明令禁止的地区，司机们对此可能更具对抗性，操作也更不安全。但归根结底，法律只是人为规定；在柏油路上，这不过是另一个想从甲地到乙地的人，并未妨碍他人的旅程。

comments.author: gcanyon
comments.content: > they got to do something kind for someoneAnd he never needs/wants this benefit of giving for himself? Because he never describes paying it forward, in fact quite the opposite.And again, he repeated describes never failing to get the help he seeks. Either he is taking advantage of people, or he is the luckiest person on the planet.Interestingly, I have some similar incidents in my past: I took the Amtrak to Crescent City, then bicycled south along the coast of California. On the train up I met someone from Eureka, who invited me to stay at their place when I got there the second night, and I did. It's been so long I had forgotten the situation until just now, and I don't remember the conversation leading up to that. I don't think I was pushing for a place to stay; I stayed at a hostel in Crescent City the night before, and another somewhere near Leggett the night after, and I never slept indoors for free on the rest of the trip.Later, when I was looking for a public trash can in a small town, I asked someone if there were any. They said no, and just to toss whatever I wanted to get rid of into the back of their pickup, and they'd drop it at the dump the next time they went.My knees got extremely painful by the time I reached San Francisco. At a hostel near Muir Beach(?) I ran into a guy from San Diego (where I lived) who took half my gear (lightening the load) and gave me a Mueller knee brace he happened to have with him to wear for the rest of the trip. That act definitely saved my trip.Still later on the trip, camping at a park I ran into a guy who was also bicycling, homeless by choice -- he said he was divorced and living without an address to deny his ex her alimony. He said to never go into a grocery store without checking the dumpster out back first, and handed me an over-date yogurt :-)But I can very confidently state that I wasn't asking for any favors. Maybe that makes me not "open" to the world looking to help me?At first I questioned whether I was being judgmental. But writing it out as I did convinced me I was not. If people are helping him at every turn, even people far less well off than he is, that is clearly him pressing the world's "kindness" button -- hard."We ended up sleeping like sardines under a single home-woven blanket while snow fell." -- how would he have kept warm if they didn't share the blanket with him? Did they have any option but to share their blanket or feel like they were leaving an innocent to freeze?Actually, I have an experience for that as well. When I was prepping for the California ride I rode through the Cuyamaca mountains east of San Diego. I brought no clothing but a bike jersey and shorts. It dropped well below freezing that night. I spent the entire night huddled in a bad K-Mart sleeping bag, dozing, shivering, and cursing how long it was until dawn. I suppose I could have knocked on any van or RV at the site, but I didn't even think to, even though I was legitimately freezing. Again, maybe I'm not "open" enough, but I made a stupid decision to not bring better gear, or at least a jacket -- I earned that consequence, and I paid for it in full. :-)And I tell that story all the time. At this point I don't think it's a better or worse story/memory than the one I would have if I had asked someone for help and received it.I've received help many times in my life. But again, it rubs me the wrong way if someone purposefully and repeatedly throws themself into deep water, expecting others to rescue them. And to me at least, it seems clear that's what he's done.

抵达旧金山时我的膝盖疼痛难忍。在缪尔海滩（？）附近的青年旅社，我遇到一位来自圣地亚哥（我的居住地）的人，他帮我分担了一半行李（减轻负重），还给了我一副他恰巧随身携带的穆勒护膝，让我在后续旅途中使用。这个举动无疑……

posts.title_cn: 如何在200行代码内编写Claude Code
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕“如何用200行代码实现Claude Code”展开，核心话题是探讨构建代码生成智能代理的简化模型与实际复杂性的差距。多数用户认为，文章展示的基础循环（LLM+系统提示+工具调用）虽能演示代理的基本形态，但过于简化。有人指出，真实场景中需要处理错误控制、状态维护、编辑可靠性等大量细节，这些“脚手架”工作才是难点。也有用户强调，专用工具（如Bash命令）虽能简化功能，但优化和稳定性才是关键。讨论中提到，社区普遍认同简单循环可作为入门参考，但与企业级应用存在巨大差距——后者需应对高负载、复杂迭代和实时调整等挑战。分歧在于对“200行代码”价值的评价：部分人认为它有助于理解核心机制，另一些人则指出这种模型已过时，无法反映当前Claude Code的实际运作逻辑。

comments.author: lmeyerov
comments.content: Something I would add is planning. A big "aha" for effective use of these tools is realizing they run on dynamic TODO lists. Ex: Plan mode is basically bootstrapping how that TODO list gets seeded and how todos ground themselves when they get reached, and user interactions are how you realign the todo lists. The todolist is subtle but was a big shift in coding tools, and many seem to be surprised when we discuss it -- most seem to focus on whether to use plan mode or not, but todo lists will still be active. I ran a fun experiment last month on how well claude code solves CTFs, and disabling the TodoList tool and planning is 1-2 grade jumps: https://media.ccc.de/v/39c3-breaking-bots-cheating-at-blue-t... .Fwiw, I found it funny how the article stuffs "smarter context management" into a breeze-y TODO bullet point at the end for going production-grade. I've been noticing a lot of NIH/DIY types believing they can do a good job of this and then, when forced to have results/evals that don't suck in production, losing the rest of the year on that step. (And even worse when they decide to fine-tune too.)
comments.content_cn: 我想补充的一点是规划。有效使用这些工具的一个关键"顿悟"在于认识到它们基于动态待办事项列表运行。例如：规划模式本质上是在引导待办列表如何被初始化，以及当任务到达时如何落地执行，而用户交互则是调整待办列表的方式。待办列表虽然微妙，却是编码工具的重大转变，我们在讨论时很多人似乎都感到惊讶——大多数人似乎只关注是否使用规划模式，但待办列表其实始终在后台运作。上个月我做了个有趣的实验，测试Claude代码解决CTF挑战的能力，结果发现禁用待办列表工具和规划功能会导致性能下降1-2个等级：https://media.ccc.de/v/39c3-breaking-bots-cheating-at-blue-t... 。顺便说句，我觉得那篇文章把"更智能的上下文管理"轻描淡写地塞进最后关于生产级应用的待办事项要点里挺有意思。我注意到很多喜欢自研的人总以为自己能做好这件事，结果当被迫要求生产环境中的结果/评估不能太差时，他们反而会在这个环节耗费大半年时间。（如果他们决定还要进行微调，情况就更糟了。）

comments.author: miki123211
comments.content: All you actually need is 50 lines and one tool.If your agent can execute Bash commands, it can do anything, including reading files (with cat), writing them (with sed / patch / awk /perl), grepping, finding, and everything else you may possibly need. The specialized tools are just an optimization to make things easier for the agent. They do increase performance (in the "how much can this do", not the "how fast is this" sense), but they're not strictly required.IMHO, this is one of the more significant LLM-related discoveries of 2025. You don't need a context-polluting Github MCP that takes 10+% of your precious context window, all you need is the gh cli, which the agent already knows how to use.
comments.content_cn: 实际上你只需要50行代码和一个工具。如果你的智能体能执行Bash命令，它就能完成所有任务，包括读取文件（用cat）、写入文件（用sed/patch/awk/perl）、搜索文本、查找文件以及其他任何你可能需要的操作。那些专用工具只是为了让智能体工作更便捷的优化手段。它们确实能提升性能（这里指“能处理多少任务”而非“处理速度多快”），但并非绝对必要。在我看来，这是2025年与大型语言模型相关的重要发现之一。你不需要那种会占用10%以上宝贵上下文空间、污染上下文的Github MCP，你只需要gh命令行工具——而智能体早已掌握其使用方法。

comments.author: mirzap
comments.content: The "200 lines" loop is a good demo of the shape of a coding agent, but it’s like "a DB is a B-tree" - technically true, operationally incomplete.The hard part isn’t the loop - it’s the boring scaffolding that prevents early stopping, keeps state, handles errors, and makes edits/context reliable across messy real projects.
comments.content_cn: "200行代码循环"很好地展示了编码代理的基本形态，但这就像说"数据库就是B树"——技术层面正确，实际操作不完整。真正的难点不在于循环本身，而在于那些枯燥的脚手架代码：防止过早终止、保持状态、处理错误，以及在混乱的真实项目中确保编辑和上下文的可靠性。

comments.author: cmiles8
comments.content: A lot of software is like this. You can build a bare bones but functional version for 1x investment or something that addresses every bell and whistle (often with market research saying it’s really needed) for 1000x. The 1000x version is better, but not remotely 1000x better.A lot of SaaS has turned into this too. Take a bloated monstrosity like Salesforce and I bet 95% of customers would be very happy with a “bare bones” version that costs 1 10th the price.
comments.content_cn: 很多软件都是如此。你可以用1倍投入打造一个基础但可用的版本，也可以用1000倍成本做出面面俱到的产品（市场调研常声称这些功能必不可少）。后者确实更好，但远没有好上1000倍。许多SaaS服务也陷入这种模式。以臃肿不堪的Salesforce为例，我敢说95%的客户会对价格仅十分之一的“基础版”感到非常满意。

comments.author: vinhnx
comments.content:
This reminds me of Amp's article last year[1]. I building my own coding agent [2]. Two goals: understand real-world agent mechanics and validate patterns I'd observed across OpenAI Codex and contemporary agents.The core loop is straightforward: LLM + system prompt + tool calls. The differentiator is the harness, CLI, IDE extension, sandbox policies, filesystem ops (grep/sed/find). But what separates effective agents from the rest is context engineering. Anthropic and Manus has published various research articles around this topic.After building vtcode, my takeaway: agent quality reduces to two factors, context management strategy and model capability. Architecture varies by harness, but these fundamentals remain constant.[1] https://ampcode.com/how-to-build-an-agent
[2] https://github.com/vinhnx/vtcode
[3] https://www.anthropic.com/engineering/building-effective-age...
comments.content_cn:
这让我想起Amp去年的文章[1]。我正在构建自己的编程助手[2]。有两个目标：理解真实世界智能体的运行机制，并验证我在OpenAI Codex和当代智能体中观察到的模式。

核心循环很直接：大语言模型+系统提示+工具调用。真正的差异在于运行框架、命令行界面、集成开发环境扩展、沙箱策略、文件系统操作（如grep/sed/find）。但区分高效智能体的关键在于上下文工程。Anthropic和Manus已围绕该主题发表多篇研究论文。

构建vtcode后，我的结论是：智能体质量可归结为两个因素——上下文管理策略和模型能力。架构因运行框架而异，但这些基本原则始终不变。

[1] https://ampcode.com/how-to-build-an-agent
[2] https://github.com/vinhnx/vtcode

comments.author: joshmlewis
comments.content: This is cool but as someone that's built an enterprise grade agentic loop in-house that's processing a billion plus tokens a month, there are so many little things you have to account for that greatly magnify complexity in real world agentic use cases. For loops are an easy way to get your foot in the door and is indeed at the heart of it all, but there are a multitude of a little things that compound complexity rather quickly. What happens when a user sends a message after the first one and the agent has already started the tool loop? Seems simple, right? If you are receiving inputs via webhooks (like from a Slack bot), then what do you do? It's not rocket science but it's also not trivial to do right. What about hooks (guardrails) and approvals? Should you halt execution mid-loop and wait or implement it as an async Task feature like Claude Code and the MCP spec? If you do it async then how do you wake the agent back up? Where is the original tool call stored and how is the output stored for retrieval/insertion? This and many other little things add up and compound on each other.I should start a blog with my experience from all of this.
comments.content_cn: 这确实很酷，但作为亲自构建过企业级智能体循环系统、每月处理超10亿token的人，我必须指出在实际应用场景中有太多细节需要考虑，这些细节会极大增加复杂性。循环结构确实是入门的好方法，也确实是核心所在，但众多细微之处会迅速叠加复杂度。比如当用户在第一轮消息后发送新消息，而智能体已启动工具循环时该怎么处理？听起来简单对吧？如果通过webhook接收输入（比如Slack机器人），又该如何应对？这并非火箭科学，但要妥善处理也并不简单。还有钩子函数（防护机制）和审批流程呢？是否应该在循环中途暂停执行并等待，还是像Claude Code和MCP规范那样实现异步任务功能？如果采用异步方式，又该如何重新唤醒智能体？原始工具调用存储在哪里？输出结果又如何存储以供检索/插入？这些以及许多其他细节问题会相互叠加产生复合影响。我应该把这些经验整理成博客分享出来。

comments.author: jacob019
comments.content:
Seems everyone is working on the same things these days. I built a persistent Python REPL subprocess as an MCP tool for CC, it worked so insanely well that I decided to go all the way. I already had an agentic framework built around tool calling (agentlib), so I adapted it for this new paradigm and code agent was born.The agent "boots up" inside the REPL. Here's the beginning of the system prompt:  >>> help(assistant)

  You are an interactive coding assistant operating within a Python REPL.
  Your responses ARE Python code—no markdown blocks, no prose preamble.
  The code you write is executed directly.

  >>> how_this_works()

  1. You write Python code as your response
  2. The code executes in a persistent REPL environment
  3. Output is shown back to you IN YOUR NEXT TURN
  4. Call `respond(text)` ...

You get the idea. No need for custom file editing tools--Python has all that built in and Claude knows it perfectly. No JSON marshaling or schema overhead. Tools are just Python functions injected into the REPL, zero context bloat.I also built a browser control plugin that puts Claude directly into the heart of a live browser session. It can inject element pickers so I can click around and show it what I'm talking about. It can render prototype code before committing to disk, killing the annoying build-fix loop. I can even SSH in from my phone and use TTS instead of typing, surprisingly great for frontend design work. Knocked out a website for my father-in-law's law firm (gresksingleton.com) in a few hours that would've taken 10X that a couple years ago, and it was super fun.The big win: complexity. CC has been a disaster on my bookkeeping system, there's a threshold past which Claude loses the forest for the trees and makes the same mistakes over and over. Code agent pushes that bar out significantly. Claude can build new tools on the fly when it needs them. Gemini works great too (larger context).Have fun out there! /end-rant
comments.content_cn:
现在大家似乎都在做同样的事情。我最近为CC构建了一个持久化Python REPL子进程作为MCP工具，效果出奇地好，于是我决定全力以赴。我原本就有一个围绕工具调用构建的智能体框架（agentlib），因此我将其适配到这个新范式，代码智能体便诞生了。这个智能体在REPL环境中“启动”。以下是系统提示的开头部分：

>>> help(assistant)

你是一个在Python REPL内运行的交互式编程助手。
你的回复就是Python代码——无需Markdown代码块，无需文字说明。
你编写的代码会被直接执行。

>>> how_this_works()

1. 你以Python代码形式回复
2. 代码在持久化REPL环境中执行
3. 执行结果会在你的下一轮对话中显示

你应该明白了。不需要自定义文件编辑工具——Python内置了所有功能，而Claude对此了如指掌。没有JSON编组或模式开销。工具只是注入到REPL中的Python函数，零上下文膨胀。

我还开发了一个浏览器控制插件，让Claude直接接入实时浏览器会话的核心。它可以注入元素选择器，这样我就能点击页面并展示我正在讨论的内容。它能在代码保存到磁盘前渲染原型，彻底摆脱烦人的“修改-调试”循环。我甚至可以从手机SSH接入并使用语音转文字功能代替打字，这对前端设计工作来说意外地方便。我刚刚为我岳父的律师事务所快速搭建了一个网站（……

comments.author: sathish316
comments.content: Excellent article on the internals of coding CLIs.I learned a similarly powerful way to build DIY coding CLIs from this Martin Fowler post, which uses PydanticAI and MCP-based tools: https://martinfowler.com/articles/build-own-coding-agent.htm...Once you understand the underlying LLM tool-calling protocols described here—and how MCP tool calls work (they’re conceptually very similar)—most coding CLIs stop feeling like magic. Anthropic’s own deep dive on MCP was especially useful for me in seeing how to integrate this into a DIY “Claude Code”-style CLI, and even adapt the same approach for non-coding agents as well: https://www.deeplearning.ai/short-courses/mcp-build-rich-con...
comments.content_cn: 一篇关于编码命令行工具内部原理的精彩文章。我从Martin Fowler的这篇文章中学到了构建DIY编码命令行工具的类似强大方法，它使用了PydanticAI和基于MCP的工具：https://martinfowler.com/articles/build-own-coding-agent.htm...一旦理解了本文描述的底层LLM工具调用协议——以及MCP工具调用的工作原理（两者在概念上非常相似）——大多数编码命令行工具就不再显得神秘。Anthropic对MCP的深入探讨对我特别有帮助，让我明白了如何将其集成到DIY的“Claude Code”风格命令行工具中，甚至可以将相同方法应用于非编码智能体：https://www.deeplearning.ai/short-courses/mcp-build-rich-con...

comments.author: armcat
comments.content: The new mental model actually is (1) skills based model, i.e. https://agentskills.io/home, and (2) where the LLM agents "see all problems as coding problems". Skills are a bunch of detailed Markdowns and corresponding code libraries and snippets. The mental model thereby loops as follows: read only the top level descriptions in each SKILL.md, use those in-context to decide which skill to pick, after picking the relevant skill read the skill in-depth to choose which code/lib to use, based on the <problem, code/lib> generate new code, execute the code, evaluate, repeat. The problem-as-a-code mental model is also a great way of evaluating, and creating rewards and guarantees.
comments.content_cn: 新的心智模型实际上是（1）基于技能的模型，即https://agentskills.io/home，以及（2）让LLM智能体“将所有问题视为编码问题”。技能是一系列详细的Markdown文档及相应的代码库和片段。因此，该心智模型的循环如下：仅读取每个SKILL.md中的顶层描述，利用这些上下文信息决定选择哪种技能，选定相关技能后深入阅读该技能内容以选择使用哪个代码/库，基于此生成新代码，执行代码，评估，并重复此过程。将问题视为代码的心智模型也是进行评估、创建奖励和保证的绝佳方式。

comments.content: > This is the key insight: we’re just telling the LLM “here are your tools, here’s the format to call them.” The LLM figures out when and how to use them.This really blew my mind back then in the ancient times of 2024-ish. comments.content_cn: 关键洞察在于：我们只是告诉大语言模型“这些是你的工具，这是调用它们的格式”。大语言模型自己会判断何时以及如何使用这些工具。这在2024年左右的“远古时代”确实让我大为震撼。我记得当时刚接触到智能体的概念，开始阅读各种“我构建了一个能实现某功能的智能体”的文章，却始终无法理解大语言模型究竟如何“知道”调用工具——它明明只是个程序，而大语言模型只能生成文本！是的，我明白你在向大语言模型描述工具，但接下来呢？直到我终于意识到：没有下一步了，除了解释之外无需任何额外操作——说实话，这种认知确实有种奇妙的魔力。

comments.author: dmvaldman
comments.content: This misses that agentic LLMs are trained via RL to use specific tools. Adding custom tools is subpar to those the model has been trained with. That's why Claude Code has an advantage, over say, Cursor, by being vertically integrated.
comments.content_cn: 这种观点忽略了智能型大语言模型是通过强化学习训练来使用特定工具的。添加自定义工具的效果不如模型已训练使用的工具。这就是为什么Claude Code通过垂直整合相比Cursor等工具更具优势。

comments.author: nyellin
comments.content: There's a bit more to it!For example, the agent in the post will demonstrate 'early stopping' where it finishes before the task is really done. You'd think you can solve this with reasoning models, but it doesn't actually work on SOTA models.To fix 'early stopping' you need extra features in the agent harness. Claude Code does this with TODOs that are injected back into every prompt to remind the LLM what tasks remain open. (If you're curious somewhere in the public repo for HolmesGPT we have benchamrks with all the experiments we ran to solve this - from hypothesis tracking to other exotic approaches - but TODOs always performed best.)Still, good article. Agents really are just tools in a loop. It's not rocket science.
comments.content_cn: 事情比这更复杂一些！例如，帖子中的智能体会展示"提前停止"现象，即在任务真正完成前就结束了。你可能认为可以通过推理模型解决这个问题，但在当前最先进的模型上实际并不奏效。要修正"提前停止"问题，需要在智能体框架中加入额外功能。Claude Code通过将待办事项重新注入每个提示来实现这一点，以提醒大语言模型哪些任务尚未完成。（如果你好奇的话，在HolmesGPT的公共代码库中，我们保存了为解决这个问题进行的所有实验测试——从假设追踪到其他特殊方法——但待办事项始终表现最佳。）不过，这仍然是篇好文章。智能体本质上只是循环中的工具，并非什么高深莫测的技术。

comments.author: tptacek
comments.content: What's interesting to me about the question of whether you could realistically compete with Claude Code (not Claude, but the CLI agent) is that the questions boil down to things any proficient developer could do. No matter how much I'd want  to try, I have no hope of building a competitive frontier model --- "frontier model" is a distinctively apt term. But there's no such thing as a "frontier agent", and the Charmbracelet people have as much of a shot at building something truly exception as Anthropic does.

comments.author: libraryofbabel
comments.content: It's a great point and everyone should know it: the core of a coding agent is really simple, it's a loop with tool calling.Having said that, I think if you're going to write an article like this and call it "The Emperor Has No Clothes: How to Code Claude Code in 200 Lines of Code", you should at least include a reference to Thorsten Ball's excellent article from wayyy back in April 2025 entitled "How to Build an Agent, or: The Emperor Has No Clothes" (https://ampcode.com/how-to-build-an-agent)! That was (as far as I know) the first of these articles making the point that the core of a coding agent is actually quite simple (and all the deep complexity is in the LLM). Reading it was a light-bulb moment for me.FWIW, I agree with other commenters here that you do need quite a bit of additional scaffolding (like TODOs and much more) to make modern agents work well. And Claude Code itself is a fairly complex piece of software with a lot of settings, hooks, plugins, UI features, etc. Although I would add that once you have a minimal coding agent loop in place, you can get it to bootstrap its own code and add those things! That is a fun and slightly weird thing to try.(By the way, the "January 2025" date on this article is clearly a typo for 2026, as Claude Code didn't exist a year ago and it includes use of the claude-sonnet-4-20250514 model from May.)Edit: and if you're interested in diving deeper into what Claude Code itself is doing under the hood, a good tool to understand it is "claude-trace" (https://github.com/badlogic/lemmy/tree/main/apps/claude-trac...). You can use it to see the whole dance with tool calls and the LLM: every call out to the LLM and the LLM's responses, the LLM's tool call invocations and the responses from the agent to the LLM when tools run, etc. When Claude Skills came out I used this to confirm my guess about how they worked (they're a tool call with all the short skill descriptions stuffed into the tool description base prompt). Reading the base prompt is also interesting. (Among other things, they explicitly tell it not to use emoji, which tracks as when I wrote my own agent it was indeed very emoji-prone.)

comments.content: >  there's a threshold past which Claude loses the forest for the trees and makes the same mistakes over and over.Try using something like Beads with Claude Code. Also don't forget to have a .claude/instructions.md file, you can literally ask Claude to make it for you, this is the file Claude reads every time you make a new prompt. If Claude starts acting "off" you tell it to reread it again. With Beads though, I basically tell Claude to always use it when I pitch anything, and to always test that things build after it thinks its done, and to ask me to confirm before closing a task (They're called beads but Claude figures what I mean).With Beads the key thing I do though once all that stuff is setup is I give it my ideas, it makes a simple ticket or tickets. Then I both braindump and / or ask it to do market research on each item and the parameters I want to be considered, and then to update the task accordingly. I then review them all. Then I can go "work on these in parallel" and it spins up as many agents as there are tasks, and goes to work. I don't always make it do the work in parallel if its a lot of tasks because Zed has frozen up on me, I read that Claude Code is fine its just the protocol that Zed uses that gets hosed up.I find that with Beads, because I refine the tickets with Claude, it does way better at tasks this way. It's like if you're hand crafting the "perfect" prompt, but the AI model is writing it, so it will know exactly what you mean because it wrote it in its own verbiage.
comments.content_cn: 存在一个临界点，一旦超过这个点，Claude就会陷入细节而忽略整体，并反复犯同样的错误。可以尝试搭配使用类似Beads这样的工具与Claude Code。另外别忘了设置一个.claude/instructions.md文件——你完全可以直接让Claude帮你生成这个文件，这是每次新建提示时Claude都会读取的配置文件。如果Claude表现开始“失常”，就让它重新读取这个文件。至于Beads，我基本上会要求Claude在提出任何方案时都使用它，并在自认为完成后始终测试构建是否成功，还要在关闭任务前请我确认（虽然它们叫“珠子”，但Claude能理解我的意思）。当这些设置完成后，我使用Beads的关键流程是：先提出想法，让它生成简洁的任务单。接着我会进行头脑风暴，或要求它对每个条目进行市场调研并考虑我设定的参数，然后据此更新任务。我会审核所有内容，随后指示“并行处理这些任务”，它就会启动与任务数量对应的代理程序开始工作。如果任务量太大，我不总是让它并行处理，因为Zed曾因此卡死——我了解到Claude Code本身没问题，问题出在Zed使用的协议上。我发现通过Beads与Claude共同完善任务单后，它的任务执行效果显著提升。这就像手工打造“完美”提示词的过程，但实际由AI模型撰写，因此它能精准理解你的意图——毕竟这是它自己写的内容。
