comments.content: I've had a LOT of success keeping a "working memory" file for CLI agents. Currently testing out Codex now, and what I'll do is spend ~10mins hashing out the spec and splitting it into a list of changes, then telling the agent to save those changes to a file and keep that file updated as it works through them. The crucial part here is to tell it to review the plan and modify it if needed after every change. This keeps the LLM doing what it does best (short term goals with limited context) while removing the need to constantly prompt it. Essentially I feel like it's an alternative to having subagents for the same or a similar result

comments.content: Ohh, looks interesting, thanks for the tip!Git as db is clever, and the sqlite cache is nice. I'd been sketching sqlite based memory features myself. So much of the current ecosystem is suboptimal just because it's new. The models are trained around immutable conversation ledgers with user/tool/assistant blocks, but there are compelling reasons to manipulate both sides at runtime and add synthetic exchanges. Priming with a synthetic failure and recovery is often more effective than a larger, more explicit system message. Same with memory, we just haven't figured out what works best.For code agents specifically, I found myself wanting old style completion models without the structured turn training--doesn't exist for frontier models. Talking to Claude about its understanding of the input token stream was fascinating; it compared it to my visual cortex and said it'd be unreasonable to ask me to comment on raw optic nerve data."Tell it to reread it again"-exactly the problem. My bookkeeping/decision engine has so much documentation I'm running out of context, and every bit is necessary due to interconnected dependencies. Telling it to reread content already in the window feels wrong, that's when I refine the docs or adjust the framework. I've also found myself adding way more docstrings and inline docs than I'd ever write for myself. I prefer minimal, self-documenting code, so it's a learning process.There's definitely an art to prompts, and it varies wildly by model, completely different edge cases across the leading ones. comments.content_cn: 一方面，它似乎是在拆分任务并评估复杂度，然后根据复杂度将任务分配给相应模型以节省资源。当我使用Opus 4.5运行Claude并执行/cost命令时，能看到Opus 4.5消耗的令牌数，但同时Sonnet和Haiku模型也消耗了大量令牌，实际上大部分令牌是由Haiku模型使用的。

comments.author: mickeyp
comments.content: Models just naturally arrive at a conclusion that they are done. TODO hints can help, but is not infallible: Claude will stop and happily report there's more work to be done and "you just say the word Mister and I'll continue" --- this is a RL problem where you have to balance the chance of an infinite loop (it keeps thinking there's a little bit more to do when there is not) versus the opposite where it stops short of actual completion.
comments.content_cn: 模型会自然而然地得出任务已完成的结论。待办事项提示虽能提供帮助，但并非万无一失：克劳德会停下来并愉快地报告还有工作要做，并表示“您只需吩咐一声，先生，我就会继续”——这是一个强化学习问题，需要在无限循环风险（即任务实际已完成却仍认为还有少量工作）与过早停止（即实际未完成却提前终止）之间取得平衡。

posts.title: AI is a business model stress test
posts.author: amarsahinovic
posts.title_cn: AI是对商业模式的压力测试
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕“AI是否构成商业模式的压力测试”展开。有用户认为AI如同地震，本身不摧毁企业，而是暴露其商业模式的脆弱性，例如Tailwind Labs因AI能快速生成定制化代码而面临困境。讨论中提到，部分人将AI比作电灯泡取代蜡烛，认为这是技术进步带来的必然变革，而非单纯的“压力测试”。也有用户指出，AI正在将可明确指定的工作商品化，但无法替代需要持续运维和实际执行的任务，如保障系统稳定与安全。分歧在于如何看待AI的影响：有人认为它迫使企业重新思考价值所在，即从“指定需求”转向“实际交付”；也有用户质疑将商业模式挑战归咎于AI是否合理，强调企业本就需随环境变化而调整。共识是AI正深刻改变软件行业的价值分配，但对其具体定位仍存在不同解读。

comments.author: heliumtera
comments.content:
Tailwind Labs relied on a weird monetization scheme. 
Revenue was proportional to the pain of using the framework. The sudden improvement in getting desired UI without relying on pre-built templates killed Tailwind Labs.There are many initiatives in a similar spot, improving your experience at using Next.js would hurt Vercel. 
Making GitHub actions runners more reliable, stable and economical would hurt Microsoft. 
Improving accessibility to compute power would hurt Amazon, Microsoft and Google. 
Improving control and freedom over your device would hurt apple and Google.Why should we be sympathetic to the middleman again?If suddenly CSS became pleasant to use, Tailwind would be in a rough spot. See the irony?"Give everything away for free and this people will leave technology", geohot said something like this and I truly appreciate. Technology will heal finally
comments.content_cn: Tailwind Labs依赖一种奇怪的盈利模式。其收入与使用该框架的痛苦程度成正比。突然之间，无需依赖预制模板就能轻松实现理想UI的改进，反而扼杀了Tailwind Labs。许多类似项目也面临同样处境：提升Next.js的使用体验会损害Vercel的利益；让GitHub Actions运行器更可靠、稳定且经济会损害微软的利益；提高计算资源的可及性会损害亚马逊、微软和谷歌的利益；增强用户对设备的控制权和自由度则会损害苹果和谷歌的利益。我们为何要再次同情这些中间商呢？如果CSS突然变得好用起来，Tailwind的处境将十分艰难。这讽刺吗？“把所有东西免费送出去，这些人就会离开技术领域”——geohot曾说过类似的话，我深表赞同。技术终将自我修复。

comments.author: ronsor

comments.content_cn: 我看到这些评论里的“黑客”现在正鼓吹将“商业模式刑事藐视”变成一件严肃的事情，而不仅仅是用来形容严苛的版权和专利法的一个梗。

comments.content_cn: 称之为压力测试似乎不太恰当。难道我们会说灯泡的发明是对蜡烛相关商业模式的"压力测试"吗？或许我们更应该说商业模式必须顺应时势而改变。

comments.author: Schnitz
comments.content: The root of the issue is that Tailwind was selling something that people can now recreate a bespoke version of in mere minutes using a coding agent. The other day I vibe coded a bespoke dependabot/renovate replacement in an hour. That was way easier than learning any of these tools and fighting their idiosyncrasies that don’t work for me. We no longer need Framer because you can prompt a corporate website faster than you can learn Framer. It is, fortunately or unfortunately, what it is and we all have to adapt.I want to be clear, it sucks for Tailwind for sure and the LLM providers essentially found a new loophole (training) where you can smash and grab public goods and capture the value without giving anything back. A lot of capitalists would say it’s a genius move.
comments.content_cn: 问题的根源在于，Tailwind过去销售的产品，现在人们只需几分钟就能用编码助手定制出专属版本。前几天我用一小时就随手编写了一个替代dependabot/renovate的定制方案。这比学习任何现有工具并克服它们那些不适合我的特性要容易得多。我们不再需要Framer，因为生成一个企业网站的速度已经快过学习Framer的时间。无论幸与不幸，现实如此，我们都必须适应。需要明确的是，这对Tailwind来说无疑是沉重的打击，而大型语言模型提供商实质上找到了新漏洞（训练机制），使他们能够攫取公共资源并独占价值却无需回馈。许多资本家会称这是天才之举。

comments.author: big_toast
comments.content: "The value got extracted, but compensation isn't flowing back. That bothers me, and it deserves a broader policy conversation.What I keep coming back to is this: AI commoditizes anything you can fully specify. [...]So where does value live now? In what requires showing up, not just specifying. Not what you can specify once, but what requires showing up again and again."This seems like a useful framing to be aware of, generally.The internet has always kinda run on the ambiguity of "does the value flow back". A quote liberated from this article itself; all the content that reporters produce that's laundered back out through twitter; 12ft.io; torrents; early youtube; late youtube; google news; apache/mit vs gnu licenses; et cetera..
comments.content_cn: 价值被提取了，但补偿并未回流。这让我感到困扰，值得展开更广泛的政策讨论。我不断思考的是：人工智能将任何你能明确指定的东西商品化。[……]那么价值现在存在于何处？在于那些需要亲身呈现的事物，而不仅仅是明确指定。不是你一次性就能指定的东西，而是需要反复呈现的事物。这似乎是一个值得了解的实用框架。互联网的运行始终伴随着“价值是否回流”的模糊性。引用这篇文章本身的话：记者生产的所有内容通过推特被洗白再传播；12英尺网站；种子下载；早期的油管；后期的油管；谷歌新闻；阿帕奇/MIT许可证与GNU许可证的对比；等等。

提供人工智能服务的公司应当为AI所使用的工具展示广告。我指的不是"Tailwind可以付费在Gemini中投放广告"，而是说"当谷歌在其输出结果中使用该库时，应当清晰明确地标注回溯至Tailwind的链接"。他们已经在深度研究输出中实践了类似做法，甚至可能更早。但输出形式应该减少低调、内嵌、隐蔽的风格，转而采用更醒目的"我使用了Tailwind！了解如何优化使用[请点击此处](链接)"这样的表述。

comments.author: kachapopopow
comments.content: I know for a fact that all SOTA models have linux source code in them, intentionally or not which means that they should follow the GPL license terms and open-source part of the models which have created derivative works out of it.yes, this is indirectly hinting that during training the GPL tainted code touches every single floating point value in a model making it derivative work - even the tokenizer isn't immune to this.

comments.author: porkloin
comments.content: Yep - exactly. Ops isn't immune to LLMs stealing your customers. Given that most of the "open source product with premium hosting" models are just reselling hyperscaler compute at a huge markup, the customers are going to realize pretty quickly that they can use an LLM to setup some basic devops and get the same uptime. Most of these companies are offering a middleman service that becomes a bad deal the moment the customer has access to expertise they previously lacked.I also think he's glossing over the fact that one of the reasons why companies choose to pay for "ops" to run their software for them is because it's built by amateurs or amateurs-playing-professional and runs like shit. I happen to know this first hand from years of working at a company selling hosting and ops for the exact same CMS that Dries' business hosts (Drupal, a PHP-based CMS) and the absolute garbage that some people are able to put together in frameworks like Wordpress and Drupal is truly astounding. I'm not even talking about the janky local businesses where their nephew who was handy with computers made them a Wordpress site - big multinational companies have sites in these frameworks that can barely handle 1x their normal traffic and more or less explode at 1.5x.The business of hosting these customers' poorly optimized garbage remains a big business. But we're entering into an era where the people who produce poorly optimized software have a different path to take rather than throwing it to a SaaS platform that can through sheer force of will make their lead-weight airplane fly. They can spend orders of magnitude less money to pay an LLM to make the software actually just not run like shit in the first place. comments.author: theropost
comments.content: I think there is a real issue here, but I do not think it is as simple as calling it theft in the same way as copying books. The bigger problem is incentives. We built a system where writing docs, tutorials, and open technical content paid off indirectly through traffic, subscriptions, or services. LLMs get a lot of value from that work, but they also break the loop that used to send value back to the people and companies who created it.The Tailwind CSS situation is a good example. They built something genuinely useful, adoption exploded, and in the past that would have meant more traffic, more visibility, and more revenue. Now the usage still explodes, but the traffic disappears because people get answers directly from LLMs. The value is clearly there, but the money never reaches the source. That is less a moral problem and more an economic one.Ideas like GPL-style licensing point at the right tension, but they are hard to apply after the fact. These models were built during a massive spending phase, financed by huge amounts of capital and debt, and they are not even profitable yet. Figuring out royalties on top of that, while the infrastructure is already in place and rolling out at scale, is extremely hard.That is why this feels like a much bigger governance problem. We have a system that clearly creates value, but no longer distributes it in a sustainable way. I am not sure our policies or institutions are ready to catch up to that reality yet.
comments.content_cn:
我认为这里确实存在一个问题，但我不认为简单地将其等同于抄袭书籍那样的盗窃行为。更核心的问题在于激励机制。我们建立了一个体系，其中编写文档、教程和开源技术内容能通过流量、订阅或服务间接获得回报。大语言模型从这些工作中获取了大量价值，但它们也打破了原本将价值回馈给创作者个人和公司的循环。

Tailwind CSS 的情况就是一个很好的例子。他们创造了一个真正有用的工具，使用量激增，在过去这意味着更多的流量、更高的知名度和更多的收入。如今使用量依然暴涨，但流量却消失了，因为人们直接从大语言模型获取答案。价值显然存在，但资金从未流向源头。这与其说是道德问题，不如说是个经济问题。

类似 GPL 风格许可证的想法指出了关键矛盾，但事后实施起来很困难。这些模型是在大规模投入阶段构建的，由巨额资本和债务资助，甚至尚未实现盈利。在基础设施已经就位并大规模推广的情况下，还要在此基础上厘清版权分成，这极其困难。

这就是为什么这更像一个重大的治理问题。我们拥有一个明显创造价值的体系，却不再以可持续的方式分配价值。我不确定我们的政策或机构是否已准备好应对这一现实。

posts.title: ChatGPT Health is a marketplace, guess who is the product?
posts.author: yoaviram
posts.title_cn: ChatGPT健康是一个市场，猜猜谁是产品？
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕ChatGPT Health服务展开，核心话题是用户健康数据的使用与隐私风险。多数用户肯定AI在健康咨询中的实用价值，如帮助理解病情、改善医患沟通，并认为用户需求真实存在。但社区对数据安全与商业模式存在明显分歧：部分用户担忧健康数据可能被用于商业推销、保险拒保或就业歧视，并指出OpenAI在隐私保护上弱于苹果等公司；也有用户强调科技公司惯于利用用户数据获利，此类风险并不新鲜。同时，有用户提到不同AI工具（如Gemini、Claude）在健康话题上的回应策略差异影响了使用体验。讨论中普遍认同监管的必要性，并出现了对开源本地化解决方案的期待，以规避法律与隐私隐患。欧洲用户则对本地隐私法规表示满意。

comments.author: bwb
comments.content: ChatGPT has made a material difference in my ability to understand health problems, test results, and to communicate with doctors effectively. My wife and I were talking last night about how helpful it was in 2025. I hope that it continues to be good at this.I want regulators to keep an eye on this and make smart laws. I don't want it to go away, as its value is massive in my life.(One example, if you are curious: I've been doing rehab for a back injury for about 10 years. I worked with a certified trainer/rehab professional for many years and built a program to keep me as pain-free as possible. I rebuilt the entire thing with ChatGPT/Gemini about 6 weeks ago, and I've had less pain than at any other point in my life. I spent at least 12 hours working with AI to test and research every exercise, and I've got some knowledge to help guide me, but I was amazed by how far it has come in 12 months. I ran the results by a trainer to double-check it was well thought out.)
comments.content_cn: ChatGPT显著提升了我理解健康问题、解读检测报告以及与医生有效沟通的能力。昨晚我和妻子还在讨论它在2025年给我们带来的巨大帮助。希望它能持续保持这样的水准。我期待监管机构能持续关注并制定明智的法规。我不希望它消失，因为它对我的生活具有不可估量的价值。（举个例子：我因背部损伤进行康复治疗已近十年，曾与持证训练师/康复专家长期合作制定了一套疼痛管理方案。六周前我借助ChatGPT/Gemini重构了整个方案，现在疼痛感已降至人生最低水平。我花费至少12小时与AI测试研究每个训练动作，虽然具备一定专业知识进行引导，但它在12个月内的进步速度令我惊叹。最终我还请训练师核验了方案以确保其严谨性。）

posts.title: OLED, Not for Me
posts.author: c0nsumer
posts.title_cn: OLED，非我所选
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕OLED显示器在文本显示方面的表现展开。核心争议在于OLED的次像素排列方式是否适合文字工作。多数用户认同，传统RGB条纹排列的LCD在文本清晰度上仍具优势，OLED的非常规像素布局会导致文字边缘出现彩色镶边（fringing），尤其在低分辨率或小字体下更明显。

有用户指出，自己使用OLED作为显示器时文本显示效果很差，令人难以忍受。也有用户提到，新一代OLED（如LG第四代产品）通过改进像素排列，文本可读性已有所提升。讨论中提到，部分用户认为这本质上是字体渲染软件未能适配OLED次像素布局的问题，而非OLED技术本身的缺陷。

共识在于，OLED在动态画面（如游戏、影视）上表现优异，但作为静态文本工作的桌面显示器仍存在短板。分歧点主要在于：部分用户认为通过设置调整或新一代技术已能改善文本显示；另一部分用户则坚持LCD（尤其是IPS面板）目前仍是文字工作的更可靠选择。

comments.author: aappleby

That works out to 1.6mm or 1.8mm high characters on a 140 dpi screen, or about 1/16 of an inch.He's also got Cleartype on and set to RGB stripe even though the OLED is not RGB stripe (though to be fair, Windows doesn't really make it clear what each page of the ClearType tuner does).But yeah, if you use a _tiny_ font and sit _really_ close to the screen, you see fringing. In practice for me, it's been unnoticeable.
comments.content_cn: 这家伙居然在抱怨9到10像素高字体上的边缘锯齿问题。在140 dpi的屏幕上，这相当于1.6毫米或1.8毫米高的字符，大约只有1/16英寸。他还开着ClearType并设置为RGB条纹模式，尽管OLED屏幕并非RGB条纹排列（不过公平地说，Windows确实没有明确说明ClearType调节器的每个页面具体是做什么的）。但确实，如果你使用极小的字体并且紧贴屏幕观看，确实能看到边缘锯齿。就我个人实际使用而言，这个问题几乎察觉不到。

comments.author: mathisd
comments.content:
Author doesn't mention it but he should try to use BetterDisplay.
MacOS interface scaling works well for screens around 200 PPI (2K 13inch, 4K 24inch, 5K 27inch). 4K 32inch is 138 PPI, which likely means he is not using default interface scaling which causes some distortion and out of grid pixel rendering.
BetterDisplay fixes this by using an integer multiple of intended GUI scaling resolution before projecting it (3X -> 1.5X).

comments.author: bob1029
comments.content: Something to consider is that the sub pixel layout of OLED is an engineering necessity to achieve longevity and cost (panel yield) objectives.LCD can have a uniform layout because it's a passive layer doing the filtering. In OLED, each pixel is active and that blue one is trying to burn itself out much faster than the other two.
comments.content_cn: 需要考虑的是，OLED的子像素排列是为了实现寿命和成本（面板良率）目标而采取的工程必要方案。LCD可以采用均匀排列是因为其滤光层是被动层。而在OLED中，每个像素都是主动发光的，其中蓝色像素的衰减速度远快于另外两种颜色。

posts.title: Start your meetings at 5 minutes past
posts.author: otoolep
posts.title_cn: “在整点过5分钟开始会议”
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕“会议是否应从整点推迟5分钟开始”展开。支持者认为这种做法能提供缓冲时间，便于参会者切换会议或处理杂务，有助于提高效率并缓解日程压力。有用户指出其实践中确实缩短了会议时长，使45分钟会议成为可能；也有人认为这能营造轻松氛围，促进会前交流。

反对者则提出多个问题：有人认为这会导致会议同样延迟5分钟结束，抵消其优势；也有用户指出日历软件显示不清容易造成混淆，反而引发通知干扰；还有观点强调守时文化更重要，认为此举可能纵容拖延。讨论中提到，部分公司试行后发现效果取决于具体执行方式，若缺乏严格时间管理，延迟开始可能演变为整体效率下降。整体而言，社区未形成共识，但普遍认同关键在于培养守时习惯与高效控会能力。

comments.author: tanvach
comments.content:
During the pandemic, we had a natural experiment at my previous company. Our org had started an org wise auto ‘meeting starts 5 minute past’ while others had the traditional meetings start on the hour.Also conveniently, we also had the calendar data for internal meetings, internal VC software (not zoom) db that logs the participants when they join and leave meetings and employee function db.I was serendipitously the lead DS for analyzing the effectiveness of the ‘starting 5 minutes past’. After joining and cleaning a lot of the data, the data showed:1) at the start of the trial, meetings ended on time. Then after few weeks it slip to ending late, negating the usefulness. Other orgs did not see meetings running late.
2) ICs tend to stick around and over run meetings, while managers tend to leave meetings on time.
3) if I remember right, we had a survey data that showed pretty clearly that managers prefer the ‘starting 5 minutes past’ while ICs do not care or have negative sentiment.The biggest predictor for people who prefer starting late is how crowded their schedules are. Managers tend to have very crowded schedules which means they want a break between meetings, while ICs prefer not having to waste time waiting.In the end we reverted back to normal schedule. It was just easier for busy people to bounce early.
comments.content_cn:
疫情期间，我前公司进行了一次自然实验。我们部门推行了全部门范围的自动“会议延迟5分钟开始”机制，而其他部门仍保持传统的整点开会模式。恰巧，我们拥有内部会议日历数据、记录参会者加入和离开时间的内部视频会议软件（非Zoom）数据库，以及员工职能数据库。

我恰好负责主导分析“延迟5分钟开始”措施效果的数据工作。在整合清理大量数据后，结果显示：
1）试验初期，会议能准时结束。但几周后，会议结束时间逐渐推迟，使该措施失去意义。其他部门未出现会议超时现象。
2）一线员工倾向于滞留并延长会议，而管理者通常准时离会。
3）若记忆无误，我们的调研数据清晰表明：管理者更青睐“延迟5分钟开始”，一线员工则对此无感或持负面态度。

预测人们是否偏好延迟开会的最强指标是其日程紧凑程度。管理者日程通常非常满，因而需要会议间隙的缓冲时间；而一线员工更不愿浪费时间等待。

最终我们恢复了常规会议安排。对忙碌者而言，提前离会确实更为便利。

comments.author: dxdm
comments.content: In my experience, the recipe for having meetings interface smoothly with the time that surrounds them is twofold:1. Constrain the meeting duration to a slighly smaller blocks than natural time.2. Be diligent and efficient in managing time within the meeting.That means, for 60 minutes of natural time, 50 minutes of meetings.You start on time, you end on time.The first few minutes are for pleasantries (important!) and getting everyone focused on the topic and goals of the meeting. This gives people the possibility of running slightly late without missing anything too important, but they still come into an ongoing meeting and are noticeably late.But: you quickly move on to the meat of the meeting, even if people are still missing, and keep things moving while having an eye on time. (Sometimes, you can even start without key people there and at least get everyone else synced and thinking about the topic.)Once you get close to the end (that is, 40 out of 50 minutes of runtime for an "hour"-long meeting, but depending on subject and people), you make sure to come to a conclusion and wrap things up by the 50 minute mark. If it's clear that's not enough time, you move to wrapping things up enough and discuss how you will keep the discussion going after the meeting time runs out. In any case, you have some time for parting pleasantries, while the meeing is officially over on time and people are free to leave.This leaves a bit of slack, while people expect to start and end on time, and it crucially gives everybody enough time to move between meetings with some breaks, even those unfortunate folks whose jobs consist of lots of back-to-back meetings.Starting on the (half) hour and ending after 50 (25) minutes works well, in my experience, and syncs well with the calendars of external meeting participants.I know this works, because I have been in meetings like this, and I have run meetings like this. Of course, this will not work in 100% of all meetings, but it can go a long way in making a lot of them much better.
comments.content_cn:
根据我的经验，让会议与周边时间顺畅衔接的秘诀有两点：一是将会议时长控制在比自然时间稍短的区块；二是在会议期间严谨高效地管理时间。这意味着，在60分钟的自然时间里，会议只占50分钟。准时开始，准时结束。

开场几分钟用于寒暄（这很重要！）并让所有人集中关注会议主题与目标。这样即使有人稍迟，也不会错过关键内容，但他们仍算迟到且会打断会议进程。但关键在于：即使有人缺席，也要迅速切入会议核心，并时刻关注时间推进议程。（有时甚至可以在关键人员未到场时先开始，至少让其他与会者同步信息并思考议题。）

临近结束时（比如50分钟的"一小时"会议进行到第40分钟，具体视议题和人员而定），要确保在50分钟前得出结论并完成收尾。若明显时间不足，则先进行阶段性总结，并讨论如何在会议时间结束后延续讨论。无论如何，要留出少许时间用于告别寒暄，同时会议已准时正式结束，参会者可自由离场。

这种方式既保留了弹性空间，又让参会者能预期会议始终准时进行，且……

comments.content: > there is social pressure not to allow meetings to run much past the top of the hour.I've never seen this pressure.> meetings rarely started on the dot anyway before this change.It's like I live in an entirely different world.Start meetings when they say they're going to start.  People will learn to show up quickly.  I think that works better than trying to psychologically game people into cooperation.  That just starts the classic treadmill.  You might have that one friend that you tell to show up half an hour before everyone else. They mentally add the half hour back because you're always giving such early times. comments.content_cn: 我们内部会议大多从整点过一刻开始，通常45分钟内就能结束。这样安排给那些全天排满会议的人留出了喘息空间。当他们与客户或其他部门通话时，对方往往也会迟到，而且由于之前的会议总是超时，他们连上厕所的时间都没有。

comments.author: ChiMan
comments.content: A norm of scheduling the “start” on the hour or half hour while really starting the meeting five minutes later also works. That way, attendees have an opportunity to arrive “on time” and chat if they like, building relationships in the process. The freedom to arrive at any point during the first five minutes also helps to create the kind of ease that’s conducive to serious discussion. This second part is particularly important when power dynamics might otherwise derail real discussion.Because five minutes of pure chitchat can feel excessive to some folks, though, a three-minute norm probably works better—-especially because the off-centeredness has the informal aesthetic that, again, forms a better backdrop for serious discussion.
comments.content_cn: 一种常见的做法是将会议开始时间安排在整点或半点，但实际上会推迟五分钟再正式开始。这样与会者就有机会“准时”到达，如果他们愿意还可以聊聊天，在这个过程中建立关系。在前五分钟内随时到达的自由也有助于营造一种轻松的氛围，有利于进行严肃的讨论。当权力动态可能阻碍真正讨论时，这第二部分尤为重要。不过，因为五分钟的纯粹闲聊对某些人来说可能显得过长，所以三分钟的惯例可能更合适——特别是因为这种非正式的美学再次为严肃讨论形成了更好的背景。

comments.author: PeterStuer

comments.content_cn: 如果你真心认同这一点，只需在每个小时的55分至05分之间有效屏蔽Teams即可。完全可以通过预先提交理由来允许例外情况。将所有事务从整点推迟到05分，充其量只是作秀，更多时候只会让情况越来越糟。

comments.author: teamonkey

comments.content_cn: 我希望Teams能显示会议的成本。输入参会人员的平均薪资估算，乘以参会人数，然后实时向每位参会者展示不断累积的会议开销。我认为这是最有效的方法，能减少会议数量、缩短会议时长，并降低参会者迟到的概率。

comments.author: VariousPrograms

comments.content_cn: 或者，你也可以准时参加我的会议。你只需点击“结束通话”，再点“加入”，整个过程只需3秒。Outlook会提前15分钟提醒，Webex或Teams也会提前5分钟通知。我相信你完全可以让手表震动或采取其他提醒方式。我办公室的人每次开会都迟到5分钟，因为现在没人指望会议能准时开始。所以，我们名义上定了时间，实际上却都在遵循这条潜规则。这真让我抓狂。

comments.author: ttul
comments.content: I have found significant frustration since the pandemic in the most unexpected place: the new expectation of punctuality for online meetings. In meatspace, in the before times, if a meeting was set for 2pm in the board room, everyone understood this to mean 2pm was the time to come through the door and chat for a bit while everyone got comfortable. The actual meeting would start at 2:05-2:10.Online, there is no equivalent to walking in the door for a bit of a chit chat. Everyone just materializes instantly and then we’re supposed to be ready to go by 2:01. I miss meatspace for meetings and the more casual, human-matched pace.
comments.content_cn: 疫情以来，我在最意想不到的地方感受到了巨大的挫败感：线上会议对守时的新要求。在过去面对面的时代，如果会议定在下午两点在会议室举行，大家都明白这意味着两点是大家进门、闲聊几句、各自安顿的时间。实际会议会在两点零五到两点十分开始。线上会议则没有相当于"进门闲聊"的缓冲环节。所有人都是瞬间闪现，然后我们就得在两点零一分准备就绪。我怀念线下会议那种更随意、更符合人性节奏的方式。

comments.author: conductr
comments.content: I’ve experienced this all before in similar ways. The metric for meetings ending on time isn’t even very useful because when it’s needed people will ask “do you have a hard stop?” or similarly agree to continue the meeting. Often because of all the points you made, it’s the IC that stick around to talk about finer points or specifics of what was decided or discussed. It’s best to do this while it’s fresh and between people that can “talk shop” at a granular level (whatever that means for your org/team). It’s actually a good thing your ICs want to collaborate or align separate from management. If you’re a manager and you could technically continue on the meeting, consider opting out to give them space as peers. I often ask “do you all need me to stay one?” and most often it’s a No. It all means that it’s basically 2 meetings occurring and it’s the scheduling calendar artifact that is faulty.
comments.content_cn: 我此前也经历过类似的情况。衡量会议是否准时结束的指标其实并不太实用，因为必要时人们会问"你有硬性截止时间吗？"或者同意延长会议。通常由于你提到的种种原因，往往是基层执行者留下来讨论更细致的要点或已决议事项的具体细节。最好趁记忆犹新时，在能够进行专业细节讨论的人员之间进行（具体程度视组织/团队而定）。实际上，基层执行者愿意在管理层不在场的情况下进行协作或协调是件好事。如果你是管理者，虽然技术上可以继续参会，不妨考虑主动退场，给予他们同事间的交流空间。我常会问"需要我留下吗？"，大多数时候答案是否定的。这本质上意味着同时在进行两场会议，问题出在日程安排这个形式本身。

comments.author: IndrekR

Starting time was given as ct (cum tempore, with time) or st (sine tempore, without time). Usually only st was marked as everybody assumed the 15 minutes delay.https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Academic_quarter_(class_timing...
comments.content_cn: 类似的概念曾被用于大学讲座，安排在整点后15分钟开始。这是因为当时没有人戴手表，所有时间都以整点教堂钟声为准。这样学生就有15分钟时间赶往下一场讲座（可能在另一栋楼）。开始时间会标注为ct（含时间）或st（不含时间）。通常只标记st，因为大家都默认有15分钟的延迟。

comments.author: bluenose69
comments.content: I work in a university environment.The teaching model is much like that proposed by the originator of this thread. This gives students and professors enough time to get from one lecture to another (unless they have to commute across a big campus, in which case they simply do not sign up for classes that are too close in time).I've served on a big committee on campus that solve the timing problem simply. It starts exactly on time. Every item has a designated number of minutes.  And if it appears that we will not finish on time, there is a vote on whether to extend the meeting by 30 minutes.I realize that a lot of the discussion on this thread involves bosses and employees, which is quite a different thing, of course. comments.content_cn: 我在大学环境中工作。教学模式与这个帖子的发起者提出的非常相似。课程时长是50分钟而非一小时（1.5小时的课程也类似）。上课时间从整点过5分钟开始，在整点前5分钟结束。这样学生和教授就有足够的时间从一个讲座赶到另一个（除非他们需要穿越一个很大的校园，那样的话他们就不会报名时间安排得太紧的课程）。我曾在一个大型校园委员会任职，该委员会简单地解决了时间安排问题。会议准时开始。每个议题都有指定的分钟数。如果看起来我们无法按时结束，就会投票决定是否将会议延长30分钟。我意识到这个帖子中的很多讨论涉及老板和员工，这当然是完全不同的情况。如果大老板迟到了，那么在指定时间开始会议就没有意义。

comments.author: anonzzzies
comments.content: I do connect 5 minutes past, but after the start of the meeting, just to miss the 'how was your weekend', 'let's do an introduction round' and other nonsense (the email invite already has intro's; i know people don't read, but that's not my problem).We mostly turned our internal and partner meetings around these days; meetings are organised and distributed by who thinks they are needed, everyone who could be needed is included (they basically have to answer when called upon during the meeting; that also keeps the meetings within bounds as no-one is going to answer anymore once the time passed) but they are called in only when needed which is to say, almost never in reality. comments.content_cn: 我确实会在会议开始后5分钟才加入，就是为了避开“周末过得怎样”、“我们先做个自我介绍”之类的废话（邮件邀请里已经有介绍了；我知道大家都不看，但这不是我的问题）。最近我们基本调整了内部及合作伙伴会议的模式：会议由认为有必要的人发起并通知，所有可能需要的人都会被列入名单（基本上会议中被点到时必须回应；这也让会议时间得到控制，因为一旦超时就不会再有人回应），但只有在真正需要时才会叫他们参与，也就是说，现实中几乎不会叫到。这让我们看清了以往这些会议的巨大浪费。

comments.author: zkid18
comments.content: I was bad in being on meeting discipline. The only thing that consistently works: start on time, end on time, and don’t wait for late arrivals. comments.content_cn: 我在会议纪律方面做得不好。唯一始终有效的方法是：准时开始、准时结束，不等待迟到者。如果有人迟到，他们可以通过笔记或录音自行跟上进度。卢卡斯影业与皮克斯的交易有个著名案例：一位卢卡斯影业高管曾习惯性迟到以彰显权力，直到史蒂夫·乔布斯开始准时开会不等他。该高管五分钟后走进会议室时，已完全失去现场掌控权。最终乔布斯拿下了这笔交易。

comments.author: kcplate
comments.content: In the early 90s I had a new department director who would bring a kitchen timer to every meeting.  Meetings started on precisely on time and the timer was set to 22 minutes.  When that bell rung, you could finish the thought, but the meeting would break at the 25 minute mark.  If you didn’t accomplish the agenda, another meeting could be set, but it needed to be at least 2 hours after the one that just broke.  Even meetings without him had to follow the rule.  He also had a request that were were supposed to follow if we could, which was to allow ourselves to only schedule one meeting in an hour.Obviously it was pretty chaotic at first and I recall us being pretty brutal in our assessment of his “crazy meeting quirk”.  However after a few weeks something pretty interesting happened:- Brevity and productive discussion became common.  People usually went with their best opinion- we usually finished the agenda (probably because we set reasonable agendas for 22 mis) and rarely needed that rollover meeting- we spent more time at our desks actually doing instead of just talking about doing.  I recall that team being really productive overall.Later when I moved into leadership roles I attempted to bring this methodology but my own leadership generally was not supportive enough to allow me to be as rigid and I didn’t see the same success with the method…but to this day 32+ years later I still think it had merit.I had asked him where he had learned it.  My recollection is that he formulated it after reading that the average person’s attention span in a meeting was 27 minutes and he figured no one was productive after that, so he decided it was pointless to go longer.
comments.content_cn:
九十年代初，我遇到一位新上任的部门主管，他每次开会都带着一个厨房计时器。会议总是准时开始，计时器设定为22分钟。铃响时，可以说完当前想法，但会议必须在25分钟时结束。如果议程未完成，可以另安排会议，但必须至少间隔两小时。即使他不在场的会议也必须遵守此规则。他还提出一个建议：尽量每小时只安排一场会议。

起初确实有些混乱，我记得大家对他这种"古怪的会议癖好"评价相当尖锐。但几周后发生了有趣的变化：
- 简洁高效的讨论成为常态，人们通常会提出最佳见解
- 我们基本都能完成议程（可能是因为设定了合理的22分钟议程），很少需要延期会议
- 更多时间用于实际工作而非空谈。我记得那个团队整体效率非常高。

后来我担任领导职务时，曾尝试推行这种方法，但上级领导不够支持，我无法严格执行，因此未能取得同等效果……但32年后的今天，我依然认为这个方法很有价值。

我曾问他从何处学来这个方法。我记得他……

comments.author: atoav
comments.content: Well the trick is to schedule the meeting at hh:mm, but start it at hh: mm+5 and then just make this a policy organization-wide.In academia (mostly European) this has been a concept for centuries to allow changes of classes to happen: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Academic_quarter_%28class_timi...So you can have a c.t. event (cum tempore = with time) or a s.t. event (sine tempore = without time).
comments.content_cn: 诀窍在于将会议安排在整点，但实际开始时间推迟五分钟，并将此作为整个组织的政策。在学术界（主要是欧洲），几个世纪以来一直存在这样的概念，以便课程调整能够顺利进行：https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Academic_quarter_%28class_timi... 因此你可以安排"顺延会议"（cum tempore，意为可延迟）或"准时会议"（sine tempore，意为不延迟）。

comments.author: dahart
comments.content: Okay, but only if this is balanced by accounting for the cost of IC engineers’ solo time too. This was after being incredibly frustrated by a guy on another team who would schedule his meetings to start on the hour, but then display a message that said we’d start at 5 after, to give people time to join, assuming other meetings would run long. This felt like he was wasting everyone’s time who showed up on time, and had the net effect of everyone showing up late to his meetings. If people learned they should show up late to his meetings, they can learn to show up on time to our meetings. Then we can stop waiting around hoping that everyone shows up. posts.title: Org Mode Syntax Is One of the Most Reasonable Markup Languages for Text (2017)
posts.author: adityaathalye
posts.title_cn: Org Mode 语法是最合理的文本标记语言之一（2017）
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕Org Mode语法是否是最合理的文本标记语言展开。有人认为Org Mode在项目管理、知识管理方面极具优势，其宏功能、与Emacs生态的深度集成及格式转换灵活性远超Markdown。也有用户指出，Markdown作为更通用的标记语言，在跨平台协作和易用性上更具优势，且通过Pandoc等工具也能满足基本需求。讨论中提到双方争议点包括：Org Mode的标题符号（如星号）是否适合人类阅读，以及语法转义机制是否便捷。尽管存在分歧，社区普遍认同Org Mode在Emacs环境下的强大功能，尤其是其结构化数据处理能力，但对于非Emacs用户而言，Markdown的普适性仍是重要考量。

Today I use it for all my project, task and knowledge management needs, with some files going over 15MB in size. And I'm still loving it. Started out with headers only, and every time I wanted something more, it was always just there for the taking. Easy to use, and also crazy powerful. Can't think of anything else that exhibits both those traits at once.

comments.author: tconfrey

Org allows me to unify my bookmark manager with the rest of my PKM as well as to-do management in a way that I don't think is possible with markdown.That said I think that AI is changing things as it becomes best practice to document and define everything in plain text for LLM consumption. Since the default text format is markdown (due to github and PKM tool support) more and more people are exposed to it as the one true markup language. So maybe the boat has sailed and org becomes another example of the better format that doesn't win out. OTOH LLMs slurp up org content just as easily as they do markdown, maybe more so given the richer syntax. So maybe there's still room for both?Either way I think the losers are going to be Sharepoint, Confluence, Jira etc, maybe even wikis, ie all the non standard ways people have been documenting their work to date.Like us org folks have been saying all along, just stick with plain text![0] https://braintool.org/2022/04/29/Tools4Thought-should-use-Or...

comments.author: tel
comments.content: I've recently begun replacing Markdown with Gemini's .gmi/gemtext format. It is Markdown with fewer features. I appreciate the simplicity and it's tremendously easy for custom tools to parse.It has no inline formatting, only 3 levels of ATX headers (without trailing #s), one level of bullet points using only asterisk and not dash to delimit, does not merge touching non-whitespace lines (thus expecting one line per paragraph), and supports only triple-backtick fenced preformatted text areas that just flip on and off.Maybe the biggest change is that links are necessarily listed on their own line, proceeded by a `=>` and optionally followed by alt-text.My gemtext parser is maybe 70 lines and it is arguably 95% of what one needs from Markdown.
comments.content_cn:
最近我开始用Gemini的.gmi/gemtext格式替代Markdown。这是一种功能更精简的Markdown。我欣赏它的简洁性，对于自定义工具来说解析起来也极其容易。它没有行内格式，只有3级ATX标题（尾部不带#号），仅使用星号而非短横线作为项目符号，且不合并相邻的非空行（因此每个段落都独占一行），仅支持用三个反引号标记的预格式化文本区域，其作用只是简单地开启和关闭格式。

或许最大的变化在于链接必须独占一行，以`=>`开头，后面可选择性地添加替代文本。我的gemtext解析器大约只有70行代码，却可以说实现了Markdown 95%的核心功能。

comments.content: There are attempts to extract it but I'm not sure any are successful. org mode is so tightly intertwined with Emacs features. posts.title: Eulogy for Dark Sky, a data visualization masterpiece (2023)
posts.author: skadamat
posts.title_cn: 《暗空》悼文：一部数据可视化杰作（2023）
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕已下线的天气应用Dark Sky展开，用户们怀念其卓越的数据可视化设计和用户体验。核心话题包括对Dark Sky界面精准性、信息呈现方式的赞赏，以及对替代应用的探讨。

多数用户认同Dark Sky在即时天气预报和界面直观性上的优势，有人认为其“本地天气一览”的准确度和用户体验至今未被超越，特别是苹果收购后未能延续其精度。同时，讨论中提到开源替代应用如Breezy Weather和MerrySky，也有用户推荐Windy.app等专业工具。

争议点集中在信息呈现方式上：有用户指出Dark Sky与其他应用类似，在温度范围显示上存在模糊性（如低温对应时段不明确）；也有用户认为其克隆版本无法完全复现原有设计。此外，部分用户强调天气预测本身存在不确定性，Dark Sky通过简化信息避免了“虚假精确”，这一设计理念获得认可。

整体上，社区普遍认为Dark Sky在数据可视化方面成就突出，而当前主流天气应用在界面设计和细节处理上仍存在不足。

comments.content_cn:
从截图来看，暗空天气应用存在一个我认为多数天气应用都处理不佳的问题。具体来说：每日显示温度范围（最低和最高值），但未明确最低温对应早晨还是夜晚，而这两个时段的温差可能极大。比如某天显示10-15度，次日显示0-10度，用户可能认为"今晚出门带件外套就行，不用戴帽子，毕竟今天最低才10度"，结果晚餐结束时气温已骤降至冰点。

应用本可通过多种方式优化这个问题。例如用垂直线状图替代离散柱状图，在日间过渡区域标注最低温；若坚持使用柱状图，可采用倾斜设计使最低温更贴近对应的清晨或夜间时段；甚至可以考虑显示三个温度值而非两个（比如包含前一天或后一天的最低温度等）。

posts.title: Changes to Android Open Source Project
posts.author: TechTechTech
posts.title_cn: Android 开源项目变更
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕Android开源项目（AOSP）的变更展开，核心话题是谷歌宣布将AOSP源代码发布频率从每季度一次改为每年两次。社区对此反应负面，普遍认为这进一步削弱了Android的开放性。

许多用户批评谷歌逐渐走向封闭，有人指出此举加剧了Android的“计划性淘汰”问题，导致设备更新滞后；也有用户将谷歌比作“1990年代的微软”，质疑其可信度。讨论中提到，部分用户认为苹果在开源内核发布上反而比谷歌更积极，甚至讽刺建议谷歌改名。此外，有用户借机批评Android的安全模式矛盾——厂商不及时更新系统却被视为“安全”，而用户自主“root”设备却被标记为不安全。

尽管存在分歧，社区共识是Android正变得越来越不开放，例如近期APK安装需身份验证等变化。有用户呼吁需要基于设备自由的第三方替代方案，反对苹果和谷歌的远程控制。不过，也有个别用户尝试从“稳定性”角度理解此变更，认为谷歌可能希望第三方开发基于更稳定的版本。整体上，社区对谷歌此举的动机持怀疑态度。

comments.author: crote
comments.content: Mobile is a massive chicken-and-egg problem. The main purpose of a smartphone these days is to run apps. Nobody is going to buy a smartphone which can't run the apps they need in their day-to-day life. On the other hand, no company is going to write apps for a platform with basically zero users.OpenMoko & friends are selling devices which basically only run Firefox, and sometimes make calls as well. The only people interested in that are diehard FLOSS enthusiasts, which means they have to use ancient hardware because new stuff doesn't have open drivers, which means that even if you ignore the app ecosystem they compare incredibly poorly to mainstream smartphones. No wonder they keep failing.Interestingly, the desktop/laptop market is heading the other way. The move to cloud SaaS products means a decent number of people now only need a browser. What's keeping a lot of people on Windows is often literally one or two applications. Valve's push for Proton is the perfect example of this: the Steam Deck is providing a huge incentive to fix those last few bugs keeping a game from running on Linux, and with the way Microsoft is screwing up W11 it is now ironically the gamers who are moving to Linux.What you are seeing in "regular computer stores" is mostly irrelevant. That market is basically dead. Corporate gets its machines directly from Dell/HP/Lenovo, PC enthusiasts mostly get custom builds, and casual people stick with smartphones and tablets. In-store PC sales is now reduced to a university student's Google Docs machine - and Microsoft is doing a pretty good job bribing the manufacturers to push Windows there.
comments.content_cn:
移动设备面临着一个巨大的先有鸡还是先有蛋的困境。如今智能手机的主要用途是运行应用程序。没有人会购买一台无法运行日常生活所需应用的智能手机。另一方面，也没有公司会为一个几乎没有用户的平台开发应用。OpenMoko等公司销售的设备基本上只能运行Firefox浏览器，偶尔还能打电话。对此感兴趣的只有铁杆的自由开源软件爱好者，这意味着他们不得不使用老旧的硬件，因为新设备没有开放的驱动程序。因此，即使不考虑应用生态系统，这些设备与主流智能手机相比也显得极其落后。难怪它们屡屡失败。

有趣的是，台式机和笔记本电脑市场正朝着相反的方向发展。向云端SaaS产品的转变意味着相当一部分人现在只需要一个浏览器。许多人仍然使用Windows，往往只是因为一两个特定的应用程序。Valve推动Proton就是一个绝佳的例子：Steam Deck为修复那些阻碍游戏在Linux上运行的最后几个漏洞提供了巨大动力。而微软在Windows 11上的糟糕表现，现在讽刺地让游戏玩家开始转向Linux。

你在“普通电脑商店”看到的情况大多无关紧要。那个市场基本上已经死了。企业直接从戴尔、惠普、联想采购设备，电脑爱好者大多选择自行组装，而普通用户则坚持使用智能手机和平板电脑。实体店的个人电脑销售现已缩减至……

posts.author: Anon84
posts.title_cn: "格陵兰为何是丹麦王国的一部分？简史"
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕格陵兰归属问题展开，核心涉及历史背景、地缘战略与当地民意。多数用户聚焦于美国对格陵兰的兴趣，尤其批评特朗普政府试图“购买”格陵兰的言论。有人认为这反映了强权政治的逻辑，指出“土地属于拥有更强武力且愿意使用的一方”，并以美国历史为例佐证。也有用户指出，美国在格陵兰的军事存在已大幅缩减，丹麦已提供全面军事准入，因此所谓“安全需求”并不成立。讨论中提到，格陵兰民意调查显示高达85%的居民反对加入美国，仅6%支持，凸显自决权的重要性。部分用户嘲讽美国一些舆论过度强调格陵兰的战略价值，实为替政治意图寻找借口。共识在于尊重格陵兰居民的意愿，分歧则体现在对强权政治的批判程度以及美国动机的解读上。

comments.content:
For context, The Guardian reports[1]:Inuit people are understood to have lived in Greenland since as early as 2,500BC and it was reached by Norse seafarers in the first millennium AD, who established settlements lasting several centuries. Modern colonisation began after the arrival of Hans Egede in 1721, acting with the support of what was then Denmark-Norway. During the second world war, when Denmark was occupied by Germany, Greenland was occupied by the US and was returned to Denmark in 1945.It became part of the kingdom of Denmark in 1953, and in 1979 home rule was introduced. But Denmark still controls Greenland’s foreign and security policy. It has its own parliament, Inatsisartut, and two MPs in the Danish parliament, Folketing. But calls for independence have been growing.Tensions have escalated significantly between Greenland and Denmark in recent years. There is intense anger in Greenland over investigations into the forced contraceptive (IUD) scandal of the 1960s and 70s, prompting the former Greenlandic prime minister to accuse Denmark of genocide. There have also been protests in Copenhagen and Nuuk over the separation of Greenlandic children from their parents.
Denmark has banned the use of highly controversial “parenting competency” tests on Greenlandic people that have resulted in Greenlandic mothers being separated from their children. In September, after years of failing to acknowledge the violations, Denmark officially apologised to the victims of the IUD scandal, in which thousands of Greenlandic women and girls were forcibly fitted with contraceptive coils without their knowledge or consent. And in December, victims won a legal fight with the Danish government to receive compensation.In recent years there has been growing support for Greenlandic independence. But amid the spectre of Trump’s threat, Greenland in March formed a new four-party coalition government in a show of national unity, with the first page of the coalition agreement stating: “Greenland belongs to us.” The pro-independence party, Naleraq, which is the most US- and Trump-friendly party, came second in the election and is now in opposition.
According to a 2009 agreement with Denmark, Greenland must hold a successful referendum before declaring independence.[1] https://www.theguardian.com/world/2026/jan/06/why-is-donald-...

posts.title: Show HN: I made a memory game to teach you to play piano by ear
posts.author: vunderba
posts.title_cn: 《展示HN：我制作了一款记忆游戏，教你用耳朵弹钢琴》
posts.abstract:
该HackerNews帖子展示了一款通过听力训练来学习钢琴的记忆游戏。核心话题围绕该游戏的教育价值、用户体验及功能改进展开讨论。

许多用户赞赏游戏的简洁设计和明确目标，认为它能有效训练听音能力。有钢琴学习背景的用户指出，这种训练方式与传统的铃木教学法相似，强调早期听觉开发。同时，多位用户提出了改进建议：有人认为游戏应允许自由试弹而不立即判误，以降低挫败感；也有用户希望增加更适合儿童或初学者的简易模式，如减少初始音符数量、放慢进度或高亮提示琴键。此外，部分用户提到界面交互问题，例如错误提示弹窗干扰专注度，以及音符需长按的操作不够直观。

讨论中明显存在分歧：一些用户享受难度递增的挑战，但另一些用户希望设置难度上限，认为过多音符会使游戏从音高练习变为纯粹的记忆测试，影响学习效果。普遍共识是游戏概念新颖且具有潜力，但需进一步优化用户体验和自定义设置以适应不同水平的使用者。

I've added a bunch of new updates, just thought I would consolidate to this message since its pinned near the top.*Changes*- Ableton keyboard layout for ladidahh also thanks for a user name that I had to type about four times because of my phone's autocorrect! :)- Tempo sliders for practice and Simon modes- Lock icon which lets you freeze the difficulty at a certain number of notes in Practice mode instead of constantly increasing- Floating display window in settings which displays stave and note that you are currently playing on a midi keyboard.*Future Updates*- Noodle time (let you play around to experiment before going O'Reilly Live)- Markov or Transformer (thanks viraptor) approach to generate more sonically pleasing melodies- Pianistic echoes (caetris24) - an optional visualization for the onscreen keyboard almost like a heat map pattern- Fix the weird iPhone audio issue (EdNutting had some good advice on this)- still looking at adding the Tracker 4-layout as proposed by moosedev*Helpful fixes*- Some midi controllers don't send a corresponding NOTE_OFF, instead they send a NOTE_ON with velocity of 0 (Thanks ta2112 for this helpful info)
comments.content_cn:

*更新内容*
- 为ladidahh添加了Ableton键盘布局——顺便感谢这位用户名让我因为手机自动更正打了大概四遍的用户！:)
- 练习模式和西蒙模式新增速度滑块
- 锁定图标：在练习模式中可将难度固定在特定音符数量，避免持续增加
- 设置中新增浮动显示窗口，可在MIDI键盘上实时显示当前演奏的五线谱和音符

*未来更新计划*
- 自由探索时间（在进入O'Reilly Live模式前提供自由试玩空间）
- 采用马尔可夫或Transformer模型（感谢viraptor建议）生成更悦耳的旋律
- 钢琴残影效果（caetris24提议）——屏幕键盘的可选可视化功能，类似热力图模式
- 修复iPhone音频异常问题（EdNutting对此提供了宝贵建议）
- 仍在考虑添加moosedev提议的Tracker四键布局

*技术修复*
- 部分MIDI控制器不发送NOTE_OFF信号，而是发送力度值为0的NOTE_ON信号（感谢ta2112提供此重要信息）

comments.author: ta2112
comments.content:
I can add a bit of information to what might be behind this bug.In MIDI, there are NOTE_ON and NOTE_OFF events, for when you press and release each key. The NOTE_ON has pitch and velocity parameters. The NOTE_OFF just has pitch parameter (maybe it has velocity as well I can't quite remember, it's off the point). So if you push middle C, it might look like this:NOTE_ON 60 (middle C) 98 (velocity),
NOTE_OFF 60Some keyboards never send NOTE_OFF events, instead they send NOTE_ON with velocity 0. On these keyboards, pressing middle C looks like this:NOTE_ON 60 98,
NOTE_ON 60 0Both are valid MIDI streams, and all stream processors should react appropriately to both. This app likely does not correctly map zero velocity NOTE_ON events to NOTE_OFF with the same pitch.
comments.content_cn:
我可以补充一些关于这个bug背后可能原因的信息。在MIDI协议中，存在NOTE_ON和NOTE_OFF两种事件，分别对应按键按下和释放的动作。NOTE_ON事件包含音高和力度参数，而NOTE_OFF事件通常只包含音高参数（或许也包含力度参数，我记不太清了，但这不影响核心问题）。例如按下中央C键时，数据流可能呈现为：NOTE_ON 60（中央C）98（力度），随后是NOTE_OFF 60。

有些键盘设备从不发送NOTE_OFF事件，而是通过发送力度值为0的NOTE_ON事件来替代。在这类设备上，按下中央C键的数据流会显示为：NOTE_ON 60 98，接着是NOTE_ON 60 0。这两种都是有效的MIDI数据流，所有流处理器都应该能正确处理这两种形式。当前这个应用很可能未能正确将力度值为0的NOTE_ON事件映射为对应音高的NOTE_OFF事件。

posts.title: Flock Hardcoded the Password for America's Surveillance Infrastructure 53 Times
posts.author: fuck_flock
posts.title_cn: 美国监控基础设施密码被Flock公司硬编码53次
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕Flock公司在美国监控基础设施中硬编码密码的安全事件展开。核心争议在于企业安全疏失是否应受法律追责，以及公共监控系统的隐私边界问题。

多数用户对Flock的安全管理能力表示强烈质疑，认为其以“安全”为名侵犯隐私的行为存在根本性矛盾。有用户指出该公司曾公开宣称“从未被黑客入侵”，但此次事件暴露其安全声明可能不实。同时，社区普遍认为此类企业违规行为缺乏法律后果，有人呼吁应通过罚款或刑事指控追责。

讨论中呈现明显分歧：部分用户主张公共摄像头数据应完全公开以接受监督，也有用户分享通过技术手段干扰车牌识别系统的实验，但提醒需注意合法性。另有用户对报道证据提出质疑，认为部分截图可能只是客户端代码而非实际密钥泄露。此外，有评论批评讨论偏向情绪化指责而缺乏实质分析。

整体上，社区形成两点共识：一是对企业监控权力扩张的警惕，二是对安全漏洞法律追责机制缺失的不满。

comments.author: bcrl
comments.content: Security for maps is basically impossible.  Maps tend to have to be widely shared within government and engineering, and if you know what you're looking for, it's remarkably straightforward to find ways to access layers you would normally have to pay for.  It's a consequence of the need to share data widely for a variety of purposes -- everything from zoning debates within a local county to maps for broadband funding across an entire country create a public need to share mapping information.  Keys don't get revoked once projects end as that would result in all the previously published links becoming stale, which makes life harder for everyone doing research and planning new projects.Moreover, university students in programs like architecture are given access to many map layers as part of the school's agreements with the organizations publishing the data.  Without that access, students wouldn't be able to pick up the skills needed to do the work they will eventually be hired for.  And if students can get data, then it's pretty much public.Privacy is becoming (or already is) nearly impossible in the 21st century.

posts.title: New information extracted from Snowden PDFs through metadata version analysis
posts.author: libroot
posts.title_cn: 通过元数据版本分析从斯诺登PDF文件中提取的新信息
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕斯诺登PDF文件通过元数据分析提取新信息的技术发现展开。核心话题是PDF文件的“增量更新”特性如何导致早期版本信息意外留存，以及这对文档安全的影响。有人认为这解锁了新的开源情报技能，并指出用文本编辑器搜索“%%EOF”标记即可提取历史版本。也有用户指出需要更好的PDF检测工具，建议为qpdf等工具开发图形界面。讨论中提到记者对删除相关调查章节未作回应，引发对编辑决策的质疑。在技术原理方面，用户对PDF是否存储完整版本历史或差异数据存在疑问。同时，有观点认为打印并重新扫描纸质文件为图像PDF能有效保护信息，而另一些用户则质疑文件中可能混入旨在传播虚假信息的伪造文档。共识在于PDF的增量更新功能可能带来安全隐患，但对其具体机制和防护方法的理解仍存在分歧。

comments.author: layer8
comments.content: These PDFs apparently used the “incremental update” feature of PDF, where edits to the document are merely appended to the original file.It’s easy to extract the earlier versions, for example with a plain text editor. Just search for lines starting with “%%EOF”, and truncate the file after that line. Voila, the resulting file is the respective earlier PDF version.(One exception is the first %%EOF in a so-called linearized PDF, which marks a pseudo-revision that is only there for technical reasons and isn’t a valid PDF file by itself.)
comments.content_cn: 这些PDF文件显然使用了PDF的“增量更新”功能，即对文档的编辑仅附加在原始文件之后。提取早期版本非常容易，例如使用纯文本编辑器即可。只需搜索以“%%EOF”开头的行，然后在该行之后截断文件。瞧，生成的文件就是对应的早期PDF版本。（一个例外是所谓的线性化PDF中的第一个%%EOF，它标记的是一个仅出于技术原因存在的伪修订版，本身并非有效的PDF文件。）

comments.author: aidos
comments.content:
You can replace objects in PDF documents. A PDF is mostly just a bunch of objects of different types so the readers know what to do with them. Each object has a numbered ID. I recommend mutool for decompressing the PDF so you can read it in a text editor:    mutool clean -d in.pdf out.pdf

If you look below you can see a Pages list (1 0 obj) that references (2 0 R) a Page (2 0 obj).    1 0 obj
    <<
      /Type /Pages
      /Count 1
      /Kids [ 2 0 R ]
    >>
    endobj

    2 0 obj
    <<
      /Type /Page
      /Contents 5 0 R
      ...
    >>
    endobj

Rather than editing the PDFs in place, it's possible to update these objects to overwrite them by appending a new "generation" of an object. Notice the 0 has been incremented to a 1 here. This allows leaving the original PDF intact while making edits.    1 1 obj
    <<
      /Type /Pages
      /Count 2
      /Kids [ 2 0 R 200 0 R ]
    >>
    endobj

You can have anything inside a PDF that you want really and it could be orphaned so a PDF reader never picks up on it. There's nothing to say an object needs to be referenced (oh, there's a "trailer" at the end of the PDF that says where the Root node is, so they know where to start).
comments.content_cn:
您可以替换PDF文档中的对象。PDF本质上就是一堆不同类型的对象，阅读器知道如何处理它们。每个对象都有编号ID。我推荐使用mutool解压PDF，以便在文本编辑器中查看：mutool clean -d in.pdf out.pdf

往下看可以看到一个页面列表（1 0 obj），它引用了（2 0 R）一个页面对象（2 0 obj）。1 0 obj
<<
  /Type /Pages
  /Count 1
  /Kids [ 2 0 R ]
>>
endobj

2 0 obj
<<
  /Type /Page
  /Contents 5 0 R
  ...
>>
endobj

与其直接编辑PDF文件，可以通过追加对象的新“代次”来更新这些对象以实现覆盖。注意这里的0已递增为1。这样可以在保留原始PDF完整性的同时进行编辑。1 1 obj
<<
  /Type /Pages
  /Count 2
  /Kids [ 2 0 R 200 0 R ]
>>
endobj

您可以在PDF中放置任何内容，这些内容可能成为孤立对象，因此PDF阅读器永远不会识别它们。并没有规定对象必须被引用（哦，PDF末尾有一个“尾部”说明根节点的位置，这样阅读器就知道从哪里开始解析）。

I don't think that it yields information that can't  otherwise be pointed out and made mention of by others; presumably known and reputable. With as high-profile of an event that this is I'd expect someone covering it almost 16 years later to tell us beyond what when judged on the merit of its import amounts to a motivated section of the ‘Snowden disclosures’ Wikipedia entry.The discussion that this series invites typically is centered around people's thoughts about the story of the Snowden documents in general, and in this case exchanges about technical aspects like how PDF documents work and can be manipulated in general. The one comment that I feel addresses the actual tension embedded in the article—"Who edited the documents?"—leads to accusations that the documents were tampered with by the media: <https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46566372>. I don't think that that's an implausible claim but I find issue with it being made with such confidence by the anonymous source behind the investigations (I'm withholding ironically putting "investigations" in...nevermind).If the author actually provided something that advanced to the reader why this information is significant, what to do with or think about it and how they came about discovering the answers to the aforementioned 'why' and ‘what’ and additionally why they’re word ought to matter to us at all, I'd be less inclined to speculate that this is just someone vibe sleuthing their way through documents that on the surface are only significant to the public as the claim "the government is spying on you" is.This particular post uncovers some nice information. It's a great find. I'm in no position to investigate whether it was already known. But what are we supposed to learn from it aside from "one of the documents were changed before it was made public". What's significant about the redaction? Is Ryan Gallagher responsible? Or does he know who is. Is he at all obliged to explain this to a presumably anonymous inquirer? Or is it now the duty of the public to expect an explanation as affected by said anonymous inquirer?Remember when believing that the government was rife with pedophiles automatically associated you with horn-helmet-wearing insurrectionists?

comments.content: I don’t think this was particularly modeled on MS Word. The incremental update feature was introduced with PDF 1.2 in 1996. posts.title: How your high school affects your chances of UC Admission
posts.author: mutator
posts.title_cn: 高中背景如何影响你被加州大学录取的机会
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕加州大学（UC）录取过程中高中背景的影响展开。核心争议在于录取标准是否公平透明，以及不同学校类型（公立/私立）和地域（州内/州外）的申请者是否受到不同对待。

有用户指出，数据显示旧金山公立高中的录取率差异显著，可能与学校种族构成有关，这引发了关于平权行动的讨论。也有用户认为私立学校学生虽资源丰富，但录取率反而低于公立学校，这种结果较为合理。讨论中提到，UC官方强调会结合学生所在高中的背景评估其努力程度，但录取过程的不透明性遭到批评，有观点认为这种模糊性可能是刻意设计。

关于录取标准，有用户质疑UC是否真的仅依据成绩录取，因为文章提到UCSD采取“无视考试成绩”政策后，高中背景的权重明显增加。此外，有用户指出学校可能存在“选择性录取”倾向，即拒绝可能选择其他名校的优秀申请者以提升自身排名数据。讨论中普遍认同地域因素（如本地申请者更积极申请）可能影响录取率，但具体数据有待进一步分析。

comments.author: Madmallard
comments.content: Are Universities still good? They're good socially but for education in the age of AI I can't imagine university even being worth it anymore outside of the absolutely most prestigious ones there are.Certainly not your run-of-the-mill UC school except maybe UCLA or Berkeley and only then for very specific majors.I went to a UC and graduated 14 years ago. I basically had to teach myself everything with the other students once I got into my major. And this school has done notable research in my field. But the quality of education was just terrible. Nobody could teach us multi-threading, compilers, theory of computation, networking, or algorithms properly. Like not at all. The students had to help each other the best they can and the most experienced or smartest individuals were just the ones that actually were able to do those subjects competently. But everyone else was pretty much shorted on their education, just like the poor math education throughout the country. It's pretty irritating how much it costs versus the quality you get. No way is it worth it.And since I've graduated I learned that none of these topics is IQ-limited at all whatsoever. Math is completely intuitively if taught properly. ANYONE can learn it to a high level with good analogies and demonstrations and applicative knowledge. I developed competence with linear algebra and vector math not in school but doing game programming after I graduated. That's what actually made it "make sense".I tutored several students since I graduated and I think I helped them for $30 an hour learning fundamentals and how to program and I think I did a significantly better job one-on-one for these students at a way cheaper rate than they would have to pay in school. It's sad.I imagine LLMs could do a better job for many things than research professors that just throw slides on the board and barely elaborate on anything. The only way you learn in those courses is by really struggling on your own and going to as many office hours and TA hours as possible.
comments.content_cn:
大学还有价值吗？社交层面或许不错，但在人工智能时代，除了最顶尖的几所名校，我很难想象大学教育还值得投入。普通水平的加州大学分校恐怕不值一提——或许UCLA或伯克利除外，而且仅限于特定专业。我14年前从一所加州大学毕业，进入专业课后基本上都是和同学自学。这所学校在我的领域虽有知名研究，但教学质量实在糟糕：没人能系统讲授多线程、编译器、计算理论、网络或算法课程，完全靠学生互相帮扶，只有经验最丰富或最聪明的人能真正掌握这些内容。其他人都像全美糟糕的数学教育缩影一样被耽误了。高昂的学费与低劣的质量对比令人愤慨，根本不值得。

毕业后我意识到这些学科根本不需要高智商。数学本可通过恰当教学变得直观——只要运用恰当的类比、演示和应用知识，任何人都能精通。我真正掌握线性代数和向量运算不是在课堂，而是毕业后通过游戏编程实践才“豁然开朗”。我曾辅导过多名学生……

posts.title: Drones that recharge directly on transmission lines
posts.author: alphabetatango
posts.title_cn: 可直接在输电线上充电的无人机
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕“无人机直接在输电线上充电”这一技术展开。核心话题是此项技术的潜在应用场景及其引发的法律与伦理争议。多数用户认为该技术具有实用价值，特别是在电力巡检和军事侦察领域，例如无人机可借助输电线长时间悬停并回传数据。但也有用户指出这可能带来安全隐患，如非法窃电或恶意滥用。讨论中提到，部分用户担心电力公司如何向无人机运营商收取电费，认为监管机制尚不明确。同时，有用户联想到“鸟类非真实”的阴谋论，以幽默方式表达对监控技术泛滥的忧虑。整体而言，社区虽认可技术创新，但普遍对潜在滥用风险和法律空白表示关注。

comments.author: dgacmu
comments.content: We do semi-automated analysis of imagery of things like utility right-of-ways and it's pretty scalable. We triage the vast majority of images automatically and then surface a small subset to human experts to review, but it's much, much faster than having the experts be in the field, while having high coverage. (Most images are really boring.)And in most cases of inspection, you need to look at the stuff anyway, so any cost reduction is very welcome. And if you do increase the total coverage volume while reducing human time, you get a double benefit of being able to provide more granular information, either in time or in space, which can often be useful.(And as a commenter below notes - this all works pretty well with several year old CNNs. We use a limited amount of image-LLM stuff to surface things zero-shot, but a lot of what we end up doing is a very conventional classifier with a lot of engineering work to make it very fast for the experts to see only the important things.)
comments.content_cn:
我们对电力线路等公用事业通道图像进行半自动化分析，这种方法具有相当强的可扩展性。系统自动完成绝大多数图像的初步筛选，仅将少量可疑图像提交给人类专家复核。相比专家实地勘察，这种方式在保证高覆盖面的同时大幅提升了效率——毕竟大多数图像内容其实相当单调。在多数巡检场景中，人工核查本就不可避免，因此任何成本削减都备受青睐。若能在减少人工时间的同时扩大总体检测范围，更能获得双重效益：无论是时间维度还是空间维度，都能提供更精细化的数据信息，这些数据往往具有重要价值。

正如某位评论者所言，这套系统即使用数年前的卷积神经网络也能良好运行。我们确实会运用少量图像大语言模型技术进行零样本检测，但最终大量工作仍依赖于经过深度工程优化的传统分类器——其核心设计目标就是让专家能快速聚焦关键信息。

comments.content:
The prototype in the linked video was first tested back in 2023, and since then a few startups have set their sights on the technology (e.g. Nomadic Drones and Voltair). 
When working on the linked prototype we ran into some fundamental issues. Firstly, the recharging will only work with AC lines, and there's currently a lot of hype around UHVDC lines which are not compatible. Secondly, the AC lines must carry substantial current (ideally thousands of amps) for the recharging to not take forever. You can of course carry a much larger transformer on the drone to compensate, but this will in turn severely limit your flight time (ours was 1kg on a drone of 4.5kg and we could charge with 50W from 300A line current). You also have to account for significant daily fluctuations in the line current. It'll be interesting to see how the tech evolves, and I'll definitely be following these startups closely.

posts.author: hhs
posts.title_cn: 研究显示：过去十年私募股权公司收购逾500家自闭症治疗中心
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕私募股权公司大量收购自闭症治疗中心的现象展开。核心争议在于私募资本进入医疗领域是否损害服务质量。多数用户持批评态度，认为私募股权以逐利为导向，导致服务降级和费用上涨。有用户列举兽医、牙科等多个被私募“毁掉”的服务行业，指出非私募机构体验更好。也有用户结合亲身经历，抱怨治疗中心质量低下且浪费金钱。讨论中提到，私募控股的医院和养老院已有研究证实其死亡率更高，引发对医疗设施允许私募运营的质疑。针对解决方案，有建议要求患者服务机构成为公益企业，并在董事会纳入医护和患者代表。不过，也有用户质疑所有权形式的根本差异，询问相比其他所有者，私募是否特别有害。整体共识是私募参与普遍对消费者不利，但对其具体影响程度及替代方案仍有分歧。

posts.title: Greenland sharks maintain vision for centuries through DNA repair mechanism
posts.author: pseudolus
posts.title_cn: 格陵兰鲨通过DNA修复机制维持视力数百年。
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕格陵兰鲨鱼通过DNA修复机制保持数百年视力这一研究发现展开。核心话题是鲨鱼的长寿命与独特生理机制，以及相关研究的伦理问题。

社区观点多元：有人认为鲨鱼作为演化成功的典范令人惊叹，其四亿年基本不变的生物学特征展现了完美的环境适应；也有用户指出文章内容与标题关联较弱，缺乏具体科学细节的深入说明；讨论中还提到研究涉及的伦理争议，包括如何获取鲨鱼眼球样本以及人类是否应该追求类似的长生不老技术——部分用户担忧权力者若永生可能阻碍社会进步。

普遍共识是格陵兰鲨鱼作为能存活400年的生物确实非凡，但对其眼部寄生虫共生现象也存在科学关注。分歧主要集中于对研究方法的伦理性质疑，以及对人类应用此类长寿技术的不同社会构想。

posts.title: RTX 5090 and Raspberry Pi: Can it game?
posts.author: scottjg
posts.title_cn: RTX 5090与树莓派：它能玩游戏吗？
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕“RTX 5090与树莓派能否运行游戏”这一实验性项目展开。核心话题是探讨在树莓派这类单板计算机上外接高端显卡的实际性能与意义。

社区观点多元。有人认为这更多是技术可行性的验证，赞赏其“能够实现”本身比预期更出色；也有用户指出CPU是主要瓶颈，即使搭配RTX 5090，性能也可能与低端显卡相近，因此高端显卡在此场景下价值有限。讨论中提到，树莓派SoC本身GPU占比较大，此举颇有“小马拉大车”的趣味性。

部分用户对技术实现表示惊讶，例如FEX模拟层与eGPU的协作竟能运行现代游戏；另有观点从实用角度出发，认为树莓派搭配配件后性价比已不如x86迷你主机或二手瘦客户端，不适合常规桌面用途。

共识在于，实验证明了技术可行性，但普遍认同性能受CPU严重制约，高端显卡优势难以发挥。分歧主要体现在对此项目价值的判断：一方看重其技术探索意义，另一方则强调实际应用中的性价比不足。

You essentially just added an ethernet port to a 5090, there must be some value in that.

comments.author: gjsman-1000
comments.content: Denuvo isn’t quite DRM either. It’s an anti-tamper layer; the whole goal being to prevent the binary from modifications. This then prevents the DRM of choice (ie Steamworks) from being bypassed.I know that sounds a little pedantic; but typically DRM involves an identity layer (who is allowed to access what?). Denuvo doesn’t care about that; it’s even theoretically possible to make a Denuvo protected binary anyone could use.
comments.content_cn: Denuvo严格来说也不算数字版权管理技术。它实际上是一层防篡改保护层，其核心目标是阻止对程序二进制文件的修改。这样一来，就能防止用户绕过所选择的数字版权管理系统（例如Steamworks）。我知道这种说法可能有些咬文嚼字，但通常数字版权管理会包含身份验证层（即确定谁有权访问哪些内容）。Denuvo并不涉及这部分功能，理论上甚至可能制作出任何人都能使用的、受Denuvo保护的二进制文件。

posts.title: NASA announces unprecedented return of sick ISS astronaut and crew
posts.author: bookofjoe
posts.title_cn: NASA宣布患病国际空间站宇航员及机组人员史无前例的紧急返回
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕NASA紧急撤离国际空间站患病宇航员的事件展开。核心话题涉及太空医疗应急机制及任务透明度。多数用户对宇航员安全返回表示欣慰，并认可太空任务对人员心理素质的严苛筛选。

讨论中产生明显分歧：部分用户强调公众知情权，认为耗资巨大的太空项目应保持透明，有助于从医疗事件中积累经验；也有用户指出医疗隐私与科研机密需平衡，且宇航员已通过长期隔离降低传染病风险。技术层面，用户补充了返回舱运作原理及具体返航时间表，同时提及历史上阿波罗任务曾出现感冒传播的案例，但认为本次情况不同。

共识在于肯定NASA的应急响应能力，但关于信息披露程度的争议持续存在，反映出公众对太空探索项目监督与隐私保护的双重期待。

comments.author: heyflyguy
comments.content: It's great we can bring them down. What a terrifying experience to have a medical issue on the space station. Kidney stone? Ruptured appendix? intestinal blockage? How could you keep calm so far away!
comments.content_cn: 能把他们带回来真是太好了。在空间站上出现医疗问题是多么可怕的经历啊。肾结石？阑尾破裂？肠梗阻？在那么远的地方你怎么能保持冷静！

comments.content_cn: 美国宇航局有没有说他们什么时候回来？文章没提这点。还应该提到美国宇航局正试图提前发射第12批宇航员，以填补部分空白期。

comments.author: nubg
comments.content: Why be so secretive? This is not a military mission. These missions cost a lot of taxpayer money (money well spend you may argue), but we deserve full transparency. You don't get to go to space on other people's money and expect privacy. We might want to learn from what went wrong here.
comments.content_cn: 为何如此神秘？这又不是军事任务。这些任务花费了大量纳税人的钱（你可能会说这钱花得值），但我们理应享有完全的透明度。你不能用别人的钱上太空还指望保有隐私。我们或许应该从这次的问题中吸取教训。

comments.content_cn: 关于返回舱工作原理的文章：https://www.bbc.com/news/science-environment-52840482

comments.author: Aurornis
comments.content: What difference would this make to you? It would unnecessarily violate someone’s medical privacy for no actual benefit to the public other than satisfying someone’s curiosity.> You don't get to go to space on other people's money and expect privacy.Yes, everyone gets privacy. You don’t get to see their private communications back home. You don’t get their medical records.They aren’t receiving money from taxpayers like a gift. They’re doing a job. It’s ridiculous to demand that they forfeit their privacy because tax money was involved.> We might want to learn from what went wrong here.NASA will learn what went wrong here because they’re in a position to act onYou are not in a position to do anything about it. Violating their privacy would make no difference.
comments.content_cn: 这对你有什么影响？这只会毫无必要地侵犯他人的医疗隐私，除了满足某些人的好奇心外，对公众没有任何实际好处。> 你不能用别人的钱去太空还指望有隐私。是的，每个人都有隐私权。你不能查看他们与家人的私人通讯，也不能获取他们的医疗记录。他们不是像接受礼物一样从纳税人那里拿钱，他们是在工作。仅仅因为涉及税款就要求他们放弃隐私是荒谬的。> 我们或许想从这次事故中吸取教训。NASA会吸取教训，因为他们有能力采取行动。你对此无能为力。侵犯他们的隐私不会有任何改变。

comments.author: NooneAtAll3
comments.content: whatever is the cause, it is not immediate - or they would've been on the ground couple days agoso no, not appendix
comments.content_cn: 无论原因是什么，都不是急性的——否则他们几天前就该倒下了。所以不，不是阑尾炎。

comments.author: bryant
comments.content: > Why be so secretive? This is not a military mission. These missions cost a lot of taxpayer money (money well spend you may argue), but we deserve full transparency.We deserve as much transparency as we can get on the science we as taxpayers paid for, not full de-anonymization of the bodily happenings of living crew. There's certainly valuable science here, but the crew member doesn't have to be outed for it.> You don't get to go to space on other people's money and expect privacy.I don't think this is a healthy mindset, and there's a heck of a slippery slope with this argument. Would we apply this to companies receiving federal grants too? Contractors? Universities? Schools? That's a lot of people who'll lose medical privacy for something probably unrelated to their job, and there'll be a much smaller applicant pool for the jobs themselves if applicants are aware that their own internal issues might be disclosed when the public clamors for it.> We might want to learn from what went wrong here.Agree, NASA certainly will, and new science and engineering will come of it that we benefit from. But that doesn't have to involve breaching medical privacy and ethics.
comments.content_cn:
为何要如此遮遮掩掩？这又不是军事任务。这些任务耗费了大量纳税人的钱（你或许会说这钱花得值），但我们理应获得充分的透明度。我们作为纳税人资助的科学项目应当尽可能公开透明，但这不意味着要完全公开宇航员的身体隐私。这里当然有宝贵的科学价值，但不必为此暴露宇航员的个人隐私。

你不能用别人的钱上太空还指望保有隐私。我认为这种心态并不健康，这种论调极易导致滑坡效应。难道我们也要这样对待获得联邦拨款的公司吗？承包商呢？大学呢？中小学呢？这将导致许多人因与工作无关的原因失去医疗隐私，如果申请者知道公众一旦要求就可能披露他们的个人健康问题，这些职位本身的申请者数量将大幅减少。

我们或许应该从这次事故中吸取教训。同意，NASA肯定会这样做，新的科学和工程成果将使我们受益。但这并不需要以侵犯医疗隐私和伦理道德为代价。

They've pretty much accepted a risk of death that most would simply not tolerate. Ex-military is common for astronauts for a reason.

comments.author: AIorNot
comments.content: I used to work in ISS mission control, this is not an emergency return but an early returnAlso coming down on the Soyuz is pretty routine and only takes a few hours- I’d say it was overall a far less risky situation than being in Antarctic on a deep ocean vessel with appendicitis etcWe have dozens and (hundreds behind them) of men and women monitoring those folks from a global network of control centers 24 hrs a day- The station is mostly commanded from the ground and plans and procedures exist for everything- if anything its all over orchestrated and over-planned in my opinion, owing to national politics, corporate contracts and international bureaucracyIs it risky- yes obviously-but I’d argue its less risky then being out at the south pole in winterSee: https://nasawatch.com/iss-news/crew-medical-telecon-summary/
comments.content_cn: 我曾在国际空间站任务控制中心工作，这并非紧急返回而是提前返回。乘坐联盟号返回舱降落其实相当常规，只需几小时——我认为总体风险远低于在南极洲深海船只上突发阑尾炎等情况。我们拥有全球控制中心网络，每天24小时有数十名（背后还有数百名）工作人员监控宇航员状态。空间站主要受地面指挥，所有情况都有既定计划和流程。在我看来，由于国家政治、企业合同和国际官僚体系的影响，整个流程甚至存在过度编排和过度规划的情况。是否存在风险？显然是的——但我认为这比冬季在南极洲执行任务的风险更低。

comments.author: gpm

comments.author: perihelions
comments.content: Without taking a side, I'll share the interesting detail that NASA did not historically grant much medical privacy to astronauts. comments.content_cn: 不站任何立场，我只想分享一个有趣的细节：美国宇航局历史上并未给予宇航员太多医疗隐私。你可以在这里阅读阿波罗-联盟号机组人员的医疗报告（记录了他们在执行任务期间因有毒火箭燃料四氧化二氮中毒的情况），https://ntrs.nasa.gov/citations/19770023791（《阿波罗-联盟号测试计划：医疗报告》（1977年））

comments.author: daeken

comments.author: ssl-3

comments.author: trebligdivad

comments.author: bryant
comments.content: Since this is a special publication and since it was published in 1977 (after the Privacy Act of 1974), I'm wondering if NASA's condition for astronauts on this mission was to release mission-related medical science to the public.Speculating:If this is a condition of employment as an astronaut, then it probably wouldn't include conditions confirmed not to be caused by being in space, which means this'll stay confidential until NASA has fully diagnosed the crew member and figured out what likely happened.And if it turns out the crew member's issue was entirely unrelated to the mission, it stays under wraps but new science or procedures are devised to better manage this and related conditions in space.
comments.content_cn: 鉴于这是一份特殊出版物，且发布于1977年（在1974年《隐私法案》之后），我猜想NASA对此任务宇航员的要求之一可能是向公众公开与任务相关的医学数据。推测：若将此作为宇航员的聘用条件，那么很可能不包括那些已确认与太空环境无关的病症，这意味着相关信息将保密至NASA完成对机组人员的全面诊断并明确可能原因。如果最终确认机组人员的问题与任务完全无关，则相关内容仍将保密，但会据此制定新的科学方案或操作流程，以更好地处理太空环境中的此类及相关病症。

comments.author: mapmeld
comments.content: Especially since every movement up and down from space is expensive and risks the life of the crew, it'd be a bad idea for NASA to name the astronaut ahead of time.

comments.author: okdood64

posts.title: How to store a chess position in 26 bytes (2022)
posts.author: kurinikku
posts.title_cn: 如何用26字节存储一个棋局（2022）
posts.abstract:
该帖子讨论了如何在26字节内存储国际象棋棋局位置的技术方案。核心争议点在于这种压缩表示是否能完整记录棋局状态以支持合法走法生成。

有人认为这种编码方式无法完全捕获重复和棋所需的历史信息，因此不能准确决定所有可能走法。也有用户指出26字节（208位）实际上超过了最小编码需求，理论上96位就足够记录包含吃过路兵和王车易位信息的完整棋局。讨论中提到，通过优化棋子编码（如象只需5位）可以实现26字节的目标。

普遍认同的是，这个问题有助于思考棋盘状态总数的上限，从而评估解决国际象棋问题的计算复杂度。分歧主要在于对“完整棋局”的定义：部分用户坚持必须包含所有历史信息才能生成合法走法，而另一些则认为基础编码已足够描述当前局面。

comments.author: btilly
comments.content: Either we have to say that the position does not dictate the possible moves, or that this does not fully capture the position. The problem here is that drawing can become an option or a requirement based on information that this representation doesn't capture.First the simpler version of this problem. After 50 full moves without a capture or pawn move, a draw MAY be claimed. After 75 moves, a draw MUST be claimed. This requires a count to be kept that may require up to 7 more bits.The bigger problem is draw by repetition. If a position repeats exactly (same castling and en passant options) for a third time, then a draw MAY be claimed. If it repeats exactly for a fifth time, then a draw MUST be claimed. (Usually it is claimed on the third time, but you don't have to.) Applying this rule correctly requires not just knowing the current position, but what positions have occurred previously, and how often. Back to the last pawn move, capture, or change in potential castling status. This may require (per the first rule) knowing what up to 75 different past positions were.The best way to store this history is almost certainly not as a list of positions, but as a history of moves. But, even if done efficiently, we will need more bytes for that history than we needed for the position.
comments.content_cn:
我们要么必须承认棋子的位置并不能完全决定可能的走法，要么承认这种表示方式未能全面捕捉棋局状态。这里的问题在于，和棋可能成为一种选择或必然要求，而这取决于当前表示法未能涵盖的信息。

首先来看这个问题的简化版本。在连续50个完整回合中没有发生吃子或兵的行进时，一方可以要求和棋。当达到75回合时，则必须宣布和棋。这需要设置一个计数器，可能需要额外7个比特位来记录。

更大的问题在于重复局面的和棋规则。如果完全相同的局面（包括王车易位和吃过路兵的权利）第三次出现，一方可以要求和棋。如果第五次出现相同局面，则必须宣布和棋。（通常第三次出现时就会提和，但并非强制要求。）正确应用这条规则不仅需要知道当前局面，还需要了解之前出现过的局面及其重复次数。这需要回溯到上一次兵的行进、吃子或王车易位权利发生变化的时刻。根据第一条规则，可能需要记录多达75个不同的历史局面。

存储这种历史信息的最佳方式几乎肯定不是记录局面列表，而是记录行棋历史。但即使采用高效的方法，记录历史所需的数据量也会超过记录单个局面所需的数据量。

comments.author: arnsholt
comments.content: Lichess uses a scheme which is probably more efficient on average, described on revoof's blog[0]. Basically, it's a variable length scheme where the first 64 bits encode square occupancies, followed by piece codes (including castling, side to move, and ep with some trickery), followed by half-move clocks if necessary.0: https://lichess.org/@/revoof/blog/adapting-nnue-pytorchs-bin...
comments.content_cn: Lichess采用了一种平均效率可能更高的方案，该方案在revoof的博客[0]中有详细描述。本质上，这是一种可变长度编码方案：前64位编码棋盘格子的占用状态，随后是棋子代码（包含王车易位、行棋方和吃过路兵等特殊情况的巧妙处理），最后在必要时附加半回合计数信息。

comments.author: pklausler
comments.content: 26 bytes is 208 bits, about twice what you really need for a minimal encoding that has enough context (en passant, castling) to generate an accurate set of legal moves.  I wrote a chess database tool back in the 90's (CDB) that used 96-bit encodings (if memory serves) to index all the positions reached in a collection of games so that one could see the moves made from any position, their frequencies, and their game outcomes.  Good fun.
comments.content_cn: 26字节等于208比特，大约是生成准确合法走法所需最小编码（包含过路兵、王车易位等完整上下文信息）的两倍。我在90年代开发过一个国际象棋数据库工具（CDB），采用96比特编码（如果没记错的话）来索引对局集合中出现的所有棋局，从而能够查看任意局面下的走法、出现频率及其对局结果。那段经历非常有趣。

comments.author: jstanley
comments.content: > Since each position takes up 6 bits ($2^6 = 64$), multiplying 6 bits by 32 pieces gives us 192 bits / 24 bytes (1 byte = 8 bits).But each position can only be used once, so you really only have 64*63*62*61*...*33 possibilities = 64!/32! = ~2^53, so you could encode this with less than 7 bytes, and then use the basic 12-byte encoding for captures, castling, en-passant, and promotions, and you are below 19 bytes in total. (Did I miscalculate this?)Also pawns can never be on the 1st or 8th rank so you can subtract those possibilities from each of the numbers that represents a pawn.You also don't care about the order of bishops, rooks, knights, and especially pawns - so you should be able to do even better.
comments.content_cn: 由于每个位置占用6比特（2^6=64），6比特乘以32个棋子得到192比特/24字节（1字节=8比特）。但每个位置只能使用一次，因此实际可能性仅为64*63*62*61*...*33 = 64!/32! ≈ 2^53，这意味着可以用少于7字节进行编码，再使用12字节基础编码处理吃子、王车易位、过路兵和升变规则，总占用可控制在19字节以内。（我是否计算有误？）此外，兵永远不可能出现在第1或第8横线，因此可以从代表兵的每个数字中排除这些位置。同时，象、车、马尤其是兵的排列顺序无关紧要——这意味着编码效率还能进一步优化。

comments.author: Smalltalker-80
comments.content:
Why not do it simpler? :
Create an array with 16 elements, one element per piece, black + white.
Every array element is 7 bits wide, 1 bit for captured or not,
and 6 bits for the square number the piece is on (8 x 8).
Then you need 16 * 7 = 112 bits = 14 bytes.
(And the captured-bit can even be compressed further as a 65th square,
but that makes it more calculation intensive to extract a position)
comments.content_cn:
为什么不采用更简单的方法呢？：
创建一个包含16个元素的数组，每个元素对应一个棋子（黑方+白方）。
每个数组元素宽度为7位，其中1位表示是否被吃，
另外6位表示棋子所在的方格编号（8x8棋盘）。
这样总共需要16 * 7 = 112位 = 14字节。
（甚至可以将“被吃”状态进一步压缩为第65个方格，
但这会增加提取位置时的计算复杂度）

comments.content:
I remember asking myself this question years ago, and came to 162 bits. I was just a kid back then so the logic is probably wrong but I do wonder how simple the encoding could be under those constraints...Edit: Here are the Notes0 Empty10 Pawn1100 Knight1101 Rook1110 Bishop1111 Queen32 + 32 + 4722 times 6 bits: position of the kings30 bits: color mask120 + 2*6 + 30 = 162 bitsWe can store the rest using the methods from the blog post and add 18 bits for promotion, giving 180 bits.I'm sure this isn't the most efficient way, and I think I had other methods and considered things like the bishops being able to occupy 32 squares, though special casing doesn't make sense because of promotions.Technically if you got 8 bishops/queens/knights/rooks
You would occupy another 16 bits, giving 196 bitsI think the upper limit can be reduced at the cost of increasing the lower limitEDIT2: I think I made the assumption at the time that to promote one piece you needed to capture at least one enemy pawn, giving the space for the two bits, which means the upper bound is actually 180 bitsWould love to see other people try in the comment section
comments.content_cn:
记得多年前我也曾问过自己这个问题，当时得出的答案是162比特。那时我还是个孩子，逻辑可能有问题，但我确实好奇在这种限制下编码能简化到什么程度……编辑：以下是笔记

1100 马

comments.author: kazinator
comments.content: I would do it like this. There are 32 pieces, any of which may be missing. So let's use four bytes (32 bits) as a mask of what pieces are present. Then, coordinates can be given for each piece that is present. The board is 8x8, so coordinates can be encoded as pairs of 3 bits, e.g. A3 is 000:011.   The worst case is that we need 32 of these pairs, which requires 24 bytes. That brings us to a worst case of 28.How can we eliminate two bytes?We can more cleverly encode the mask so that two bytes are used to express the all-pieces-present, and certain other cases. A fully decoded mask is only used for boards that have too few pieces to break over 26 bytes.For instance suppose we have a two-bit header encoding several cases:00 - no piece are missing (32 six-bit coordinates follow)01 - one piece is missing, followed by 5 bit ID of that piece10 - two pieces are missing, followed by two 5 bit IDs of the two pieces11 - three or more pieces missing, full mask follows.In case 11, we need a 32 bit mask, followed by as many as 29 coordinate pairs.So 2 + 32 + 6 * 29 = 208 bits.And hey look, by dumb luck, 208 / 8 = 26.I will check the article later.
comments.content_cn:
我会这样处理。棋盘共有32个棋子，其中任意棋子都可能缺失。因此我们可以用四个字节（32位）作为掩码来表示哪些棋子存在。接着，为每个存在的棋子提供坐标。棋盘是8x8规格，所以坐标可以用两个3位二进制数编码，例如A3表示为000:011。最坏情况是需要32组坐标对，这需要24字节。这样最坏情况总共需要28字节。

如何能减少两个字节呢？我们可以更巧妙地编码掩码：用两个字节表示所有棋子都存在的情况，以及其他特定情况。完整解码的掩码仅用于棋子数量过少、无法突破26字节限制的棋盘。

例如，假设我们用两位头部编码几种情况：
00 - 没有棋子缺失（后接32个6位坐标）
01 - 缺失一个棋子，后接该棋子的5位标识符
10 - 缺失两个棋子，后接两个棋子的5位标识符
11 - 缺失三个或更多棋子，后接完整掩码。

在情况11中，我们需要一个32位掩码，后接最多29组坐标对。
这样总共是2 + 32 + 6 * 29 = 208位。
看，巧合的是，208 / 8 = 26字节。
稍后我会查看这篇文章。

comments.author: RiverCrochet
comments.content: The king can't be captured, so the capture bit for the kings can be used for something else.
comments.content_cn: 国王不能被捕获，因此国王的捕获位可用于其他用途。

comments.author: billforsternz
comments.content: I know of two distinct methods of encoding any legal chess position into 24 bytes worst case. In both cases, you get the full position, plus who to move, plus full information on future castling and en-passant possibilities. This is the FEN state of the board, minus the two counts. It's more than the information you get from a published chess diagram in a book or magazine. Although in a book or magazine inevitably "who to move" is represented somehow, castling and en-passant possibilities are not usually.Method 1: Lichess method; 64 bit header, 1 bit per square indicating occupied squares, then (up to) 32 4 bit codes for the 32 occupied squares. So 24 bytes worst case!Method 2: My own method a list of 2 bit codes, one of the 4 codes indicates empty square, the other three codes are prefixes for a second 2 bit code. Three prefixes applied to one of 4 code values gives a total of 12 possibilities corresponding to any possible chess piece. Worst case 32x2 bits plus 32x4 bits = 24 bytes.In each case there is sufficient entropy to create tricks to add the supplementary information (who to move etc.), similar tricks are in the original article.I mention my own method from my Tarrasch Chess GUI https://github.com/billforsternz/tarrasch-chess-gui only for completeness. If I had known about method 1 I would have used that, it is simpler and better and there is much more entropy available making the tricks easier.I would urge commentators to keep clear the difference between compressing a chess position (this challenge), a chess move and a chess game. A chess move needs far less bits of course. A complete chess game is always encoded as a list of moves, not positions, for this reason.Edit: I should have mentioned that the chief advantage of method 1 over method 2 is average bits required. An empty board is 64x1 bits = 8 bytes for method 1 and 64x2 bits = 16 bytes for method 2.Edit 2: I am going to describe my tricks, just because they are fun. Two kings the same colour means Black to move. Two White kings means the first king is white, two black kings means the first king is black. Otherwise White to move. A friendly pawn on the first rank means an enpassant vulnerable pawn. Swap it with the 4th rank square to get the actual contents of both squares. A hostile pawn on the first rank is an unmoved rook or king, establishing all castling rights. The castling and en-passant tricks can be combined in a pleasant and harmonious way.
comments.content_cn:
据我所知，有两种不同的方法可以在最坏情况下将任何合法的国际象棋局面编码为24字节。这两种方法都能提供完整的局面信息，包括当前行棋方、未来的王车易位可能性以及吃过路兵的全部信息。这相当于棋盘FEN状态减去两个计数项。它比书籍或杂志上发布的国际象棋图示所包含的信息更全面——尽管书刊中通常会以某种方式标注行棋方，但王车易位和吃过路兵的可能性通常不会明确标示。

方法一：Lichess采用的方法；使用64位头文件，每个方格用1位表示是否被占据，随后（最多）32个4位编码对应32个被占据方格。最坏情况下仅需24字节！

方法二：我自行设计的方法采用2位编码列表，四种编码之一表示空格，其余三种编码作为第二组2位编码的前缀。三种前缀与四种编码值组合可产生12种可能性，对应所有可能的棋子类型。最坏情况下32×2位加32×4位=24字节。

两种方法都具有足够的熵值空间来实现附加信息（行棋方等）的编码技巧，原文献中也有类似技巧。我提及自己为Tarrasch Chess GUI开发的方法（https://github.com/billforsternz/tarrasch-chess-gui）仅为保持论述完整性。若早知方法一的存在，我必然会采用该方案——它更简洁高效，且可利用的熵值空间更大，使编码技巧更易实现。

comments.author: untech
comments.content: This nerd-sniped me. I think we should separate "chess board" and "chess game state" as two different problems. For "chess board", we don't consider any castling, en-passant or similar. We might store a bit for "who goes next". This is useful for chess puzzles where state shenanigans are rare (I think).But if we store castling state, I think we are already trying to store the whole game state, and this is representable only by full history because of move repeating rules.So, I think storing board state as a sequence of moves is more interesting. I would estimate that a number of possible actions on average is closer to 8 than to 16, so it would give as 3 bits for half-move and 6 bits for full move. 24-move game could be represented with 18 bytes, which is considerably lower than 26 bytes!You can get close to average bit per move, if you reuse "spare" places for the next move. So, for instance, first move have 20 possibilities, which is representable by 5 bits, but you can reuse "spare" 32-20=12 possibilities as a bit for the next move.This is a representation assuming you use only "move validator" thing that returns a list of possible moves. I think that if you use a chess engine that would output you a probability distribution of possible moves, you can compress noticeably better on average, but decoding would be slow.
comments.content_cn:
这个难题让我陷入了深度思考。我认为应该把“棋盘状态”和“棋局状态”作为两个不同的问题来处理。对于“棋盘状态”，我们不需要考虑王车易位、吃过路兵等特殊规则，或许可以存储一个“当前行棋方”的标志位。这在棋局诡计较少见的象棋残局中应该很实用。

但如果我们存储王车易位状态，实际上就已经在尝试存储完整的棋局状态了——由于重复行棋规则的存在，这种状态只能通过完整行棋历史来记录。

因此我认为将棋盘状态存储为行棋序列更有意义。我估计平均每步可行棋数量更接近8步而非16步，这样半步行棋可用3比特表示，完整行棋用6比特。24步棋局仅需18字节即可表示，比26字节方案显著优化！

通过复用下一步棋的“空闲”编码空间，我们可以逼近每步棋的平均比特数。例如首步棋有20种可能，本需5比特表示，但我们可以将剩余的32-20=12种编码可能性作为下一步棋的存储空间复用。

这种编码方案的前提是使用“行棋验证器”来生成可行棋列表。我认为如果使用象棋引擎输出可能行棋的概率分布，平均压缩率还能显著提升，但解码速度会相应降低。
