posts.author: vismit2000
posts.title_cn: 计算机科学中的数学（2018）[pdf]
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕《计算机科学数学（2018）》PDF教材展开。核心话题是社区用户对这本经典教材的内容、结构及相关学习资源的评价与分享。

多数用户对教材表示高度认可，认为其内容扎实、讲解清晰，并提供了丰富的学习资源链接，如配套视频课程。有人认为书中引用回溯功能很实用，希望更多书籍采纳；也有用户称赞其幽默的表述方式，尽管内容难度较高但仍具启发性。

讨论中出现了几点分歧：有用户对第二章涉及良序原则表示惊讶，因其通常与集合论中的良序定理关联；也有用户指出教材未涵盖环形缓冲区正确性证明等具体计算机科学问题。此外，对于教材的篇幅存在不同看法，部分用户认为千页篇幅过于庞大，可能影响学习效率，而其他用户则强调其内容的全面性。

社区普遍认同该教材是计算机数学领域的优质资源，并自发补充了多种学习渠道。同时，有用户借此机会询问习题答案获取方式、屏幕阅读器推荐以及计算机科学必备书单，体现了对延伸学习支持的需求。

comments.content: re: Chapter 15.8 on the so-called pigeonhole principleFollowing Dijkstra’s EWD1094, here’s a way to solve the hairs-on-heads problem eschewing the language of pigeonholes and employing the fact that the mean is at most the maximum of a non-empty bag of numbers.We are given that Boston has 500,000 non-bald people. The human head has at most 200,000 hairs. Show that there must be at least 3 people in Boston who have the same number of hairs on their head.Each non-bald Bostonian must have a hair count between 1 and 200,000. The average number of such people per hair count is 500,000 / 200,000  = 2.5. The maximum is at least that; moreover, it must be a round number. So the maximum >= 3. QED.
comments.content_cn:
关于第15.8节所谓的鸽巢原理  
遵循迪杰斯特拉的EWD1094思路，这里提供一种解决"头上发量问题"的方法，该方法避免使用鸽巢术语，而是利用"非空数字集合的平均值不超过其最大值"这一性质。  
已知波士顿有50万非秃顶人口。人类头部最多有20万根头发。证明波士顿至少存在3人拥有完全相同的头发数量。  
每位非秃顶波士顿人的头发数量必然在1到20万之间。每个发量值对应人数的平均值为50万除以20万，即2.5。最大值至少等于该平均数；此外，该值必为整数。因此最大值≥3。证毕。

Apparently, elsewhere in mathematics, they've proven that even though it exists, you cannot articulate that ordering.There's a common joke:"The Axiom of Choice is obviously true, the well-ordering principle obviously false, and who can tell about Zorn's lemma?"
comments.content_cn: 良序原理、选择公理和佐恩引理都是“等价”的，这意味着你可以选择其中任何一个作为公理，并证明另外两个。因此，有些教科书可能选择其中一个作为公理，而其他教科书则选择不同的公理。关于良序原理的惊人之处在于：它声称实数集上存在一个良序，这意味着你可以找到一个排序，使得任何开集都有最小值。显然，在数学的其他领域，人们已经证明，尽管这种排序存在，但你无法明确描述它。有一个常见的笑话：“选择公理显然正确，良序原理显然错误，而佐恩引理谁能说得清呢？”

This is mathematics that Knuth needed for the rest of TAOCP.So it's more "mathematics for the analysis of algorithms" (incidentally the title of another book by Greene and co-authored by Knuth), and so probably most applicable to the field of "AofA" rather than physics or computer science in general.Lovely book, very few math books fill one with as much joy as this one.

posts.title: Open Chaos: A self-evolving open-source project
posts.author: stefanvdw1
posts.title_cn: 开放混沌：一个自我演进的开源项目
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕开源项目“Open Chaos”展开，这是一个通过社区投票自动演化代码的项目。核心话题在于探讨这种“自演化”开发模式的可行性与意义。

有人认为这类似游戏《Screeps》中玩家通过代码协作控制的体验，或是一种计算机辅助的“Nomic”规则博弈游戏。也有用户指出其本质类似“Twitch plays Github”的自动化版本，但过程更为开放。讨论中提到，许多投票最高的合并请求反而是为项目增加结构（如计票机制），这反映出社区在混乱中仍渴望一定秩序。

分歧点主要集中在项目价值上：部分用户期待它能产出实质性成果，甚至幽默地提及可能解决通用人工智能；另一些用户则质疑最终产物可能只是一个网站，缺乏实际意义。共识在于，这种模式体现了在LLM时代编程可能趋向艺术化与自动化结合的新形态，但进展速度（每周更新一次）和产出方向仍存在不确定性。

There's a Github App (which may not still work, but if there's interest I'll restart it) and a "run it yourself" python library and CLI you can run from Github Actions[4].1. https://screeps.com/2. https://github.com/ScreepsQuorum/screeps-quorum3. https://www.gitconsensus.com/4. https://pypi.org/project/gitconsensus/
comments.content_cn: 以前玩Screeps[1]（一款需要编程控制单位和建筑的MMO策略游戏）时，我们一群人建立了一个名为Quorum[2]的玩家，其管理方式正是如此。如果有人想以这种方式运作自己的项目，我已经在GitConsensus[3]项目中开源了相关代码。其中包含一个Github应用（可能已失效，但若有需求我会重启它），以及一个可通过Github Actions[4]运行的“自主运行”Python库和CLI工具。

posts.title: UK government exempting itself from cyber law inspires little confidence

posts.title_cn: 英国政府豁免自身遵守网络安全法引发信心不足
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕英国政府在新网络安全法案中豁免自身法律责任一事展开。用户普遍质疑这一豁免的正当性，认为这体现了“严以待人、宽以律己”的双重标准。有用户指出，政府辩称将通过“网络行动计划”自我约束，但这缺乏法律强制力，相当于空头承诺；也有用户认为，豁免可能出于避免自我审批、保护敏感信息等实际行政考量，但应通过更清晰的立法框架来规范。讨论中提到，类似现象在其他领域（如美国州政府不遵循地方建筑规范）也存在。部分用户强调，政府本身也是关键服务提供者，不应天然排除在监管之外。整体上，社区对政府自我豁免持批评态度，认为这会削弱法律公信力，并担忧其背后的威权倾向。

comments.author: dwroberts
comments.content: I think this is an overly cynical read on the whole thing, at least after skimming the main points from the bill.A lot of it is about designating critical suppliers + providers and their security obligations.Central government would typically be a customer, that uses other suppliers and providers to achieve its goals, not a supplier or a provider itself.So in that sense it doesn't seem so strange to see it omitted, or at least for first set of legislation etc.? Get the first party suppliers in shape first, then legislate the net result of government function using those suppliers etc.
comments.content_cn: 我认为这种解读对整个事件过于偏激，至少在我浏览了法案的主要内容后是这样看的。法案很多内容是关于指定关键供应商和服务提供商及其安全义务的。中央政府通常是客户方，通过其他供应商和服务商来实现其目标，而非自身充当供应商或服务商。因此从这个角度看，将其排除在外似乎并不奇怪，至少在第一轮立法中如此？先让第一方供应商规范起来，再针对政府使用这些供应商所产生的最终效果进行立法。

comments.author: Beretta_Vexee
comments.content: So there are legitimate reasons for doing this, such as avoiding having to write reports and request authorizations from oneself, not having to disclose certain sensitive information, etc.The right way to do this is to draft a framework law and a few decrees along the lines of “administrations XXX and YYY will apply NIS2 with the following exceptions and adaptations ....”This avoids creating overly broad exemptions, ensuring that there is a reference framework, and preventing each administration from developing its own system.This is very common in the arms and nuclear sectors, where many civil norms and standards clearly state “not applicable to nuclear” and the nuclear standard states “apply civil standard XXX, with the following specific provisions, the competent authority is the ONR.”Declaring an overly broad exemption from the outset is not the right way to go about it.
comments.content_cn: 因此，这样做存在合理理由，例如避免自行撰写报告和申请授权、无需披露某些敏感信息等。正确做法是起草一部框架性法律及若干法令，内容应遵循“XXX和YYY行政部门将适用NIS2指令，但存在以下例外情况和调整……”的思路。这种做法既能避免设立过于宽泛的豁免条款，确保存在参考框架，又可防止各部门自行建立独立体系。这在军工和核能领域十分常见——许多民用规范标准明确标注“不适用于核能领域”，而核能标准则规定“适用民用标准XXX，但需遵循以下特殊条款，主管机构为核监管办公室”。从一开始就宣布过于宽泛的豁免范围并非恰当的处理方式。

posts.title: JavaScript Demos in 140 Characters
posts.author: themanmaran
posts.title_cn: 140字符内的JavaScript演示
posts.abstract:
该HackerNews帖子讨论了Dwitter网站上的“140字符JavaScript演示”创作现象。核心话题是探讨在极端代码长度限制下，开发者如何创作出富有创意的生成艺术和动态视觉效果。

社区普遍赞赏这种创意形式，认为限制反而激发了多样性，有人指出这让人重拾对创造力的信心，也有用户联想到类似的代码高尔夫挑战。讨论中多次提到，许多作品依赖`eval(unescape(escape...))`技巧来绕过字符数限制，这引发了争议。部分用户认为这种做法类似作弊，削弱了挑战的本意，希望平台能禁止此类技巧或提供更多内置函数缩写以编写更可读的代码。另有用户思考是否存在既能保持创意又不陷入纯粹代码高尔夫或产生巨大文件的评判标准。

共识在于大家都认为这些演示非常酷且令人印象深刻，展现了社区的创造力。分歧主要围绕技术规则的公平性与代码的可读性，一方接受利用漏洞的“元游戏”，另一方则希望推动更清晰、规范的编码方式。

comments.author: amiga386
comments.content:
It's very cool, but it's also a shame that measuring in characters leads to the metagame of using 97 multi-byte Unicode characters that decode to 194 ASCII characters when reinterpreted. Almost everything is in the format:    eval(unescape(escape`<<97 wide characters>>`.replace(/u../g,'')))

Can't they just have the same agreement that Ford Prefect had with Mr Prosser? "So, assuming I'm going to use this lossless compression technique to fit 194 characters into a 140 character tweet... how about you just show the 194 characters and say that I fitted into 140 characters?"I suppose you could make the same argument about size-based competitions at demo parties; the limit is strictly 4096 bytes but everyone + their dog is using Crinkler to compress a 12-20KB executable down to that size. In fact, part of the effort is in aligning data and tweaking constants with Crinkler's algorithm in mind, to make the raw data more amenable to compression! But at least then, it's not a constant compression (turning any 194 ASCII characters into 97 Unicode characters which with embedded decoder makes exactly 140 characters)
comments.content_cn:
这确实很酷，但遗憾的是，以字符数作为衡量标准会引发一种策略游戏：人们使用97个多字节Unicode字符，这些字符在重新解释时会解码为194个ASCII字符。几乎所有的内容都采用这种格式：eval(unescape(escape`<<97个宽字符>>`.replace(/u../g,'')))  

难道他们不能像福特·普里弗克特和普罗瑟先生那样达成共识吗？“假设我要使用这种无损压缩技术将194个字符塞进一条140字符的推文……你干脆直接显示194个字符，然后说我成功塞进了140个字符，怎么样？”我想，对于演示派对上基于大小的比赛，你也可以提出同样的论点：严格限制是4096字节，但每个人（甚至他们的狗）都在使用Crinkler将12-20KB的可执行文件压缩到这个大小。事实上，部分努力在于根据Crinkler的算法调整数据和对齐常量，以使原始数据更容易压缩！但至少在这种情况下，压缩不是恒定的（将任意194个ASCII字符转换为97个Unicode字符，加上内嵌的解码器，正好是140个字符）。

comments.author: MORPHOICES
comments.content: Viewing sites like Dwitter always refreshes my confidence in creativity. ~You would expect severe restrictions to yield sameness. On the contrary, you receive untamed variety. Optical illusions. Modern sayings. People twisting the medium in unplanned directions.The trend I’ve noticed.Limits prevent uninvited focus.Constraints that we all share can become a shared language.A tiny scope reduces experimentation expenditure.When the area of surface is small, people penetrate deep instead of spread wide. They experiment with odd concepts since failing is inexpensive and quick.Unlike most platforms that add features to unlock creative potential, which actually ends up overwhelming it.A rule that I keep coming back to: if something feels playful, constraints are probably doing their job.Inquisitive.In what situations did restrictions lead to better outcomes?When do limitations start to seem fictitious?What contemporary instruments ought to be more limited?
comments.content_cn: 浏览像Dwitter这样的网站总能重燃我对创造力的信心。你或许以为严苛的限制会导致千篇一律，但事实恰恰相反，这里呈现的是无拘无束的多样性：视觉幻象、现代格言、人们以意料之外的方式重塑媒介——这是我观察到的趋势。限制能排除不必要的干扰，我们共同面对的约束反而能成为共享的语言。狭小的创作范围降低了试错成本，当表现空间有限时，人们会选择纵深挖掘而非横向铺陈，他们会尝试各种奇特构想，因为失败代价低廉且迅速。这与多数平台形成鲜明对比——那些平台试图通过增加功能来释放创意，结果往往适得其反。我始终坚信一个原则：当某件事物充满趣味性时，往往意味着限制正在发挥作用。这引发深思：在哪些情境下限制反而催生更优成果？限制何时会显得形同虚设？哪些当代工具本应施加更多约束？

comments.author: jsheard
comments.content: The compression tricks used in standalone Javascript demos are significantly more cursed. The meta is to concatenate a compressed binary payload and a HTML/JS decompression stub in the same file, abusing the fact that HTML5 parsers are required to be absurdly tolerant of malformed documents. Nowadays it's done using raw DEFLATE and DecompressionStream, but before that was available they would pack the payload into the pixels of a PNG and use Canvas to extract the data.Try saving this Normal HTML File and open it in a text/hex editor: https://0b5vr.com/domain/domain.html
comments.content_cn: 独立JavaScript演示中使用的压缩技巧要诡异得多。常见的做法是将压缩后的二进制载荷与HTML/JS解压缩存根拼接在同一文件中，这利用了HTML5解析器必须对畸形文档异常宽容的特性。如今人们使用原始DEFLATE和DecompressionStream实现，而在此之前，开发者会将载荷打包到PNG图像的像素中，再通过Canvas提取数据。你可以尝试保存这个普通HTML文件并用文本/十六进制编辑器打开：https://0b5vr.com/domain/domain.html

posts.title: Finding and fixing Ghostty's largest memory leak
posts.author: thorel
posts.title_cn: 发现并修复Ghostty的最大内存泄漏问题
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕Ghostty终端应用的内存泄漏修复展开。核心话题是开发者通过深入分析定位并解决了因滚动缓冲区管理不当导致的内存泄漏问题，相关技术细节在博客文章中有详细说明。

社区普遍赞赏开发团队的快速响应和详尽的技术分析，许多用户表示从中学到了有价值的调试方法。有人认为这类底层内存管理问题凸显了系统编程的复杂性，也有用户指出此类问题若使用Rust等内存安全语言可能更容易避免。讨论中提到部分用户对修复方案的实施时间有不同看法，有人期待立即发布补丁，而开发者计划将其纳入后续功能更新。此外，有用户对终端应用是否需要自定义内存分配器表示疑虑，同时也有技术性探讨涉及滚动缓冲区是否可采用环形缓冲区等替代设计。整体而言，社区肯定开发者的专业态度，但也在技术选型和问题预防方面存在不同观点。

comments.author: tialaramex
comments.content: The specific language feature you want if you insist that you don't want this kind of leak is Linear Types.Rust has Affine Types. This means Rust cares that for any value V of type T, Rust can see that we did not destroy V twice (or more often).With Linear Types the compiler checks that you destroyed V exactly once, not less and not more.However, one reason I don't end up caring about Leak Safety of this sort is that in fact users do not care that you didn't "leak" data in this nerd sense. In this nerd sense what matters is only leaks where we lost all reference to the heap data. But from a user's perspective it's just as bad if we did have the reference but we forgot - or even decided explicitly not - to throw it away and get back the RAM.The obvious way to make this mistake "by accident" in Rust is to have two things which keep each other alive via reference counting and yet have been disconnected and forgotten by the rest of the system. A typical garbage collected language would notice that these are garbage and destroy them both, but Rust isn't a GC language of course. Calling Box::leak isn't likely to happen by accident (though you might mistakenly believe you will call it only once but actually use it much more often)I think the main part of Ghostty's design mentioned here that - as a Rust programmer - I think is probably a mistake is the choice to use a linked list. To me this looks exactly like it needs VecDeque, a circular buffer backed by a growable array type. Their "clever" typical case where you emit more text and so your oldest page is scrapped and re-used to form your newest page, works very nicely in VecDeque, and it seems like they never want the esoteric fast things a linked list can do, nor do they need multi-writer concurrency like the guts of an OS kernel, they want O(1) pop & push from opposite ends. Zig's Deque is probably that same thing but in Zig.
comments.content_cn:
如果你坚持不希望出现这类内存泄漏，所需的具体语言特性是线性类型。Rust拥有仿射类型。这意味着Rust会确保对于类型T的任意值V，编译器能检测到我们没有重复销毁V（或多次销毁）。而线性类型要求编译器严格检查你恰好销毁V一次——既不能少也不能多。

不过，我最终不太在意这类内存泄漏安全性的一个原因是：实际上用户并不关心这种技术层面上的“泄漏”。在这种技术语境下，只有当我们完全丢失对堆数据的引用时才构成泄漏。但从用户视角看，即使我们持有引用却忘记释放——甚至明确决定不释放内存——其结果同样糟糕。

在Rust中“意外”犯这类错误的典型情况是：两个对象通过引用计数相互保持存活状态，却已被系统其他部分断开连接并遗忘。典型的垃圾回收语言会识别出这些垃圾并销毁它们，但Rust当然不是GC语言。虽然意外调用Box::leak的可能性不大（尽管可能误以为只会调用一次实际却频繁使用）。

我认为Ghostty设计中值得商榷的部分——作为一名Rust程序员——是选择使用链表结构。在我看来这显然应该使用VecDeque，即由可增长数组类型支持的环形缓冲区。他们……

posts.title: Show HN: I used Claude Code to discover connections between 100 books
posts.content:
I think LLMs are overused to summarise and underused to help us read deeper.I built a system for Claude Code to browse 100 non-fiction books and find interesting connections between them.I started out with a pipeline in stages, chaining together LLM calls to build up a context of the library. 
I was mainly getting back the insight that I was baking into the prompts, and the results weren't particularly surprising.On a whim, I gave CC access to my debug CLI tools and found that it wiped the floor with that approach. 
It gave actually interesting results and required very little orchestration in comparison.One of my favourite trail of excerpts goes from Jobs’ reality distortion field to Theranos’ fake demos, to Thiel on startup cults, to Hoffer on mass movement charlatans (https://trails.pieterma.es/trail/useful-lies/).
A fun tendency is that Claude kept getting distracted by topics of secrecy, conspiracy, and hidden systems - as if the task itself summoned a Foucault’s Pendulum mindset.Details:* The books are picked from HN’s favourites (which I collected before: https://hnbooks.pieterma.es/).* Chunks are indexed by topic using Gemini Flash Lite. The whole library cost about £10.* Topics are organised into a tree structure using recursive Leiden partitioning and LLM labels. This gives a high-level sense of the themes.* There are several ways to browse. The most useful are embedding similarity, topic tree siblings, and topics cooccurring within a chunk window.* Everything is stored in SQLite and manipulated using a set of CLI tools.I wrote more about the process here: https://pieterma.es/syntopic-reading-claude/I’m curious if this way of reading resonates for anyone else - LLM-mediated or not.
posts.author: pmaze
posts.title_cn: "Show HN：我用Claude Code发现了100本书之间的联系"
posts.content_cn:
我认为大型语言模型在总结方面被过度使用，而在帮助我们深度阅读方面却未得到充分利用。我为Claude Code构建了一个系统，能够浏览100本非虚构书籍并找出它们之间有趣的联系。最初我采用分阶段的流程，通过串联多个LLM调用来构建图书馆的语境框架。

但主要得到的只是我预先设计在提示词中的见解，结果并不特别出人意料。后来我突发奇想，让Claude Code接入我的调试命令行工具，结果发现这种方法完全超越了之前的方案。它给出了真正有趣的发现，且几乎不需要复杂的流程编排。

我最喜欢的摘录线索之一，从乔布斯的现实扭曲力场延伸到Theranos的虚假演示，再到蒂尔关于创业公司崇拜的论述，最后指向霍弗对群众运动骗术的分析（https://trails.pieterma.es/trail/useful-lies/）。一个有趣的现象是，Claude总是被秘密、阴谋和隐藏体系这类话题吸引——仿佛这个任务本身唤醒了某种《傅科摆》式的思维模式……
posts.abstract:
该帖子讨论用户利用Claude Code分析100本非虚构书籍并寻找关联性的项目。核心话题聚焦于大语言模型在深度阅读与知识关联挖掘中的应用潜力及局限性。

社区观点呈现明显分歧。部分用户肯定项目创意，认为界面设计具有启发性，并探讨了扩大数据集或聚焦核心概念节点能否提升分析深度。也有用户指出分析结果存在明显缺陷，认为模型输出的关联牵强甚至错误，如将“灭霸欺诈”与“有益谎言”强行联系，或仅基于表面词汇（如“我们/他们”）建立肤浅连接，实质是“将批判性思考过度外包给统计模型”。讨论中提到类似尝试（如用AI解构电影结构），但普遍认为当前书籍关联分析部分尚未展现真正价值。

共识在于肯定探索方向，但多数认为现有方法在语义理解与逻辑关联上仍不足，需更严谨的设计以避免生成无意义的表面关联。

Then I simply averaged all chunks for a doc and wrote that single vector back to postgresql. Then I used UMAP + HDBScan to perform dimensionality reduction and clustering. I ended up with a 2D data set that I can plot with plotly to see my clusters. It is very cool to play with this. It takes hours to import 100 pdf files but I can take one folder that contains a mix of programming titles, self-help, math, science fiction etc. After the fully automated analysis you can clearly see the different topic clusters.I just spent time getting it all running on docker compose and moved my web ui from express js to flask. I want to get the code cleaned up and open source it at some point.
comments.content_cn: 我做过类似的事情，用pdfplumber从我的PDF书籍库中提取文本。将其导入PostgreSQL后，我把文本分割成100字符的片段，并设置10字符的重叠。这些片段通过python的sentence_transformers直接嵌入到384维空间中。接着我计算每个文档所有片段的向量平均值，并将这个单一向量存回PostgreSQL。随后使用UMAP+HDBScan进行降维和聚类分析，最终得到可二维可视化的数据集，通过plotly能清晰观察到聚类分布。这个过程非常有趣——虽然导入100个PDF文件需要数小时，但当我将编程教程、自助指南、数学著作、科幻小说等混合文件夹进行全自动分析后，不同主题的聚类结果泾渭分明。最近我刚用docker compose部署了整个系统，并将网页界面从Express.js迁移到Flask。待代码整理完善后，我打算将其开源。

comments.author: pxc
comments.content: I read a book maybe a decade ago on the "digital humanities". I wish now I could remember the title and author. :(Anyway, it introduced me to the idea of using computational methods in the humanities, including literature. I found it really interesting at the time!One of the the terms it introduced me to is "distant reading", whose name mirrors that of a technique you may have studied in your gen eds if you went to university ('close reading"). The idea is that rather than zooming in on some tiny piece of text to examine very subtle or nuanced meanings, you zoom out to hundreds or thousands of texts, using computers to search them for insights that only emerge from large bodies of work as wholes. The book argued that there are likely some questions that it is only feasible to ask this way.An old friend of mine used techniques like this for dissertation in rhetoric, learning enough Python along the way to write the code needed for the analyses she wanted to do. I thought it was pretty cool!I imagine LLMs are probably positioned now to push distant reading forward in an number of ways: enabling new techniques, allowing old techniques to be used without writing code, and helping novices get started with writing some code. (A lot of the maintainability issues that come with LLM code generation happily don't apply to research projects like this.)Anyway, if you're interested in other computational techniques you can use to enrich this kind of reading, you might enjoy looking into "distant reading": https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distant_reading

I do this all the time in my Claude code workflow:
- Claude will stumble a few times before figuring out how to do part of a complex task
- I will ask it to explain what it was trying to do, how it eventually solved it, and what was missing from its environment.
- Trivial pointers go into the CLAUDE.md. Complex tasks go into a new project skill or a helper scriptThis is the best way to re-enforce a copilot because models are pretty smart most of the time and I can correct the cases where it stumbles with minimal cognitive effort. Over time I find more and more tasks are solved by agent intelligence or these happy path hints. As primitive as it is, CLAUDE.md is the best we have for long-term adaptive memory.

- 我会要求它解释原本的意图、最终的解决方案，以及环境配置中缺失了什么
- 简单的提示会记录在CLAUDE.md文件中，复杂任务则创建新的项目技能或辅助脚本

我热爱阅读。这些都是很棒的书。如果这个工具真能帮助指出被忽视的关联，我会很兴奋。然而它似乎并未做到这一点。

comments.author: ako
comments.content: According to Claude (easy guess from the wikipedia link?):The book is almost certainly by *Franco Moretti*, who coined the term "distant reading." Given the timeframe ("maybe a decade ago") and the description, it's most likely one of these two:1. *"Distant Reading"* (2013) — A collection of Moretti's essays that directly takes the concept as its title. This would fit well with "about a decade ago."2. *"Graphs, Maps, Trees: Abstract Models for Literary History"* (2005) — His earlier and very influential work that laid out the quantitative, computational approach to literary analysis, even if it didn't use "distant reading" as prominently in the title.Moretti, who founded the Stanford Literary Lab, was the major proponent of the idea that we should analyze literature not just through careful reading of individual canonical texts, but through large-scale computational analysis of hundreds or thousands of works—looking at trends in genre evolution, plot structures, title lengths, and other patterns that only emerge at scale.Given that the commenter specifically remembers learning the term "distant reading" from the book, my best guess is *"Distant Reading" (2013)*, though "Graphs, Maps, Trees" is also a strong possibility if their memory of "a decade" is approximate.
comments.content_cn:
根据克劳德（从维基百科链接不难猜到？）：这本书几乎可以确定是*弗兰科·莫雷蒂*的著作，他创造了"远读"这一术语。结合时间线（"大约十年前"）和描述内容，最可能是以下两本之一：
1. *《远读》*（2013年）——以该概念直接命名的莫雷蒂论文集，与"大约十年前"的时间点吻合。
2. *《图表、地图、树形图：文学史的抽象模型》*（2005年）——他早期极具影响力的著作，奠定了文学分析的量化计算方法基础，尽管书名未突出使用"远读"一词。

作为斯坦福文学实验室创始人，莫雷蒂是该理念的主要倡导者：我们不应仅通过细读个别经典文本来分析文学，而应对数百甚至数千部作品进行大规模计算分析——观察体裁演变趋势、情节结构、标题长度等仅在大规模研究中显现的模式。

鉴于评论者明确提到从书中了解到"远读"术语，虽然若其对"十年"的记忆是近似值则《图表、地图、树形图》也有可能，但最合理的推测应是*《远读》（2013年）*。

posts.title: Code and Let Live
posts.author: usrme
posts.title_cn: 代码与生存
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕Sprites.dev平台展开，核心话题是开发者沙盒环境的创新应用，特别是其快速启动和持久化特性如何优化开发流程。多数用户对平台表示赞赏，认为它解决了开发环境隔离与安全运行代理程序等实际问题，并欣赏fly.io平台的技术表现。  
讨论中提到一些争议点：有人认为沙盒每次使用后销毁的做法并不常见，也有用户指出安装过程中遇到卡顿等技术问题。此外，有观点强调该技术代表了软件动态化的未来趋势，应用可能根据用户需求自适应调整，但具体形态尚不明确。  
普遍认同的看法是Sprites.dev在提升开发效率与安全性方面具有潜力，且fly.io的基础设施受到肯定。分歧主要体现在对沙盒使用习惯的认知差异，以及个别用户遇到的操作障碍。

comments.author: dtkav
comments.content: fly.io is doing really good work. I've super enjoyed building our product on their platform. I love fly-replay combined with super fast start-up.I've been thinking a lot about how to run agents (and skills) securely while giving them a lot of powerful capabilities.I recently used their macaroons library to turn arbitrary API keys (e.g. for stripe's API) into macaroons. I route requests for an upstream host (like stripe) through Envoy as a mitm proxy which injects the real creds after verifying the macaroon.It is such a powerful pattern. I'm always worried about leaking sensitive keys through prompt injection attacks (or just sending them to anthropic), but in this model you can attenuate the keys (both capabilities & validity window) client side. The Envoy proxy lives inside my flycast network so it can't be accessed externally.It would be so cool if fly built something like this into sprites.dev (though I can see how it would be spooky to have fly install their own certs for stripe, etc...)

fly.io 的工作确实出色。我在他们的平台上开发产品时体验极佳，尤其喜欢 fly-replay 与极速启动的结合。最近我一直在思考如何在赋予智能体（及技能）强大能力的同时确保其安全运行。

最近我运用他们的 macaroons 库将任意 API 密钥（例如 Stripe 的 API 密钥）转换为 macaroons。我通过 Envoy 作为中间人代理，将发往上游主机（如 Stripe）的请求进行路由，并在验证 macaroon 后注入真实凭证。

这种模式非常强大。我一直担心敏感密钥会通过提示注入攻击（或直接发送给 Anthropic）而泄露，但在这个模型中，客户端可以限制密钥的权限（包括能力范围和有效期）。Envoy 代理部署在我的 flycast 网络内部，因此无法从外部访问。

如果 fly 能在 sprites.dev 中内置类似功能就太棒了（尽管我能理解让 fly 为 Stripe 等安装自有证书可能会令人不安……）
